Sec. 3-33. - Application forms. (a)  All persons desiring to sell or manufacture alcoholic beverages shall make application on the form prescribed by the city clerk. (b)  The application shall include but shall not be limited to: the name and address of the applicant; the proposed business to be carried on; if a partnership, the names and residence addresses of the partners; if a corporation, the names of the officers; the name and address of the agent for service of process; the name and address of the manager; and the name of all shareholders holding more than ten (10) percent of any class of corporate stock, or any other entity having a financial interest in each entity which is to own or operate the establishment. If the manager changes, the applicant must furnish the city clerk and the police department with the name and address of the new manager and other information as requested within ten (10) days of such change. (c)  All applicants shall furnish data, information and records as required by the city clerk and to ensure compliance with the provisions of this chapter. Failure to furnish data as requested shall automatically serve to dismiss the application with prejudice. (d)  All applications shall be sworn to by the applicant before a notary public or other officer to administer oaths. (e)  In all instances in which an application is denied under the provisions of this chapter, the applicant may not reapply for a license for at least one (1) year from the final date of such denial. (f)  The city clerk shall provide written notice to any applicant whose application is denied under the provisions of this chapter. Such written notification shall set forth in reasonable detail the reasons for such denial and shall advise the applicant of the right to appeal under the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. No. 14-01, § 1, 1-27-2014) 
Sec. 3-34. - Separate application and separate license for each location of sale.     A separate application must be made for each location and a separate license must be issued. (Ord. No. 14-01, § 1, 1-27-2014) 
Sec. 3-35. - Fee scale. (a)  Before a license shall be granted, the applicant therefore shall comply with all rules and regulations adopted by the governing authority regulating the sale or manufacture of alcoholic beverages and each applicant shall pay a license fee in accordance with the scale fixed by the governing authority and set forth in division 2 of this chapter. (b)  In addition, a permit fee in the amount of ten dollars ($10.00) shall be paid to the city precedent to the issuance of any employee permit authorized under the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. No. 14-01, § 1, 1-27-2014) 
Sec. 3-36. - Alcoholic beverage review board.     There is hereby established an alcoholic beverage review board which shall have the duty of hearing appeals from decisions of the city clerk denying the issuance or renewal of any license pertaining to the sale of alcoholic beverages in the city and to hear appeals from the decision of the city clerk revoking or suspending a license. The alcoholic beverage review board shall be composed of the city manager, the chief of police, and the codes enforcement officer. (Ord. No. 14-01, § 1, 1-27-2014) 
Sec. 3-37. - Hearings. (a)  No license shall be denied, suspended or revoked without the opportunity for a hearing as provided in this section. (b)  The city clerk shall provide written notice to the applicant or licensee of the order to deny, suspend, or revoke the license. Such written notification shall set forth in reasonable detail the reasons for such action and shall notify the applicant or licensee of the right to appeal under the provisions of this chapter. Any applicant or licensee who is aggrieved or adversely affected by a final action of the city clerk may have a review thereof by appeal to the alcoholic beverage review board. Such appeal shall be by written petition filed in the office of the city clerk within fifteen (15) days after notification of the final order or action of the city clerk. (c)  A hearing shall be conducted on each appeal within thirty (30) days of the date of filing with the city clerk unless a continuance of such date is agreed to by the appellant and city clerk. The appellant at such hearing shall have the right to be represented by an attorney, at the expense of the appellant, and to present evidence and cross examine witnesses. (d)  The findings of the alcoholic beverage review board shall be provided to the city clerk after the conclusion of the hearing and it shall be the duty of the city clerk to notify in writing the appellant of the action of the alcoholic beverage review board. (e)  The findings of the alcoholic beverage review board shall not be set aside unless found to be: (1)  Contrary to law or ordinances; (2)  Unsupported by substantial evidence on the record as a whole; or (3)  Wholly unreasonable in the circumstances. (f)  The findings of the alcoholic beverage review board shall be final unless appealed within thirty (30) days of the date of such findings by certiorari to the superior court of the county. (Ord. No. 14-01, § 1, 1-27-2014) 
Sec. 3-38. - Display at place of business.     The city license shall at all times be displayed prominently on the premises for which the license is issued. (Ord. No. 14-01, § 1, 1-27-2014) 
Sec. 3-39. - Transferability. (a)  No license for the sale or manufacture of alcoholic beverages shall be transferable except as otherwise provided in this section. (b)  In case of the death of a licensee, the establishment shall be allowed to continue to sell or manufacture alcoholic beverages for a period of forty-five (45) days from the date of death, or until expiration of the license, or until approval of a new licensee, whichever shall first occur. However, no sale of alcoholic beverages shall be allowed until such time as a personal representative of the estate, appointed by a probate court of competent jurisdiction, shall make application for authorization with the city clerk. (c)  If a license is surrendered or a licensee severs his association with a licensed establishment, the establishment may continue to sell or manufacture alcoholic beverages for a period of forty-five (45) days from the date of surrender or from the date determined to be the date of severance. However, no such sale or manufacture shall be authorized until such time as a new application for a license is made, such application indicating that no change of ownership has occurred, except as excepted in this section. Upon issuance of a new license, the authorization to sell or manufacture under the previous license shall be revoked by operation of law. No additional license fees shall be required during the period for which the original license was issued. (d)  Nothing in this section, however, shall prohibit one (1) or more of the partners in the partnership holding a license to withdraw from the partnership in favor of one (1) or more of the partners who were partners at the time of the issuance of the license. This section shall not prohibit transfer of stock between persons who held stock in the corporate owner at the time of issuance of the license nor shall it prohibit transfers of stock which do not result in any person increasing his stock holdings to a total of ten (10) percent or more of any class of stock. (e)  Should a transfer of location be approved, with no change of ownership of the business, the license fee paid for the old location shall be applied to the new location. (f)  Except as provided above, any change in the ownership of any entity owning a licensed establishment shall automatically cancel and revoke any license issued under this article without the necessity of any hearing. (g)  Violation of this section shall result in revocation of the license being used and a fine on the new ownership and the old ownership of five hundred dollars ($500.00). No license will be issued to the old or the new owner in the city for one (1) year from the date of the violation. (Ord. No. 14-01, § 1, 1-27-2014) 
Sec. 3-40. - Expiration; renewal. (a)  All licenses granted under this article shall expire on December 31 of each year. Licensees who desire to renew their license shall file application, with the requisite annual fee provided in division 2 of this article, with the city clerk on the form provided for renewal of the license for the ensuing year. Applications for renewal must be filed by November 30 of each year; otherwise, investigative and administrative costs and penalties will be assessed. No renewal license shall be granted after January. Such application shall be treated as an initial application and the applicant shall be required to comply with all rules and regulations for the granting of licenses as if no previous license had been held. (b)  All licenses granted under this article shall be for the full calendar year or for the number of months remaining in the calendar year. License fees shall be prorated based on the number of months remaining in the calendar year; partial months shall be counted as a full month. License fees are not refundable. (c)  Any person renewing any license issued under this article who shall pay the required fee, or any portion thereof, after the date set for such payment shall, in addition to such annual fee, pay a late payment penalty of ten (10) percent plus five (5) percent for each additional month, or fraction thereof, during which failure continues. Such penalty shall not exceed twenty-five (25) percent in the aggregate. (Ord. No. 14-01, § 1, 1-27-2014) 
Sec. 3-41. - Suspension or revocation. (a)  A license may be suspended or revoked by the city clerk where the licensee furnishes fraudulent or untruthful information in the application for a license, or omits information required in the application for a license, and for failure to pay all fees, taxes or other charges imposed under the provisions of this chapter. (b)  Whenever the state shall revoke any permit or license to sell or manufacture alcoholic beverages, the city license shall thereupon be automatically revoked. The chief of police, upon notice of this revocation from the city clerk, shall take the necessary steps to see that signs are removed and that all alcoholic beverage sales and manufacture cease. (c)  Any licensed establishment that is found to be in violation of section 3-14 shall be subject to immediate license revocation in addition to all other penalties provided for in this chapter. (d)  The city clerk shall revoke the license of any licensee where the establishment has been found in violation of the Sunday sales ordinance. (e)  The city clerk shall revoke the license of any licensee whose license has been suspended three (3) or more times in any consecutive twelve-month period. (f)  The city clerk shall revoke the license for any premises where alcoholic beverages have been sold or distributed during a period of suspension. (g)  The city clerk may suspend or revoke the license of any establishment which does not meet the licensing qualifications set forth in this chapter at any time such knowledge becomes known to him. (h)  An act or omission, willingly or knowingly performed, of a licensee, owner of more than ten (10) percent interest in the licensed establishment, or employee of the licensee or licensed establishment which constitutes a violation of federal or state law or of any provision of this chapter will subject the licensee to suspension or revocation of his license in accordance with the provisions of this chapter when evidence is submitted to the city clerk that the act or omission did occur, regardless of whether any criminal prosecution or conviction ensues. However, in the case of a violation by an employee, evidence must be submitted to the city clerk that the acts of the employee were known to or, under reasonable circumstances, should have been known to the licensee, were condoned by the licensee, or that the licensee has not established practices or procedures to prevent the violation from occurring, or that the licensee fails to properly train or supervise employees to prevent the violation from occurring. Notwithstanding the provisions of this section for the suspension or revocation of a license, no such suspension or revocation shall be imposed except for a violation occurring within twelve (12) months after a licensee has been given a written letter of warning, pursuant to procedures listed below as to a reported or observed violation by the licensee's establishment: (1)  Upon receipt of a complaint for a violation of section 3-7, the police department shall send the establishment's licensee a certified letter advising that a complaint has been received by the city and stating that such acts place the licensing status of the establishment in jeopardy. (2)  Should the police department not receive postal confirmation of delivery to the licensee within ten (10) days, the officer assigned to the complaint will hand deliver a copy of the previously sent certified notice to the licensee or the establishment's registered agent. The officer shall require the licensee's or registered agent's personal signature to verify that service was effected. (3)  Upon receipt of a subsequent complaint, the police department shall conduct an appropriate investigation to determine whether the establishment does, in fact, permit or require an employee under the age of eighteen (18) to violate section 3-7. (4)  Should such a violation be established, the licensee and the person committing the violation shall be cited to the municipal court of the city for the code violation. Further, the police department will prepare an incident report detailing all facts and events concerning the violation. This report, along with a copy of the aforementioned certified notice and proof of delivery, shall be sent to the city clerk for a suspension/revocation hearing. (i)  Subject to the provisions of this chapter, a violation of section 3-13 by a licensee, or owner of more than ten (10) percent interest in the licensed establishment, or employee of the licensee or licensed establishment shall result in license suspension for a period not less than two (2) days which shall be scheduled to include a Friday and Saturday; second violation within a consecutive twelve-month period shall result in license suspension for a period not less than one (1) week; third violation within a consecutive twenty-four month period shall result in license revocation. (j)  If a licensee or licensed establishment is convicted of violating O.C.G.A. § 3-3-21(a)(1), prohibiting the furnishing of alcoholic beverages to minors, or action is taken against the holder of a license for violating any state or local law relating to the sale of alcoholic beverages to minors, the city clerk shall notify the state department of revenue of such violation or action. (Ord. No. 14-01, § 1, 1-27-2014) 
Sec. 3-42. - Establishment to open for business within three (3) months of issuance; cessation of operation; automatic forfeiture for failure to open and remain open. (a)  All holders of licenses under this section must open for business the establishment referred to in the license within three (3) months after issuance of the license. Failure to open the licensed establishment within such time shall automatically forfeit and cancel the unused license, and no refund of license fees shall be made to the license holder. (b)  Any holder of a license under this article who shall begin the operation of the business as authorized in the license, but who shall cease to operate the business as authorized in the license for a period of three (3) consecutive months, shall automatically forfeit his license. Such license shall, by virtue of such failure to operate, be canceled by the city clerk. (Ord. No. 14-01, § 1, 1-27-2014) 
Secs. 3-43—3-55. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - FEES 
Sec. 3-56. - License fees and permits. (a)  An annual license fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) shall be charged to wholesale dealers in beer and malt beverages when the principal place of business is located outside the corporate boundaries of the city. (b)  An annual license fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) shall be charged to wholesale dealers in wine with the principal place of business located outside the corporate boundaries of the city when deliveries are made inside the city in conjunction with sales of alcoholic beverages. (c)  An annual license fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) shall be charged to wholesale dealers in distilled spirits with the principal place of business located outside the corporate boundaries of the city when deliveries are made inside the city in conjunction with sales of alcoholic beverages. (d)  An annual license fee of six hundred dollars ($600.00) shall be charged to wholesale dealers in beer and malt beverages when the principal place of business is located inside the corporate boundaries of the city. (e)  An annual license fee of six hundred dollars ($600.00) shall be charged to wholesale dealers in wine when the principal place of business is located inside the corporate boundaries of the city. (f)  An annual license fee of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) shall be charged to wholesale dealers in beer, malt beverages and wine when the principal place of business is located inside the corporate boundaries of the city. (g)  An annual license fee of two thousand five hundred twenty dollars ($2,520.00) shall be charged to wholesale dealers in beer, malt beverages, wine, and distilled spirits when the principal place of business is located inside the corporate boundaries of the city. (h)  An annual license fee of six hundred dollars ($600.00) shall be charged to sell beer and malt beverages at retail in original packages, not to be consumed on the premises. (i)  An annual license fee of six hundred dollars ($600.00) shall be charged to sell wine at retail in original packages, not to be consumed on the premises. (j)  An annual license fee of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) shall be charged to sell beer, malt beverages, and wine at retail in original packages, not to be consumed on the premises, at the same location. (k)  An annual license fee of two thousand five dollars ($2,500.00) shall be charged to sell distilled spirits at retail in original packages, not to be consumed on the premises. (l)  An annual license fee of six hundred dollars ($600.00) shall be charged to sell beer and malt beverages for consumption on the premises. (m)  An annual license fee of six hundred dollars ($600.00) shall be charged to sell wine for consumption on the premises. (n)  An annual license fee of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) shall be charged to sell beer, malt beverages, and wine for consumption on the premises, at the same location. (o)  An annual license fee of two thousand five hundred twenty dollars ($2,520.00) shall be charged to sell distilled spirits, beer, malt beverages, and wine for consumption on the premises. (p)  An annual fee of three hundred forty dollars ($340.00) shall be charged for a Sunday sales permit for qualified establishments to sell beer, malt beverages, and/or wine and/or distilled spirits for consumption on the premises. (q)  A fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) per day for a temporary license for the sale of distilled spirits, beer, malt beverages, and/or wine by a nonprofit civic organization for consumption on the premises. (r)  An additional annual fee of two hundred forty dollars ($240.00) shall be charged for an alcoholic beverage caterer license for establishments licensed to sell or distribute beer, malt beverages, wine or distilled spirits by the drink off-premises in connection with authorized catered functions. (s)  An annual license fee of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) shall be charged for a qualified wine retailer to hold wine tastings pursuant to article XI of this chapter. (t)  An annual license fee of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) shall be charged for a qualified beer retailer to hold beer tastings pursuant to article XII of this chapter. (u)  An annual license fee of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) shall be charged for a qualified craft brewery to manufacture on-premises. (v)  An annual license fee of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) shall be charged for a qualified craft distillery to manufacture on-premises. (w)  An annual license fee of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) shall be charged for a qualified craft beer brewery to hold beer tastings pursuant to article XII of this chapter. (x)  An annual license fee of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) shall be charged for a qualified craft distilled spirit manufacturer to hold distilled spirit tastings pursuant to article XIII of this chapter. (Ord. No. 14-01, § 1, 1-27-2014) 
Secs. 3-57—3-69. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - RETAIL SALES OF BEER, MALT BEVERAGES AND WINE FOR CONSUMPTION ON THE PREMISES 
Sec. 3-70. - License fee and amount to defray investigative and administrative costs to accompany application.     Each application for a license under this article shall be accompanied by a certified check for the full amount of the license fee plus a separate check or cash in the amount of one hundred dollars ($100.00) to defray investigative and administrative costs. If the application is denied and the license refused, or if the applicant withdraws his application prior to its being issued, the license fee shall be refunded but the one hundred dollars ($100.00) paid for investigation and administrative costs shall be retained. (Ord. No. 14-01, § 1, 1-27-2014) 
Sec. 3-71. - Hours of sale. (a)  Beer and/or wine shall not be sold for consumption on the premises except between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 11:55 p.m., Monday through Saturday, and the two (2) hours immediately following such time, i.e., until 1:55 a.m. on the subsequent day. (b)  Any alcoholic beverage served must be consumed within thirty (30) minutes of the required closing. (Ord. No. 14-01, § 1, 1-27-2014) 
Sec. 3-72. - Sunday sales authorization. (a)  Licensed establishments deriving a minimum of fifty (50) percent of their total annual gross food and beverage sales from the sale of prepared meals or food, or licensed establishments deriving at least fifty (50) percent of their total annual gross income from the rental of rooms for overnight lodging, are authorized to apply for a Sunday sales permit to sell and serve alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises on Sundays between the hours of 11:00 a.m. and 12:00 midnight. (b)  Applicants for a Sunday sales permit shall complete a form and affidavit furnished by the city clerk and certify the percentages, as required in subsection (a) of this section, for the most recently ended fiscal year. For new establishments, no affidavit shall be required and such establishments shall be allowed six (6) months to comply with the fifty-percent rule. An audit may be required at any time to ensure compliance. (c)  All annual permit renewals shall be filed with the city clerk not later than November 30 of the year preceding the license year for which the permit is to be issued. All renewals are subject to audit and must be accompanied with a sworn affidavit that certifies the percentages, as required in subsection (a) of this section, for the most recently ended fiscal year prior to being renewed to ensure compliance with this chapter. (d)  Sunday sales permits are granted for the full calendar year for the number of months remaining in the calendar year. The permit fee shall be prorated based on the number of months remaining in the calendar year; partial months shall be counted as a full month. Fees are not refundable and permits shall not be transferable. (Ord. No. 14-01, § 1, 1-27-2014; Ord. No. 18-06, § 1, 11-19-2018) 
Sec. 3-73. - Open area, deck and patio sales.     No consumption and/or sale of alcoholic beverages shall be allowed in open areas, decks, patios or similar unenclosed spaces on the premises of an establishment licensed to sell alcoholic beverages unless written application is made to and approved by the governing authority under such conditions as it may deem appropriate for the protection of public health, safety and welfare including, but not limited to, maximum capacity, ingress and egress. (Ord. No. 14-01, § 1, 1-27-2014) 
Sec. 3-74. - Employee regulations. (a)  The following regulations shall apply to all establishments holding a license for consumption of beer and/or wine on the premises: (1)  Except for the residency requirements, an employee shall meet the same character requirements as set forth in the general ordinances for the licensee. (2)  No person shall be employed by an establishment holding a license hereunder until such person has been cleared by the city police department and a permit issued indicating that such person is eligible for this employment. (3)  No permit shall be issued until such time as a signed application has been filed with the city police department and a search of the criminal record of the applicant completed. The application shall include, but shall not be limited to, the name, date of birth, and prior arrest record of the applicant. The fact of an arrest record shall be used for investigative purposes only and shall give rise to no presumption or inference of guilt. Due to the inclusion of arrest information, these applications shall be regarded as confidential and shall not be produced for public inspection without a court order. (4)  The chief of police shall have a complete and exhaustive search made relative to any police record of the person. If there is no record of a violation of this chapter, the chief of police shall issue a permit to the employee which states that the person is eligible for employment. If it is found that the person is not eligible for employment, the chief of police shall notify the employer that this person is not eligible for employment. (5)  It shall be the duty of all persons holding any license to sell alcoholic beverages to file with the chief of police the name of the establishment, the license number and a list of all employees, with their home addresses and home telephone numbers, twice annually on or before June 1 and again on or before December 1. (6)  All permits issued through administrative error or through an error in completion of a background investigation can be terminated by the chief of police or the city clerk. (7)  This section shall not be construed to include employees whose duties are limited solely to those of busboy, cook or dishwasher. (8)  No licensee shall allow any employee required to hold a permit to work on the licensed premises unless the licensee has on file, on the premises, the current, valid permit of each such employee. (9)  If any permit holder leaves the employ of a licensed establishment, the licensee shall immediately surrender the permit to the city police department. (10)  All permits shall expire at midnight on December 31 of the calendar year for which they are issued. (11)  All permits issued hereunder remain the property of the city and shall be produced for inspection upon the demand of any officer of the city police department. (b)  The permit issued to a person under this section shall include the person's name and address, the name of the establishment, and the address of the establishment. Permits shall be either of the following: (1)  An alcoholic beverage permit which shall be issued only to a person eighteen (18) years of age or older who sells, serves or dispenses alcoholic beverages; or (2)  A nonalcoholic beverage permit which shall be issued to a person whose employment includes, but is not limited to, host, hostess, doorman and bouncer. (Ord. No. 14-01, § 1, 1-27-2014) 
Secs. 3-75—3-89. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - RETAIL SALES OF DISTILLED SPIRITS FOR CONSUMPTION ON THE PREMISES 
Sec. 3-90. - License fee and amount to defray investigative and administrative costs to accompany application.     Each application for a license under this article shall be accompanied by a certified check for the full amount of the license fee plus a separate check or cash in the amount of two hundred dollars ($200.00) to defray investigative and administrative costs. If the application is denied and the license refused, or if the applicant withdraws his application prior to its being issued, the license fee shall be refunded but the two hundred dollars ($200.00) paid for investigation and administrative costs shall be retained. (Ord. No. 14-01, § 1, 1-27-2014) 
Sec. 3-91. - Excise tax on sale of distilled spirits by the drink. (a)  There is imposed and levied upon every sale of an alcoholic beverage purchased by the drink in the city an excise tax in the amount of three (3) percent of the purchase price of such beverage. (b)  Every licensee for the sale of alcoholic beverages by the drink operating a place of business in the city shall, at the time of collecting for food and drinks served, give to the purchaser a receipt on which the price of alcoholic beverages served shall be itemized separately. Where the charges for food and drink are satisfied by credit or deferred payment, the payment of the tax to the licensee may be deferred in a like manner; however, the licensee shall be liable therefor at the time and to the extent that such credits are incurred. (c)  Every licensee or the licensee's agent shall collect the tax imposed in this section from purchasers of alcoholic beverages by the drink sold within the licensee's licensed premises. Such licensee or agent shall furnish such information as may be requested by the city clerk to facilitate the collection of the tax. (d)  All taxes collected by any licensee or agent under this article shall be due and payable to the city clerk monthly on or before the twentieth (20 th ) day of every month next succeeding each respective monthly period. (e)  On or before the twentieth (20 th ) day of the month following each monthly period, a return for the preceding monthly period shall be filed with the city clerk in such form as the city clerk may prescribe by every licensee or agent liable for the payment of the excise tax. (f)  All returns shall show the gross receipts from the sale of alcoholic beverages by the drink, amount of tax collected or authorized due for the related period, and such other information as may be required by the city clerk. (g)  The person required to file the return shall deliver the return with the remittance of the net amount of tax due to the city clerk. (h)  Operators collecting the tax shall be allowed a deduction of three (3) percent of the tax due and accounted for and shall be reimbursed in the form of a deduction in submitting, reporting, and paying the amount due, if such amount is not delinquent at the time of payment. (i)  Any licensee who fails to pay the tax to the city within the time required shall pay a penalty of ten (10) percent of the tax, plus interest at the rate of one (1) percent per month. (Ord. No. 14-01, § 1, 1-27-2014) 
Sec. 3-92. - Hours of sale. (a)  Distilled spirits shall not be sold for consumption on the premises except between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 11:55 p.m., Monday through Saturday, and the two (2) hours immediately following such time, i.e., until 1:55 a.m. on the subsequent day. (b)  Any alcoholic beverage served must be consumed within thirty (30) minutes of the required closing. (Ord. No. 14-01, § 1, 1-27-2014) 
Sec. 3-93. - Sunday sales authorization. (a)  Licensed establishments deriving a minimum of fifty (50) percent of their total annual gross food and beverage sales from the sale of prepared meals or food, or licensed establishments deriving at least fifty (50) percent of their total annual gross income from the rental of rooms for overnight lodging, are authorized to apply for a Sunday sales permit to sell and serve alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises on Sundays between the hours of 12:30 p.m. and 12:00 midnight. (b)  Applicants for a Sunday sales permit shall complete a form and affidavit furnished by the city clerk and certify the percentages, as required in subsection (a) of this section, for the most recently ended fiscal year. For new establishments, no affidavit shall be required and such establishments shall be allowed six (6) months to comply with the fifty-percent rule. An audit may be required at any time to ensure compliance. (c)  All annual permit renewals shall be filed with the city clerk not later than November 30 of the year preceding the license year for which the permit is to be issued. All renewals are subject to audit and must be accompanied with a sworn affidavit that certifies the percentages, as required in subsection (a) of this section, for the most recently ended fiscal year prior to being renewed to ensure compliance with this chapter. (d)  Sunday sales permits are granted for the full calendar year for the number of months remaining in the calendar year. The permit fee shall be prorated based on the number of months remaining in the calendar year; partial months shall be counted as a full month. Fees are not refundable and permits shall not be transferable. (Ord. No. 14-01, § 1, 1-27-2014) 
Sec. 3-94. - Consumption sales only.     Persons holding a license to sell distilled spirits for consumption on the premises shall not be permitted to sell liquor by the package or bottle at the same location. (Ord. No. 14-01, § 1, 1-27-2014) 
Sec. 3-95. - Open area, deck and patio sales.     No consumption and/or sale of alcoholic beverages shall be allowed in open areas, decks, patios or similar unenclosed spaces on the premises of an establishment licensed to sell alcoholic beverages unless written application is made to and approved by the governing authority under such conditions as it may deem appropriate for the protection of public health, safety and welfare including, but not limited to, maximum capacity, ingress and egress. (Ord. No. 14-01, § 1, 1-27-2014) 
Sec. 3-96. - Employee regulations. (a)  The following regulations shall apply to all establishments holding a license for consumption of distilled spirits on the premises: (1)  Except for the residency requirements, an employee shall meet the same character requirements as set forth in the general ordinances for the licensee. (2)  No person shall be employed by an establishment holding a license under this article until such person has been cleared by the city police department and a permit issued indicating that such person is eligible for this employment. (3)  No permit shall be issued until such time as a signed application has been filed with the city police department and a search of the criminal record of the applicant completed. The application shall include, but shall not be limited to, the name, date of birth, and prior arrest record of the applicant. The fact of an arrest record shall be used for investigative purposes only and shall give rise to no presumption or inference of guilt. Due to the inclusion of arrest information, these applications shall be regarded as confidential and shall not be produced for public inspection without a court order. (4)  The chief of police shall have a complete and exhaustive search made relative to any police record of the person. If there is no record of a violation of this chapter, the chief of police shall issue a permit to the employee which states that the person is eligible for employment. If it is found that the person is not eligible for employment, the chief of police shall notify the employer that this person is not eligible for employment. (5)  It shall be the duty of all persons holding any license to sell alcoholic beverages to file with the chief of police the name of the establishment, the license number and a list of all employees, with their home addresses and home telephone numbers, twice annually on or before June 1 and again on or before December 1. (6)  All permits issued through administrative error or through an error in completion of a background investigation can be terminated by the chief of police or the city clerk. (7)  This section shall not be construed to include employees whose duties are limited solely to those of busboy, cook or dishwasher. (8)  No licensee shall allow any employee required to hold a permit to work on the licensed premises unless the licensee has on file, on the premises, the current, valid permit of each such employee. (9)  If any permit holder leaves the employ of a licensed establishment, the licensee shall immediately surrender the permit to the city police department. (10)  All permits shall expire at midnight on December 31 of the calendar year for which they are issued. (11)  All permits issued hereunder remain the property of the city and shall be produced for inspection upon the demand of any officer of the city police department. (b)  The permit issued to a person under this section shall include the person's name and address, the name of the establishment, and the address of the establishment. Permits shall be either of the following: (1)  An alcoholic beverage permit which shall be issued only to a person eighteen (18) years of age or older who sells, serves, or dispenses alcoholic beverages; or (2)  A nonalcoholic beverage permit which shall be issued to a person whose employment includes, but is not limited to, host, hostess, doorman and bouncer. (Ord. No. 14-01, § 1, 1-27-2014) 
Secs. 3-97—3-110. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - PRIVATE CLUBS 
Sec. 3-111. - Definitions.     The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:     Fixed salary means the amount of compensation paid any member, officer, agent, or employee of a bona fide private club as may be fixed for him by its members at a prior annual meeting or by the governing body out of the general revenue of the club and shall not include a commission on any profits from the sale of alcoholic beverages. For the purpose of this definition, tips or gratuities which are added to the bills under club regulation shall not be considered as profits from the sale of alcoholic beverages.     Private club means any nonprofit association organized under the laws of this state which: (1)  Has been in existence at least one (1) year prior to the filing of its application for a license to be issued pursuant to this chapter; (2)  Has at least seventy-five (75) regular dues-paying members; and (3)  No member, officer, agent or employee directly or indirectly receiving in the form of salary or other compensation any profits from the sale of alcoholic beverages beyond a fixed salary. (Ord. No. 14-01, § 1, 1-27-2014) 
Sec. 3-112. - Retail sales for consumption on the premises.     Private clubs may sell and dispense alcoholic beverages by the drink for consumption upon the premises of the private club upon compliance with all applicable ordinances and regulations of the city governing the sale of such beverages and upon payment of such license fees and taxes as may be required by the existing ordinances, rules, and regulations of the city, including, but not limited to, articles I, II, III and IV of this chapter. (Ord. No. 14-01, § 1, 1-27-2014) 
Secs. 3-113—3-119. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - NONPROFIT CIVIC ORGANIZATIONS 
Sec. 3-120. - Eligibility for issuance of temporary license. (a)  Any bona fide nonprofit civic organization may be issued a temporary permit to sell alcoholic beverages for consumption only on the premises for a period not to exceed one (1) day. The nonprofit civic organization must make application and pay a fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00). (b)  No more than two (2) permits may be issued to an organization in any one (1) calendar year. (c)  Such civic organizations shall be required to comply with all ordinance regulations dealing with general licensing and consumption on the premises' establishments. (Ord. No. 14-01, § 1, 1-27-2014) 
Secs. 3-121—3-129. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - RETAIL PACKAGE SALES OF BEER AND WINE 
Sec. 3-130. - Hours of sale.     Retail package licensees shall not engage in the sale of beer and/or wine except between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 12:00 midnight, Monday through Saturday, and between the hours of 12:30 p.m. and 11:30 p.m. on Sunday. The hours within which business may be carried on shall be determined by the standard time in force at the time of sale thereof. (Ord. No. 14-01, § 1, 1-27-2014) 
Sec. 3-131. - Use of tags or labels to indicate prices.     Retailers shall indicate plainly, by tags or labels on the bottles or containers or on the shelf immediately below where the containers are placed, the prices of all beer and wine exposed or offered for sale. (Ord. No. 14-01, § 1, 1-27-2014) 
Sec. 3-132. - License fee and amount to defray investigative and administrative costs to accompany application.     Each application for a license under this article shall be accompanied by a certified check for the full amount of the license fee plus a separate check or cash in the amount of one hundred dollars ($100.00) to defray investigative and administrative costs. If the application is denied and the license refused, or if the applicant withdraws his application prior to its being issued, the license fee shall be refunded but the one hundred dollars ($100.00) paid for investigation and administrative costs shall be retained. (Ord. No. 14-01, § 1, 1-27-2014) 
Secs. 3-133—3-139. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - RETAIL PACKAGE SALES OF DISTILLED SPIRITS 
Sec. 3-140. - Hours of sale.     Retail package licensees shall not engage in the sale of distilled spirits except between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 12:00 midnight, Monday through Saturday, and between the hours of 12:30 p.m. and 11:30 p.m. on Sunday. The hours within which business may be carried on shall be determined by the standard time in force at the time of sale thereof. (Ord. No. 14-01, § 1, 1-27-2014) 
Sec. 3-141. - Use of tags or labels to indicate prices.     Retailers shall indicate plainly, by tags or labels on the bottles or containers or on the shelf immediately below where the containers are placed, the prices of all distilled spirits exposed or offered for sale. (Ord. No. 14-01, § 1, 1-27-2014) 
Sec. 3-142. - License fee and amount to defray investigative and administrative costs to accompany application.     Each application for a license under this article shall be accompanied by a certified check for the full amount of the license fee plus a separate check or cash in the amount of one hundred dollars ($100.00) to defray investigative and administrative costs. If the application is denied and the license refused, or if the applicant withdraws his application prior to its being issued, the license fee shall be refunded but the one hundred dollars ($100.00) paid for investigation and administrative costs shall be retained. (Ord. No. 14-01, § 1, 1-27-2014) 
Sec. 3-143. - Special regulations for retail package businesses selling distilled spirits.     Every retailer of distilled spirits within the city shall comply with each of the following regulations as a condition of the retailer's license to sell distilled spirits by the package. Violation of this section may result in suspension or revocation of the retailer's license. (1)  No retailer shall sell or offer for sale a package of distilled spirits containing less than seventeen (17) fluid ounces; (2)  Every retailer licensed to sell distilled spirits by the package shall post a sign that reads "No Loitering" in a prominent location near the entrance of the business and such retailer shall not allow one (1) or more persons to loiter in or near his business; (3)  No retailer of distilled spirits shall maintain bars or other similar security devices on the outside of the door(s) or window(s) of his business, though bars may be installed inside the building at the retailer's option; (4)  No retailer of distilled spirits may permit on his premises any "amusement machine" as defined by O.C.G.A. § 16-12-35, any billiard tables, or any other device or game of any type or character which may be operated for amusement purposes; (5)  No retailer of distilled spirits shall also be a "retailer" of lottery tickets, as defined by O.C.G.A. § 50-27-3(22), at the same location. (6)  No retailer of distilled spirits shall offer any tobacco products for sale at the same location where distilled spirits are sold. (7)  No retailer of distilled spirits shall offer growlers for sale at the same location where distilled spirits are sold. (Ord. No. 14-01, § 1, 1-27-2014) 
Secs. 3-144—3-160. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - WHOLESALERS 
Sec. 3-161. - Special provisions applicable to wholesale license. (a)  Any person desiring to sell, at wholesale, any alcoholic beverages in the city shall make written application on the prescribed forms to the city clerk for a license to do so and pay any license fee as set by the governing authority. (b)  No person who has any direct financial interest in a license for the retail sale of distilled spirits shall be allowed to have any interest or ownership in any wholesale distilled spirit license. (c)  No retailer shall purchase any alcoholic beverage from any person other than a wholesaler licensed under this article. No wholesaler shall sell any alcoholic beverage to any person other than a retailer licensed under this chapter. (d)  No alcoholic beverage shall be delivered to any retail sales outlet in the city except by a duly licensed wholesaler. The name of the wholesaler distributor shall be clearly marked on the delivery vehicle. (Ord. No. 14-01, § 1, 1-27-2014) 
Sec. 3-162. - Excise tax. (a)  There is hereby imposed an excise tax upon all alcoholic beverages purchased by persons holding a retail package license and/or consumption on the premises license at the following rates: (1)  Where malt beverages, commonly known as tap or draft beer, are sold in or from a barrel or bulk container, a tax of six dollars ($6.00) on each container sold containing not more than fifteen and one-half (15 ½) gallons and a proportionate tax at the same rate on all fractional parts of fifteen and one-half (15 ½) gallons; (2)  Where beer or malt beverages are sold in bottles, cans, or other containers, except barrel or bulk containers, a tax of five cents ($0.05) per twelve (12) ounces and a proportionate tax at the same rate on all fractional parts of twelve (12) ounces; (3)  On the first sale or use of wine by the package, a tax of twenty-two cents ($0.22) per liter and a proportionate tax at the same rate on all fractional parts of a liter; (4)  On the first sale or use of distilled spirits, a tax of twenty-two cents ($0.22) per liter of distilled spirits and a proportionate tax at the same rate on all fractional parts of a liter. (b)  The excise tax shall be collected by all wholesale dealers selling alcoholic beverages to licensed retailers and shall be paid by the wholesale dealers to the city clerk by the tenth (10 th ) of each month, based upon the units of alcohol sold during the previous month. Interest shall accrue on late payments at the rate of one (1) percent per month. The wholesale dealer shall keep true and correct records of all sales and shipments. The monthly remittance shall be accompanied by a sworn statement showing, but not limited to, the type and volume sold to each retail licensee on a form or in a format as approved by the city clerk. (Ord. No. 14-01, § 1, 1-27-2014) 
Sec. 3-163. - Bond required on wholesalers. (a)  Each wholesale dealer, prior to commencement of business operation in the city, shall post a performance bond with the city clerk equal to one and one-half (1 ½) times the estimated highest monthly payment made in a calendar year of the excise tax, based on sales collected by the wholesale dealer from the retailers, to secure the payments for the tax imposed herein. These bonds shall be secured by cash, which shall bear no interest, or a surety bond executed by a surety company licensed to do business in this state. (b)  A wholesaler may be excused from posting the performance bond as provided in this section after demonstrating full and satisfactory compliance with the provisions required hereunder for a period of twelve (12) months subsequent to the commencement of business operations within the city. Continued exemption from the requirement of posting the performance bond shall be conditioned upon continued compliance with the terms of this article and the payment of all sums as required by the provisions of this section. (Ord. No. 14-01, § 1, 1-27-2014) 
Sec. 3-164. - Audit by city clerk.     The city clerk shall have the right to audit each wholesale dealer licensed to do business in the city. (Ord. No. 14-01, § 1, 1-27-2014) 
Sec. 3-165. - Hours of sale.     Wholesalers shall not engage in the sale of alcoholic beverages except between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m., Monday through Saturday. (Ord. No. 14-01, § 1, 1-27-2014) 
Secs. 3-166—3-170. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - SALES OFF-PREMISES FOR CATERED FUNCTIONS 
Sec. 3-171. - Eligibility for license to sell or distribute by the drink off-premises; application; fee. (a)  Any holder of a city license authorizing the licensee to sell beer, malt beverages, or wine by the drink for consumption on the premises may apply for an off-premises license as an alcoholic beverage caterer to sell or distribute beer, malt beverages, or wine by the drink off premises and in connection with an authorized catered function. (b)  Any holder of a city license authorizing the licensee to sell beer, malt beverages, or wine by the package for consumption off the premises may apply for an off-premises license as an alcoholic beverage caterer to sell or distribute beer, malt beverages, or wine by the drink off premises and in connection with an authorized catered function. (c)  Any holder of a city license authorizing the licensee to sell distilled spirits by the drink for consumption on the premises may apply for an off-premises license as an alcoholic beverage caterer to sell or distribute distilled spirits by the drink off-premises and in connection with an authorized catered function. (d)  Each application for a license as an alcoholic beverage caterer shall be accompanied by a certified check for the full amount of the license fee. (Ord. No. 14-01, § 1, 1-27-2014) 
Sec. 3-172. - Authorized catered functions; event permits. (a)  In order to distribute or sell distilled spirits, malt beverages, or wine at a catered function, the licensed alcoholic beverage caterer shall be required to apply to the city clerk for an event permit. The application shall include the name of the caterer; the date, address, and time of the event; and the alcoholic beverage caterer's license number. (b)  When an alcoholic beverage caterer is domiciled outside the city and currently licensed by the local government authority in which it is domiciled as an alcoholic beverage caterer, a city license shall not be required in order for the alcoholic beverage caterer to distribute or sell distilled spirits, malt beverages, or wine at a catered function inside the city. However, an event fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) shall be charged by the city and local excise taxes shall be levied on the total quantity of alcoholic beverages brought into the city by the caterer. A copy of the license issued by the local government authority where the alcoholic beverage caterer is domiciled shall be attached to the event application. (Ord. No. 14-01, § 1, 1-27-2014) 
Sec. 3-173. - Hours of sale. (a)  Licensed alcoholic beverage caterers may not distribute or sell distilled spirits, beer, malt beverages, or wine for off-premises consumption except between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 11:55 p.m., Monday through Saturday, and the two (2) hours immediately following such time, i.e., until 1:55 a.m. on the subsequent day. (b)  Licensed alcoholic beverage caterers who derive a minimum of fifty (50) percent of their total annual gross food and beverage sales from the sale of prepared meals or food may sell and serve alcoholic beverages for off-premises consumption on Sundays between the hours of 12:30 p.m. and 12:00 midnight. Such alcoholic beverage caterers must complete a form and affidavit furnished by the city clerk and certify the percentages for the most recently ended fiscal year. For new establishments, no affidavit shall be required and such establishments shall be allowed six (6) months to comply with the fifty-percent rule. (c)  Any alcoholic beverage served must be consumed within thirty (30) minutes of the required closing. (Ord. No. 14-01, § 1, 1-27-2014) 
Sec. 3-174. - Regulations as to employees.     A licensed alcoholic beverage caterer shall not employ any person under twenty-one (21) years of age who, in the course of such employment, would dispense, serve, sell, or handle alcoholic beverages. (Ord. No. 14-01, § 1, 1-27-2014) 
Sec. 3-175-180. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XI. - WINE, BEER AND DISTILLED SPIRITS TASTINGS 
Sec. 3-181. - Wine tastings.     Upon receiving an application and payment of a license fee of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) per year, the city manager may issue a permit to hold wine tastings. The permit shall allow the applicant to provide samples of wine to the public for consumption on the premises under the following conditions: (1)  The applicant shall be an establishment licensed to sell wine, in original packages for off-premises consumption. (2)  The applicant shall maintain on the premises and offer for sale at all times a variety of wines from not less than twenty-five (25) manufacturers of wine. (3)  The applicant's establishment shall have minimum interior floor area of eight hundred (800) square feet devoted to the storage, display and sale of wine. (4)  The applicant for a wine tasting must hold a valid current wine license in the state. (5)  No wine tasting may be conducted on the premises of any place of business licensed to sell distilled spirits in original packages for off-premises consumption. (6)  All wines secured for tasting purposes must be obtained through a retail or wholesale wine outlet. (7)  Wine tastings must comply with all laws and regulations otherwise pertaining to the sale and distribution of alcoholic beverages in the state. (8)  All applicants and permit holders must comply with all state statutes and sections of this Code and other city ordinances concerning alcoholic beverages, including but not limited to those dealing with hours of operation, zoning and distance requirements. (Ord. No. 14-01, § 1, 1-27-2014) 
Sec. 3-182. - Beer tastings.     Upon receiving an application and payment of a license fee of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) per year, the city manager may issue a permit to hold beer tastings. The permit shall allow the applicant to provide samples of beer to the public for consumption on the premises under the following conditions: (1)  The applicant shall be an establishment with a license under this chapter, excluding retail establishments where the primary retail function is not the sale of beer. (2)  If the premises is retail, the applicant shall maintain on the premises and offer for sale at all times a variety of beers from not less than twenty-five (25) manufacturers of beer. (3)  If the premises is retail, the applicant's establishment shall have minimum interior floor area of eight hundred (800) square feet devoted to the storage, display and sale of beer. (4)  If the premises is retail, The applicant for a beer tasting must hold a valid current package malt beverage license in the state. (5)  No tasting may be conducted on the premises of any place of business licensed to sell distilled spirits in original packages for off-premises consumption. (6)  If the premises is retail, all beer secured for tasting purposes must be obtained through a retail or wholesale beer outlet. (7)  Beer tastings must comply with all laws and regulations otherwise pertaining to the sale and distribution of alcoholic beverages in the state. (8)  All applicants and permit holders must comply with all state statutes and sections of this Code and other city ordinances concerning alcoholic beverages, including but not limited to those dealing with hours of operation, zoning and distance requirements. (9)  Beer tasting for each customer shall be available one (1) time per day. (10)  Beer is allowed to be sampled but at no time shall a customer be given more than four (4) two (2) ounce samples or more than one (1) eight (8) ounce sample. (11)  No open containers shall be removed from the licensed premises. (12)  Beer tasting only permitted within the interior portions of the premises, unless allowed for a special event. (Ord. No. 14-01, § 1, 1-27-2014) 
Sec. 3-183. - Distilled spirits tastings.     Upon receiving an application and payment of a license fee of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) per year, the city manager may issue a permit to hold distilled spirits tastings. The permit shall allow the applicant to provide samples of distilled spirits to the public for consumption on the premises under the following conditions: (1)  The applicant shall be an establishment licensed to manufacture distilled spirits. (2)  The applicant for a distilled spirit tasting must hold a valid license in the state. (3)  Distilled spirits tastings must comply with all laws and regulations otherwise pertaining to the sale and distribution of alcoholic beverages in the state. (4)  All applicants and permit holders must comply with all state statutes and sections of this Code and other city ordinances concerning alcoholic beverages, including but not limited to those dealing with hours of operation, zoning and distance requirements. (5)  Distilled spirit tasting for each customer shall be available one (1) time per day. (6)  Distilled spirits tasting is allowed to be sampled but at no time shall a customer be given more than one-half (½) an ounce per day. (7)  No open containers shall be removed from the licensed premises. (8)  Distilled spirits tasting only permitted within the interior portions of the premises, unless allowed for a special event. (Ord. No. 14-01, § 1, 1-27-2014) 
Secs. 3-184—3-190. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XII. - HOME-BREW SPECIAL EVENTS[2] Footnotes: --- (2) --- Editor's note— Ord. No. 14-03, § 1, adopted Feb. 24, 2014, repealed the former Art. XII., §§ 3-191—3-193, and enacted a new Art. XII, as set out herein. The former Art. XII pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 14-01, § 1, adopted Jan. 27, 2014. 
Sec. 3-191. - Definition.     A home-brew special event is an event held pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 3-5-4(d) in which malt beverages brewed pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 3-5-4 may be consumed by participants in and judges of the home-brew special event. (Ord. No. 14-03, § 2, 2-24-2014) 
Sec. 3-192. - Permits.     No home-brew special event shall be held in the city except pursuant to a permit issued in advance by the city manager. Upon receiving an application from a qualified applicant and the payment of a license fee of fifty dollars ($50.00), the city manager may issue a home-brew special event permit allowing for up to six (6) home-brew special events per calendar year. No home-brew special event may be held at a facility otherwise licensed for the production or sale of alcoholic beverages. (Ord. No. 14-03, § 2, 2-24-2014) 
Sec. 3-193. - Transportation of home-brew to special event.     Home-brew may be removed from the residence where produced for transportation and delivery by the producer for use at a permitted home-brew event in a quantity not to exceed twenty-five (25) gallons, provided that such malt beverages are securely sealed in one (1) or more containers and clearly labeled with the following information: (1)  The name of the producer; (2)  The address of the residence at which it was produced; (3)  The name and address of the home-brew special event to which it is being transported; and (4)  The permit number under which the home-brew special event is being held. (Ord. No. 14-03, § 2, 2-24-2014) 
Chapter 4 - ANIMALS AND FOWL[1] Footnotes: --- (1) --- Charter reference— Authority to regulate, § 1-102(31). Cross reference— Creation of noise by animals, § 12-4(5). State Law reference— Cruelty to animals, O.C.G.A. §§ 4-8-5, 16-12-4, 27-5-6. 
Sec. 4-1. - Definitions.     The following words, terms, and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:     Abandoned animal means any domesticated animal which has been placed upon public property or within a public building unattended or uncared for, or upon or within the private property of another without the express permission of the owner, custodian or tenant of the private property and is unattended or uncared for. A domesticated animal shall also be considered as abandoned when it has been upon or within the property of the owner or custodian of such animal for a period of time in excess of thirty-six (36) hours unattended and without proper food and water.     Abused animal means any animal which is: (1)  Mistreated, beaten, tormented or teased; (2)  Deprived of water, food or shelter; (3)  Kept under unsanitary conditions; (4)  Abandoned; or (5)  Trained for fighting other animals.     Animal control officer means any person so designated by the county to perform the duties prescribed by this chapter.     Dangerous animal means any animal which constitutes a physical threat to human beings or domestic animals by virtue of a known propensity to endanger life by an unprovoked assault or by biting so as to cause serious bodily harm or an animal trained, owned or harbored for the purpose, primarily or in part, of animal fighting. An animal shall not be deemed dangerous if it: (1)  Bites, attacks or menaces anyone assaulting the owner, a trespasser on the property of the owner, or any person or other animal who has tormented or abused it; (2)  Is otherwise acting in defense of an attack from a person or other animal upon the owner or other person; or (3)  Is protecting or defending its young or other animal.     Dog at large means any dog not under restraint.     Dog under restraint means any dog humanely secured by a leash or other device and held by a person competent to maintain control, or humanely secured by a lead, or enclosed by way of fence or other enclosure, or confined within a vehicle which is parked or in motion.     Domesticated animal means an animal that is accustomed to living in or about the habitation of people.     Guard dog means a dog which has been trained to attack persons independently or upon oral command and any dog which, while not so trained, is reasonably expected to perform as a guardian of its owner and/or the property upon and within which the dog is located.     Owner means any person owning, keeping, harboring or acting as custodian of a domesticated animal.     Public nuisance or public nuisance animal means: (1)  A dog which is found at large in violation of section 4-9 or 4-11; (2)  A cat or dog which is unlicensed (unregistered) in violation of section 4-12; (3)  A dog which is trained, owned or harbored for the purpose, primarily or in part, of dog fighting; (4)  An animal which is dangerous and is not restrained or confined, as provided for in sections 4-10 and 4-11; (5)  An animal which produces, because of quantity, manner or method in which the animals are domesticated or maintained, unsanitary conditions in the city; or (6)  An animal which is inimical to the public health, welfare or safety according to the rules and regulations promulgated by the county board of health. (Ord. No. 852, § 1(4-1), 5-24-93) Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 4-2. - Enforcement of chapter. (a)  Complaint; owner to appear before judge of municipal court. Upon information made known to or complaint lodged with the county animal control center that any owner, possessor or custodian of any animal is in violation of this chapter, the county animal control center shall cause a summons to be issued requiring the owner, possessor or custodian of the animal to appear before the judge of the municipal court on a day and time certain, then and there to stand trial for the violation of this chapter. If a violation of this chapter has not been personally witnessed by employees of the county animal control center, a subpoena shall be issued to the person making the complaint to be and appear on the day and time set for trial to testify. The city will refuse to respond to anonymous complaints. (b)  Impoundment of animal. If the owner, possessor or custodian of any animal is not known and such animal is upon the public streets, alleys, sidewalks, school grounds, or other public places or premises or the property of another without that property owner's permission as provided by this chapter, upon complaint made to or information made known to the animal control center, it shall be the duty of the animal control center to take possession of such animal and impound it in the county animal control shelter. Once impounded, the animal shall be kept for the period of time defined by the county code pertaining to animal control; thereafter, if the animal is not claimed by anyone after a reasonable effort has been made to locate the owner, possessor or custodian of the animal as hereinafter provided, the animal may be disposed of in a humane fashion or in accordance with the provisions of O.C.G.A. tit. 4, ch. 1 (O.C.G.A. § 4-1-1 et seq.). (Ord. No. 852, § 1(4-2), 5-24-93) 
Sec. 4-3. - Fees.     The county shall be entitled to retain all fees for boarding and impoundment collected from owners or custodians of animals impounded and/or boarded. (Ord. No. 852, § 1(4-3), 5-24-93) 
Sec. 4-4. - Breeding pens and barnyard animals prohibited.     It shall be unlawful for any person to keep or maintain within the limits of the city any breeding pens of any type or any barnyard animals. (Ord. No. 852, § 1(4-4), 5-24-93) 
Sec. 4-5. - Public and specific nuisances prohibited. (a)  It shall be unlawful to knowingly keep, own, harbor, or act as custodian or caretaker of a public nuisance animal as defined in section 4-1. (b)  All complaints of specific nuisance animals shall be made in writing to the city manager or his designee. Each such complaint shall: (1)  Identify the animal complained of; (2)  Contain a statement of the facts and circumstances which allegedly constitute conduct prohibited by this chapter; and (3)  Identify the owner, possessor, custodian or caretaker of such animal. Upon receipt of a complete, specific nuisance complaint, the city manager or his designee shall cause a summons to issue requiring the owner, possessor, custodian or caretaker to appear in the municipal court on a date and time certain to show cause as to why appropriate civil remedies and/or punishments as provided in the city Code should not be ordered or imposed. In all such cases, the complainant shall also be required to appear and give evidence in support of the specific nuisance allegations. (Ord. No. 852, § 1(4-5), 5-24-93; Ord. No. 856, § 1, 9-27-93) 
Sec. 4-6. - Dangerous animals.     If a police officer of the city has probable cause to believe that a dangerous animal is being harbored in violation of this chapter, such officer may: (1)  Order the violation immediately corrected and cite the owner or keeper to appear in municipal court for the violation; or (2)  If the violation cannot be immediately corrected and the animal is posing an imminent, serious threat to human beings or other domestic animals, the police officer shall advise the county animal control center and the animal may be seized and impounded by the county animal control center in accordance with provisions of the county code pertaining to animal control. (Ord. No. 852, § 1(4-6), 5-24-93) State Law reference— Dangerous dog control law, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-20 et seq. 
Sec. 4-7. - Notice to owner of impounded animal.     Upon impounding any animal, the county shall cause to be made a prompt and reasonable effort to locate the animal's owner, possessor, or custodian in accordance with the county code pertaining to animal control. (Ord. No. 852, § 1(4-7), 5-24-93) 
Sec. 4-8. - General responsibilities of owners. (a)  It shall be the duty of every owner of any animal, or anyone having possession or custody of any animal, to exercise reasonable care and to take all necessary steps and precautions to protect other people, property and animals from injuries or damages which might result from such animal's behavior, regardless of whether such behavior is motivated by mischievousness, playfulness or ferocity. (b)  If the owner or keeper of any animal is a minor, the parent or guardian of such minor shall be responsible to ensure that there is compliance with the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. No. 852, § 1(4-8), 5-24-93) 
Sec. 4-9. - Running at large.     It shall be unlawful for the owner of a dog, or anyone having custody of any dog, to allow it to run at large unattended on or about the streets and highways of the city, or on the property of another person without permission of the owner of that property or of the person in possession of that property. (Ord. No. 852, § 1(4-9), 5-24-93) 
Sec. 4-10. - Keeping dogs under restraint—On owner's property. (a)  It shall be the duty of every owner of any dog, or anyone having possession or custody of any dog, to ensure that the dog is kept under restraint and that reasonable care and precautions are taken to prevent the dog from leaving, while unattended, the real property limits of its owner, possessor, or custodian, and to ensure that the dog is: (1)  Securely and humanely enclosed within a house, building, fence, pen or other enclosure out of which it cannot climb, dig, jump or otherwise escape on its own volition; such enclosure must be securely locked at any time the animal is left unattended; or (2)  On a leash held by a person competent to maintain control. (b)  Additional requirements for precautions to be taken by owners of dangerous dogs are: (1)  Whenever outside of its enclosure as provided for in subsection (a)(1) of this section, but on the owner's property, a dangerous dog must be attended by the owner and restrained by a secure collar and leash of sufficient strength to prevent escape and which is held by a person competent to maintain control; (2)  No dangerous dog shall be chained, tethered, or otherwise tied to any inanimate object such as a tree, post or building outside of its own enclosure as provided for in subsection (a)(1) of this section; and (3)  In addition to the requirements in subsection (a)(1) of this section, owners of dangerous dogs who maintain their dogs out-of-doors shall fence a portion of their property with a perimeter or area fence. Within this perimeter fence, the dangerous dog must be humanely confined inside a pen or kennel of adequate size. The pen or kennel may not share common fencing with the area or perimeter fence. The kennel or pen must have secure sides and a secure top attached to all sides. The sides must either be buried two (2) feet into the ground, sunken into a concrete pad or securely attached to a wire bottom. The gate to the kennel must be locked. (c)  Failure to keep any dog confined or under restraint as provided for in this section shall be unlawful. (Ord. No. 852, § 1(4-10), 5-24-93) 
Sec. 4-11. - Same—Off owner's property. (a)  It shall be the duty of the owner of any dog or anyone having possession of any dog to keep the dog under restraint and control at all times while the dog is off the real property limits of the owner, possessor, or custodian. (b)  For the purposes of this section, a dog is deemed under control when it is: (1)  Securely confined within a vehicle, parked or in motion; (2)  Properly confined within a secure enclosure with the permission of the owner of the property where the enclosure is located; or (3)  Securely restrained by a leash or other device held by a person competent to maintain control. (c)  Additional requirements for precautions to be taken by owners of dangerous dogs are that, except when being transported in and securely confined within a vehicle, no dangerous dog shall be permitted off the property of its owner, except when it is: (1)  Attended by its owner; (2)  Restrained by secure collar and leash (not to exceed six (6) feet in length), both collar and leash of sufficient strength to prevent escape; and held by a person competent to maintain control; and (3)  Muzzled by any means sufficient to prevent biting other persons or domestic animals. (d)  Failure to keep any dog under restraint or control as provided for in this section shall be unlawful. (Ord. No. 852, § 1(4-11), 5-24-93) 
Sec. 4-12. - Rabies vaccination; rabies tag; registration with county. (a)  All dogs and cats three (3) months of age or older in the city shall be inoculated for the prevention of rabies by a licensed veterinarian. It shall be the duty of any owner, possessor, or custodian of such dogs or cats to procure a current rabies vaccination from a licensed veterinarian. (b)  It shall be the duty of any owner, possessor, or custodian of such dogs or cats to register these animals with the county by providing proof of current rabies vaccination and paying a fee to the county in the amount established by the county. (c)  It shall be the duty of each dog or cat owner, possessor or custodian to provide a collar for such dog or cat to which the rabies inoculation tag shall be attached. The collar, together with the tag, shall be worn by the dog or cat if the animal is required to be inoculated against rabies as provided in this section. (Ord. No. 852, § 1(4-12), 5-24-93) State Law reference— Licensing and regulation required, O.C.G.A. § 31-19-3. 
Sec. 4-13. - Rabies control.     It shall be the duty of the owner, custodian, or person having possession of, or knowledge of, any animal which has bitten any person or animal, or any animal which exhibits any signs of rabies, to notify the county animal control center. (Ord. No. 852, § 1(4-13), 5-24-93) 
Sec. 4-14. - Abandonment or abuse.     It shall be unlawful for anyone to knowingly abandon or abuse any domesticated animal within the city. Any person who knowingly abandons or abuses, or willingly permits such abandonment or abuse, or aids in the abandonment or abuse of any domesticated animal shall be guilty of an offense. (Ord. No. 852, § 1(4-14), 5-24-93) State Law reference— Georgia Animal Protection Act, O.C.G.A. § 4-11-1 et seq.; cruelty to animals, O.C.G.A. § 16-12-4. 
Sec. 4-15. - Training for fighting prohibited.     It shall be prohibited for any person to keep, buy, sell, trade, exchange, give, transport, or deliver any animal: (1)  For the purpose of training the animal, primarily or in part, for animal fighting; (2)  Which has been trained, primarily or in part, for animal fighting; (3)  Which has been or is intended to be engaged in any manner in animal fighting. (Ord. No. 852, § 1(4-15), 5-24-93) 
Sec. 4-16. - Unlawful to allow dogs to defecate or urinate on certain properties; removal required. (a)  It shall be unlawful for the owner of a dog, or anyone having custody of any dog, to allow it to defecate or urinate upon the private property of another. (b)  It shall be unlawful for the owner of a dog, or anyone having custody of any dog, to refuse or fail to immediately remove any feces deposited by such dog upon the private property of another, public sidewalk, public verge, public street, public park, or any other public property in the city. (c)  It shall be unlawful for any owner of a dog or anyone having custody of any dog, to place or deposit any dog excrement on public property or in any unsanitary manner on private property. (Ord. No. 0107, §§ 1—3, 9-24-01) 
Chapter 5 - BUILDINGS; CONSTRUCTION, MAINTENANCE, AND RELATED ACTIVITIES[1] Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Creation of noise in building operation, § 12-4(10); drainage not to be obstructed, § 17-19. State Law reference— Buildings and housing, O.C.G.A. tit. 8. 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
Sec. 5-1. - Remedies for violations or proposed violations of chapter.     In case any building, system, appliance, or equipment is or is proposed to be erected, constructed, reconstructed, altered, converted or maintained, or any building, system, appliance, or equipment is or is proposed to be used in violation of any provision of this chapter, the building official or other duly authorized and empowered city official may, in addition to other remedies, and after due notice to the owner or contractor of the violation, issue a citation for violation of the city Code requiring the presence of the violator in the municipal court; institute injunction or other appropriate action or proceeding to prevent the unlawful erection, construction, reconstruction, alteration, conversion, maintenance, or use so as to correct or abate the violation or to prevent the occupancy of the building. Where a violation of these regulations exists with respect to a building, system, appliance, or equipment, the building official may, in addition to other remedies, require that public utility service, further permits, and/or inspections be withheld therefrom until such time as the building or premises are no longer in violation of these regulations. 
Sec. 5-2. - Penalties for violation of chapter. (a)  Other remedial provisions of this chapter notwithstanding, any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be summoned to the municipal court for each violation and upon conviction shall be punished by a fine not exceeding one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), or by imprisonment for a period not to exceed six (6) months, or both, or by fine, imprisonment, or alternative sentencing as provided by law. (b)  The owner of a building or premises, where anything in violation of these regulations shall be effected, constructed, reconstructed, altered, converted, maintained, used or shall exist, or an architect, engineer, builder, contractor, agent, person, or corporation employed in connection therewith, and who assisted in the commission of such violation, shall be charged with a separate offense. (c)  Where any offense continues from day to day, each day's continuance thereof shall be deemed a separate offense. 
Sec. 5-3. - Certificate of occupancy. (a)  When required. No new residential, commercial, or industrial building or portion thereof shall be occupied or a change made in occupancy or the nature of the use of an existing building or part thereof until after a certificate of occupancy has been issued therefor. (b)  Final certificate of occupancy. A final certificate shall not be issued until all construction is complete and all final building, plumbing, HVAC, electrical, drainage, fire and health inspections have been performed and approved by the city and/or by the county as appropriate.
