Each application for a final certificate of occupancy shall be accompanied by a final site plan and one copy of the as-built plans. (c)  Temporary certificate of occupancy. A temporary certificate of occupancy may be issued for nonresidential buildings or portions thereof for a specified period of time when it has been determined by the building official that no outstanding code violations or deficiencies exist and the building may be safely occupied for the use requested. Requests for a temporary certificate of occupancy shall be made in writing to the building official. Temporary certificates of occupancy are issued for stated purposes only when construction has not been fully completed and all final inspections have not been performed. This certificate shall not be construed otherwise. The final certificate of occupancy shall be issued as specified in subsection (b) of this section. Temporary certificates of occupancy may be revoked at the option of the city for the following reasons: (1)  Violation of any building, plumbing, HVAC, electrical, fire safety, or site development codes or regulations. (2)  Failure to complete any stage of construction and/or site improvements required by the city in a timely manner consistent with good development practices. (3)  Unauthorized occupancy or use of any part of the structure or building other than the space for which a temporary occupancy permit has been granted. (4)  Any other condition that may affect the health, safety and welfare of persons or property. (d)  Fee. The fee for a final certificate of occupancy shall be twenty-five dollars ($25.00). 
Sec. 5-4. - Utility service connections. (a)  Permanent electrical service connection. Permanent electrical service connection and meter shall not be authorized by the county until all required final building, plumbing, HVAC, electrical, drainage, fire and health inspections have been performed and approved by the city and/or by the county as appropriate. (b)  Permanent gas service connection. Permanent gas service connection and meter shall not be authorized until the gas supply house line has been tested and approved and all connected appliances and equipment have been inspected and approved. (c)  Temporary electrical service connection. Temporary electrical service connection and meter may be authorized by the county for a specified period of time when the system and building have been inspected and found to be safe for the use authorized. Such temporary service connection shall be authorized only for the following reasons: (1)  Testing of appliances and equipment. (2)  To provide heat during the winter months to prevent freeze damage to water systems and equipment and including, but not limited to, painting or installing wallpaper. (3)  Temporary occupancy of the building by no more than ten (10) employees for training of employees or stocking of merchandise. Single-tenant occupancy buildings and portions of multitenant occupancy buildings for which temporary electrical service connections have been authorized by the county shall not be allowed access by the general public or used for business activity other than allowed in this section. Application for temporary electrical service connection and meter shall be made on such form as prescribed by the county. 
Sec. 5-5. - Demolition of structures. (a)  Demolition of any structure shall not begin until all of the following conditions are satisfied: (1)  A permit for demolition has been secured from the city. (2)  The county health department has inspected the premises and accepted an appropriate vermin and rat extermination plan. (3)  All utilities are cut off and capped at the street. (b)  Within the time specified in the demolition permit the following shall be completed: (1)  All debris, trash, litter, rubbish, rubble and foundation exposed above the ground level shall be removed from the premises. (2)  Any excavation or other depression must be filled to existing grade with clean dirt containing no more than twenty-five (25) percent stone or masonry and all filled areas must be adequately sloped and drained. 
Secs. 5-6—5-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - BUILDING OFFICIAL 
Sec. 5-21. - Office of building official. (a)  The city manager shall designate one (1) or more qualified persons to perform the duties of the office of building official pursuant to this Code of Ordinances. (b)  Any person designated as a building official by the city manager shall serve at the pleasure of the city manager. (c)  A building official need not be an employee of the city. The city may contract with any qualified person or entity to perform some or all of the duties of the building official. (Code 1973, § 2-719; Ord. No. 13-04, § 1, 12-16-2013) 
Sec. 5-22. - Powers and duties—Building construction generally. (a)  The building official shall receive applications required of such official by this chapter, issue permits and furnish the prescribed certificates. The building official shall examine premises for which permits have been issued and shall make necessary inspections to see that the provisions of law are complied with and that construction is completed safely. The building official shall enforce all provisions of the building codes. The building official shall, when requested by proper authority, or when the public interest so requires, make investigations in connection with matters referred to in the codes adopted in this chapter and render written reports on the same. The building official shall enforce compliance with law, to remove illegal or unsafe conditions, secure the necessary safeguards during construction, require adequate exit facilities in buildings and structures, and issue such notices or orders as may be necessary. (b)  Inspections required under the provisions of the codes adopted herein shall be made by the building official or such official's qualified representative. The building official may accept reports of inspectors of recognized inspection services, after investigation of their qualifications and reliability. No certificate called for by any provision of the codes shall be issued on such reports unless the same are in writing and certified to by a responsible officer of such service. (c)  The building official shall make written reports to the city manager as requested, including statements of permits and certificates issued and orders promulgated. (d)  The building official may request and shall receive so far as may be necessary, in the discharge of his official duties, the assistance and cooperation of other officials of the city. (e)  The building official, in the discharge of his official duties, and upon proper identification, shall have authority to enter any building, structure or premises at any reasonable hour. (Code 1973, §§ 2-721(a), (b), (e), 2-723, 2-724) 
Sec. 5-23. - Same—Public improvements, public recreation, etc.     Subject to the supervision and control of the city manager in all matters, the building official shall manage and have charge of the construction, improvement, repair and maintenance of streets, sidewalks, alleys, lanes, bridges, viaducts and other public highways; of all municipally owned sewers, drains, ditches, culverts, canals, streams, and watercourses; of all public buildings; of boulevards, squares, and other public places and grounds belonging to the city dedicated to public use, including recreational facilities and parks and playgrounds. The building official shall have charge of the enforcement of all obligations of privately owned or operated public utilities enforceable by the city. The building official shall have charge of the making and preservation of all surveys, maps, plans, drawings. (Code 1973, §§ 2-367, 2-374) 
Sec. 5-24. - Records and plans. (a)  Maintenance and retention. The building official shall keep and maintain comprehensive records of applications, permits issued, inspections made, certificates of occupancy issued, reports rendered, and of notices and orders issued. He shall retain on file copies of required plans and documents relating to buildings, equipment, appliances or systems for which a permit has been issued so long as any part of the building or structure to which they relate may be in existence. (b)  Public inspection. All such records and plans shall be open to public inspection during the building official's normal office hours but shall not be removed from their place of keeping. 
Sec. 5-25. - Appeals from decision of building official. (a)  Basis for appeal. When the building official shall reject or refuse to approve the mode or manner of work proposed or performed, or when it is claimed that the provisions of the codes adopted in section 5-41 do not apply, or that an equally good or desirable form, method or process can be employed in any specific case, or when it is claimed that the true intent and meaning of the codes adopted in section 5-41 or any of the regulations thereunder have been misconstrued or wrongly interpreted, the permittee or contractor may appeal from the decision of the building official to the city's board of appeals. (b)  Time limitation for appeals; exception. Appeals shall be in writing and shall be filed with the city clerk within ten (10) days after the decision is rendered by the building official. In case a building, system, appliance or equipment is unsafe or dangerous in the opinion of the building official, he may, in his order or decision, limit the time of such appeal to a shorter period. 
Sec. 5-26. - Liability. (a)  An employee of the city designated as building official and acting in such capacity in good faith and without malice is hereby relieved of all personal liability for his official acts. (b)  Any suit brought against such an employee acting in good faith for any official act or omission in the performance of his duty as building official shall be defended by the city. (Code 1973, § 2-722; Ord. No. 13-04, § 2, 12-16-2013) 
Sec. 5-27. - Contracting with county if position not occupied. (a)  If the position of building official is not occupied or if the governing body concludes that it would be more efficient, the city may elect to contract with the county for the provision of plans review, issuance of building, plumbing, HVAC, and electrical permits, and inspections of same within the city pursuant to the following: (1)  A resolution shall be adopted by the governing body. (2)  The city shall review all plans for compliance with the city's zoning requirements, development standards, and other ordinances. (3)  An application form for any planned construction involving new structures or additions to existing structures shall be completed by the city and when signed by an authorized city official shall signify to the county that the plans are in compliance with the city's zoning requirements, development standards, and other ordinances. (4)  An application/authorization fee shall be charged by the city in an amount as determined by the city manager. (5)  Only those state codes and amendments adopted by the county shall be enforced in the city by the county. (6)  The fees charged for such permits issued by the county shall be in accordance with those adopted by the county and such fees shall be retained by the county. (7)  Code violations found and not corrected during the normal inspections process shall be referred to and prosecuted by the city. County inspection staff may appear as expert witnesses for the city. (8)  The county shall issue a certification of completion when all final inspections have been performed and approved. (9)  A certificate of occupancy shall be issued by the city upon receipt of a certification of completion and verification that the completed work is in compliance with the city's zoning requirements, development standards, and other ordinances. (b)  An authorization/building permit shall be required in situations where a permit is not required by the county if a review of plans for compliance with the city's zoning requirements, development standards, and other ordinances is necessary (e.g., fencing). The fee for such authorization/building permit shall be in accordance with the building permit fee specified in article III. 
Secs. 5-28—5-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - STANDARD/TECHNICAL CODES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
Sec. 5-41. - Adoption of state minimum standard codes. (a)  The editions of the following state minimum standard codes adopted by the state department of community affairs are hereby adopted by reference as if set forth in full herein: (1)  International Building Code (ICC); (2)  National Electrical Code (NFPA); (3)  International Fuel Gas Code (ICC); (4)  International Mechanical Code (ICC); (5)  International Plumbing Code (ICC); (6)  International Residential Code for One and Two-Family Dwellings (ICC); (7)  International Energy Conservation Code (ICC); (8)  International Fire Code (ICC); (9)  International Existing Building Code (ICC); (10)  International Property Maintenance Code (ICC). (b)  Any future amendments and revisions, including adoptions of new additions, to the state minimum standard codes by the state shall so amend the pertinent provisions of this chapter without any action by the governing body of the city being required. (c)  Each of the codes adopted in this section, hereinafter referred to as "these codes" or "this code," shall be maintained in the office of the building official or the employee charged with the enforcement of these codes as part of the public record and be accessible to members of the public. (d)  The provisions, requirements, powers, remedies, and other matters enumerated in such codes are cumulative of the provisions, requirements, powers, remedies and other matters contained elsewhere in this chapter and in other existing ordinances of the city. If in conflict, the express subsequent provisions of this chapter shall prevail over those contained in the various standard codes. (Code 1973, §§ 2-716, 2-718, 2-7216, 2-7283; Ord. No. 824, §§ 1, 2, 9-25-89; Ord. No. 13-04, § 3, 12-16-2013) Cross reference— Fire prevention code adopted, § 10-1. State Law reference— Required minimum standards, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-20 et seq. 
Sec. 5-42. - Provisions of codes remedial. (a)  Generally. These codes are hereby declared to be remedial and shall be construed to secure and provide minimum standards and regulations to safeguard life, limb, health, property and general welfare of the citizens of the city. (b)  Quality control. Quality control of materials and workmanship is not within the purview of these codes except as it relates to the purpose stated in this chapter. (c)  Permitting and inspections. The permitting or inspections of any building or plans, under the requirements of these codes, shall not be construed in any court as a warranty of the physical condition of such building or the adequacy of such plan. The city or any employee thereof shall not be liable in tort for damages for any defect or hazardous or illegal condition or inadequacy in such building or plan, or for any failure of any component of such building, which may occur subsequent to such inspections or permitting. 
Sec. 5-43. - Scope. (a)  Applicability. The provisions of these codes shall apply to the construction of any building or swimming pool, erection of any fence, installation of any plumbing, HVAC (mechanical and gas) or electrical systems, appliances or equipment. (b)  Federal and state authority. The provisions of these codes shall not be held to deprive any federal or state agency, or any applicable governing body having jurisdiction, of any power or authority which it had on the effective date of the adoption of these codes or of any remedy then existing for the enforcement of its orders, nor shall it deprive any individual or corporation of its legal rights as provided by law. 
Sec. 5-44. - All work to conform. (a)  No building, system, appliance, or equipment, as specified in this article, shall be constructed, erected, installed, altered or repaired except in conformity with the provisions of these codes. (b)  The provisions of these codes shall not apply to the installation, alteration or repair of services up to and including the meters where such work is performed by or is an integral part of the system owned or operated by a public utility service corporation, water department, gas company, railroad company, pipeline company, or other public utility in the exercise of its normal functions or in rendering its duly authorized service as such. 
Sec. 5-45. - Unsafe systems, appliances or equipment. (a)  Use and maintenance. It shall be unlawful to maintain, use, repair, or alter any system, appliance, or equipment that has been or will be installed, after the adoption of these codes that is in violation or will violate the provisions as specified in this chapter. No system, appliance, or equipment, as hereinafter specified in this chapter, shall be used unless it is in a safe condition. (b)  Unsafe building, systems, appliances, or equipment. Systems, appliances, or equipment covered by this Code that may be or shall be found upon inspection to have become dangerous or unsafe shall, unless made safe and so certified by the building official, be removed or the use of same discontinued. The term "dangerous or unsafe systems, appliances or equipment" shall include systems, appliances or equipment structurally unsafe, unstable or unsanitary; constituting a fire hazard; unsuitable or improper for the use to which they are put; constituting a hazard to health or safety because of inadequate maintenance, dilapidation or obsolescence; or otherwise dangerous to life or property. (c)  Notice of unsafe systems, appliances or equipment. Upon receipt of information that systems, appliances or equipment covered by this code are unsafe, the building official shall make or cause to be made an inspection and, if it is found that an unsafe condition exists, he shall serve or cause to be served on the owner, or someone of the owner, executors, administrator, agents, lessees or other persons who may have a vested or contingent interest in the same, a written notice containing a description of the particulars in which the systems, appliances, or equipment are unsafe, and an order requiring the same to be made safe, as may be deemed necessary. If the owner, executor, administrator, agent, lessee, or other person cannot be found after diligent search, then such notice and order shall be sent by certified mail to the last known address of such person; and a copy of such notice shall be posted in a conspicuous place on the premises to which it relates. Such mailing and posting shall be deemed adequate notice. (d)  Disregard of notice. If the person served with a notice or order fails to remove, repair, or replace the unsafe condition of the system, appliance, or equipment or fails to discontinue the use of same, within a reasonable time as set by the building official, the building official shall institute appropriate legal action to compel compliance. In addition, he is authorized to withhold issuance of any additional permits to any contractor who has not complied with any notice or order to remove or repair any defective work installed under the provisions of these codes. 
Secs. 5-46—5-60. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - FLOW RATE RESTRICTIONS ON PLUMBING FIXTURES 
Sec. 5-61. - Definitions.     The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:     Commercial building, as referred to in this division, means any type of building other than residential.     Plumbing fixtures means any toilet, urinal, showerhead, bathroom, lavatory and kitchen faucet and replacement aerators.     Residential building means any building or unit of a building intended for occupancy as a dwelling but shall not include a hotel or motel.     Toilet means any fixture consisting of a water-flushed bowl with a seat used for the disposal of human waste.     Urinal means any fixture consisting of a water-flushed bowl used for the disposal of human waste. Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 5-62. - Standards.     No plumbing fixture shall be installed which does not meet the standards listed in this section or the Standard Plumbing Code with state amendments, whichever is stricter. This includes all plumbing fixtures installed in newly constructed buildings or when replacing plumbing fixtures during remodeling or renovation of existing buildings, except as noted in the following exceptions: (1)  All plumbing fixtures installed as referred to above shall not exceed the following maximum water use rates: a. Toilets ..... 1.6 gallons per flush b. Urinals ..... 1.0 gallons per flush c. Showerheads ..... 2.5 gallons per minute, at 60 psi gauge pressure d. Kitchen faucets ..... 2.5 gallons per minute e. Bathroom and lavatory faucets ..... 2.0 gallons per minute  (2)  The flow restriction device in a showerhead must be a permanent and integral part of the showerhead and must not be removable to allow flow rates in excess of that stated in subsection (1) of this section. (3)  Lavatory faucets located in restrooms intended for use by the general public shall be of the metering or self-closing type, in addition to the flow requirement listed in subsection (1) of this section. (4)  The flow rates for all showerheads, kitchen, bathroom and lavatory faucets shall be determined in accordance with ANSI/ASME A112.18.1M-1989 Plumbing Fixture Fittings, as amended; except that maximum flow rates may not exceed those given in subsection (1) of this section. (5)  All toilets and urinals shall be certified to meet the hydraulic performance standards for "low consumption" water closets specified in ANSI/ASME A112.19.2-1990 Vitreous China Plumbing Fixtures, as amended, and ANSI/ASME A112.19.6-1990 Hydraulic Requirements for Water Closets and Urinals, as amended. 
Sec. 5-63. - Product certification.     The manufacturer shall certify compliance with the standards listed in section 5-62 by labeling the fixture and packaging as described in this section and providing upon request appropriate certification by an independent national testing organization acceptable to the building official. All toilets, urinals, showerheads, or faucets shall be clearly labeled to indicate the maximum flow rate or water usage of the fixture at the specified test pressure. Toilets and urinals shall additionally be labeled ASME A112.19.2M, as prescribed in that standard. The label shall be affixed to the fixture and remain there until the proper building and/or plumbing inspections have been conducted. Also, the packaging must be clearly marked to identify water use rates when offered for retail. 
Sec. 5-64. - Exceptions. (a)  The following fixture uses or applications shall be exempt from the standards established in section 5-62: (1)  Showers and faucets installed for safety purposes, such as emergency eye wash stations, etc. (2)  Plumbing fixtures specifically designed for the physically handicapped. (3)  Fixtures specifically designed to withstand unusual abuse or for installation in a correctional institution which may require more water for proper operation. (4)  Instances of building renovation where significant plumbing modifications would be required to accommodate the lower flows or for specialized purposes which cannot be accommodated by existing technology. (b)  Permission for the exceptions listed in subsection (a) of this section must be obtained from the building official. 
Sec. 5-65. - Compliance and enforcement.     In addition to the penalty provided in section 5-66, the city may take any of the following actions to compel compliance and may maintain an action or proceeding in any court of competent jurisdiction to compel compliance with or restrain any violation of this section: (1)  Compliance with the requirements for installation and labeling at the time of installation as provided in sections 5-62 and 5-63 shall be determined by the building official in cases of new or replacement plumbing fixture installations and compliance shall be a condition for receipt of any occupancy permit. (2)  The county water department may deny any service connection to an establishment which does not comply with section 5-62. (3)  Compliance with section 5-63 regarding the labeling of plumbing fixtures offered for retail sale shall be determined by the building official. The building official shall have access to all establishments located in the city which offer for sale or sell these plumbing fixtures for purposes of determining compliance. 
Sec. 5-66. - Penalty for violation of division.     Any person who violates any provision of this division shall be subject to a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each violation. Each violation shall constitute a separate offense and each day that such violation continues shall constitute a separate offense. In addition, any building or plumbing contractor, developer, etc., who violates the provisions of this division shall be subject to suspension of his license for a period of up to ninety (90) days. 
Secs. 5-67—5-70. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - PERMITS 
Sec. 5-71. - Required. (a)  It shall be unlawful to construct, alter or repair any building, structure, or fence or to construct, erect, install, alter or repair, or to commence the construction, erection, installation or alteration of any system, appliance, or equipment provided for in these codes without first filing an application with the city and obtaining a permit in conformity with this section. (b)  Permits shall be obtained at least four (4) hours before beginning work on new jobs or alterations. Permits for emergency work shall be obtained within twenty-four (24) hours after beginning work. 
Sec. 5-72. - Building permit.     No new construction, alterations or repairs shall be begun, the cost of which exceeds three hundred dollars ($300.00), or for which structural alterations or fencing are proposed regardless of cost, without first obtaining a building permit from the city. 
Sec. 5-73. - Application. (a)  Forms. (1)  An application for a permit shall be submitted on such form as provided by the city. (2)  It shall be the responsibility of the property owner to see that a permit is obtained by any contractor before any work is started. (3)  The application shall contain the full names and addresses of the applicant/contractors and of the owners. (4)  The application shall contain all information that may be required by the city for an intelligent understanding of the work to be performed. (b)  Plans and specifications to be submitted. A site plan, construction plans or mechanical and/or plumbing plans, and specifications shall accompany each application for permit. Plans shall be drawn to scale and of such clarity and detail to fully show the nature and character of the work. Such plans and specifications shall contain the name and address and professional seal of the architect, engineer and/or designer and information in the form of notes or otherwise, as to the quality of materials, where quality is essential to conformity with these codes. Such information shall be specific, and these codes shall not be cited as a whole or in part, nor shall the term "legal" or its equivalent be used as a substitute for specific information. No major change shall be made in the work done or the installation which shall vary from the plans unless the plans are first resubmitted to the building official for approval. A copy of the approved plans for the work under construction or installation shall be on the job site and available to the building official during inspections or conferences at the site. The building official may require details, computations, stress diagrams, and other data necessary to describe the construction and basis of calculations and they shall bear the signature of the person responsible for the design. (c)  Approval or rejection. Applications for permits shall be examined within a reasonable time after filing. If after examination, which shall include the review of any required plans and specifications, no objection is found to the application and it appears that the proposed work will be in compliance with these codes and ordinances applicable thereto, the application shall be approved and a permit issued. If examination and review reveals that the proposed work does not comply with these codes and ordinances, such application shall be rejected. 
Sec. 5-74. - Issuance not construed to be approval for any violation. (a)  The issuance or granting of a permit or approval of plans and specifications shall not be construed to be a permit or approval for any violation of any of the provisions of these codes. No permit presuming to give authority to violate or cancel the provisions of these codes shall be valid, except insofar as the work or use which it authorizes is lawful. (b)  The issuance of a permit based on applications, plans or specifications shall not prevent the city from thereafter requiring the correction of errors in such applications, plans, or specifications or from preventing the work from being carried on thereunder when in violation of these codes or other ordinances of the city. 
Sec. 5-75. - Conditions; registration of contractors. (a)  All work performed under a permit issued shall conform to the approved application and plans and all codes or ordinances governing the work. All work shall be performed by an individual (contractor, firm or corporation) licensed by the state to perform such work except when performed by an individual constructing, installing, erecting, altering or repairing mechanical, plumbing, or electrical services in a single-family dwelling owned and occupied by him. Permits for such work in owner-occupied single-family dwellings shall be issued only upon demonstration by the owner that he is competent to perform such work. (b)  All mechanical (heating, ventilation, refrigeration and air conditioning), plumbing, and electrical contractors shall hold a valid state class I or class II certificate of competency. Prior to obtaining a permit for work to be performed, a contractor shall present his valid certificate of competency and, if located in the city, shall also register with the city and pay an occupational tax in accordance with applicable provisions of chapter 14 of this Code. 
Sec. 5-76. - Expiration.     The time period under which work authorized by a building permit must be completed shall be twelve (12) months from the date of issuance. Upon application by the permittee prior to expiration of the permit, the city manager shall have the authority to extend such period for an additional one hundred eighty (180) days only when construction has begun in good faith within the initial twelve (12) month period and when the work is incomplete due to the scope of the project or factors beyond the applicant's control, including, but not limited to, weather and illness. Any building permit not so extended shall be absolutely void after twelve (12) months from the date of issuance, and fees paid shall be forfeited. If work described in the building permit has not commenced within six (6) months from the date of issuance, the permit shall expire. Once a permit expires, the application, plans and specifications shall be reviewed and a new permit required before work is started or resumed. (Ord. No. 16-07, § 1, 12-12-16) 
Sec. 5-77. - Revocation.     The building official may revoke a permit or approval, issued under the provisions of this article, where it is shown that there has been any false statement or misrepresentation as to material facts in the application or plans and specifications on which the permit or approval was based or if the building covered by the permit is in violation of any of these codes or ordinances of the city. 
Sec. 5-78. - Contractor change, reissuance of permit.     No permit shall be reissued on any job for which a permit exists except after notification in writing from the owner of the change in contractors and that the new contractor is authorized by the owner to re-permit. Reissuance of a permit shall make the new contractor responsible for the complete job or system and all deficiencies, if any, as built, erected or installed by the original contractor. The contractor who permits the job must be licensed by the state and shall repay the fee required for the entire job. The original contractor, upon request, may be eligible for a refund of a portion of the original permit fee. If a refund is made, the city will also retain a service fee. 
Sec. 5-79. - Building permit and inspection fees. (a)  Fees for permits and inspections required by this chapter shall be determined by resolution of the board of mayor and commissioners. (b)  The current fee amount(s)/formula(s) established by the city pursuant to subsection (a) shall be published on the city's website and in writing at city hall. (Ord. No. 17-03, § 1, 5-17-17) Editor's note— Ord. No. 17-03, § 1, adopted May 17, 2017, repealed former § 5-79, and enacted a new § 5-79 as set out herein. Former § 5-79 pertained to permit fees and derived from the Code of 1973. 
Secs. 5-80—5-94. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - INSPECTIONS 
Sec. 5-95. - Inspections required.     All new construction of buildings, including additions, and all alterations and repairs of buildings, including additions, and all construction, installation, erection, alteration, or repairs of systems, appliances, or equipment for which a permit has been issued shall be inspected by the building official to ensure compliance with these codes and the permit issued. (Ord. No. 17-03, § 2, 5-17-17) 
Sec. 5-96. - Notice to be given when work is ready for inspection.     Building, plumbing, and HVAC contractors shall give notice to the building official when work is completed and ready for inspection. It shall be the duty of the contractor to make sure that the work will stand the test prescribed before an inspection is requested. If the building official finds that the work will not pass the test, the contractor shall be required to make necessary corrections and the work shall then be resubmitted for inspection. All equipment, material, power, and labor necessary for the inspection and test shall be furnished by the contractor. (See section 5-100 pertaining to reinspection fees.) 
Sec. 5-97. - Right of entry.     Inspections required under the provisions of these codes shall be made by the building official. Upon presentation of proper credentials, he may enter at 8:00 a.m. to 8:00 p.m. any building, structure or premises in the city to perform any duty imposed upon him by these codes. 
Sec. 5-98. - Enforcement of standard/technical codes provisions.     The building official is hereby authorized and directed to enforce all the provisions of these codes, and is hereby invested with all police power necessary for the purposes of issuing copies of charges and prosecution of any persons, firms, or corporations as may be charged with any violation of these codes. 
Sec. 5-99. - Stop work orders.     Whenever, in the opinion of the building official, defective or illegal work in violation of any provisions of these codes exists or is being carried on, the building official shall order, in writing, all further work to be stopped and may require suspension of all other work until the condition in violation has been corrected. 
Sec. 5-100. - Reinspection fees. (a)  The city manager may impose a reasonable reinspection fee of up to two hundred dollars ($200.00) per reinspection when the city manager, in his discretion, determines that a permittee has conducted the permitted work in a manner that has caused unnecessary work for the building official. (b)  Circumstances that would justify a reinspection fee to be imposed by the city manager include, but are not limited to: (1)  The reinspection is required due to a failure to correct a previously noted standard/technical code violation on a prior inspection. (2)  The job is not ready for inspection when an inspection is requested and performed. (3)  The building or structure is not accessible and inspection cannot be performed. (4)  Work to be inspected has been covered and proper inspection cannot be performed. (5)  A reinspection has to be performed due to a prior issuance of a stop work order. (Ord. No. 17-03, § 3, 5-17-17) 
Sec. 5-101. - Conflict of interest.     No official or employee of the city making inspection of properties for the purpose of determining the necessity for repairs or corrections shall have any financial interest, directly or indirectly, in any repairs or corrections which may be required by this article. 
Secs. 5-102—5-115. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - PROPERTY MAINTENANCE[2] Footnotes: --- (2) --- Editor's note— Ord. No. 12-08, §§ 1, 2(Att.), adopted Oct. 22, 2012, repealed the former Art. IV, §§ 5-116—5-127, and enacted a new Art. IV as set out herein. The former Art. IV pertained to similar subject matter and derived from original codification. 
Sec. 5-116. - Purpose of article.     This article is enacted for the purpose of establishing minimum standards governing the, condition and maintenance of property, dwellings, buildings, and structures in order to make dwellings, buildings, structures, and surrounding premises safe, sanitary, and fit for human use and habitation. Further, this article will promote and protect the public health and safety through the control of weeds and grass which constitute a fire or health hazard, fixing certain responsibilities and duties of owners, operators, and occupants of dwellings and authorizing the inspection of dwellings and structures. (Ord. No. 12-08, § 2(Att.), 10-22-2012) 
Sec. 5-117. - Reserved. 
Sec. 5-118. - Scope and application. (a)  Every lot, building, dwelling, and structure in the city, whether occupied or vacant, shall conform to the requirements of this article, irrespective of when such building may have been constructed, altered or repaired. Where applicable, this article also governs the condition of unimproved property. (b)  When a unit is vacant, the full application of this article may be held in abeyance for an indefinite period, provided the exterior complies with this article, the interior has been cleaned of trash, rubbish and debris, and the unit has been secured in a manner approved by the city and is maintained in a closed and inaccessible manner until it is fully repaired. (c)  The provisions of this article shall apply to any building, equipment, appliance, or system installed, altered, repaired, maintained or used in the city except as may be otherwise specifically provided for by statute or by ordinance. (d)  Where repairs, alterations, construction, maintenance, and work required to meet the provisions of this article are regulated and/or required to be permitted by other ordinances, such repairs, alterations, construction, maintenance, and work shall be done only in accordance with those ordinances. (Ord. No. 12-08, § 2(Att.), 10-22-2012) 
Sec. 5-119. - Enforcement.     The city's codes enforcement officer and city manager shall enforce the provisions of this article. They shall be authorized to exercise such powers as may be necessary or convenient to carry out and effectuate the purpose and provisions of this article, including: (1)  Investigating the condition of all properties in the city in order to determine which lots, dwellings, buildings, or structures therein are in violation of this article. (2)  Entering upon premises for the purpose of making examinations; provided, however, that such entries shall be made in such manner as to cause the least possible inconvenience to the persons in possession. (3)  Exercising the police power necessary for issuing citations and for prosecuting persons charged with violating provisions of this article. (Ord. No. 12-08, § 2(Att.), 10-22-2012) 
Sec. 5-120. - Unsafe, unsanitary, etc., structures prohibited. (a)  Owning or maintaining any dwelling, building, or structure which is not in compliance with applicable codes due to dilapidation or defect increasing the hazards of fire, accident, or other calamity shall be a violation of this article. (b)  Owning or maintaining any dwelling, building or structure that lacks adequate ventilation, light, or sanitary facilities shall be a violation of this article. (c)  Owning or maintaining any condition or use of real estate which renders adjacent real estate unsafe or inimical to safe human habitation shall be a violation of this article. (Ord. No. 12-08, § 2(Att.), 10-22-2012) 
Sec. 5-121. - Windows to be kept in good repair.     It shall be a violation of this article for any owner or occupant of any building within the city to allow any window, window-pane, or portion of any window to remain cracked, missing or broken for thirty (30) consecutive days. (Ord. No. 12-08, § 2(Att.), 10-22-2012) 
Sec. 5-122. - Reserved. 
Sec. 5-123. - Compliance prerequisite to utility services for substandard structure.     Electrical utility service shall not be reconnected to any vacant building which is unfit for human habitation, and has been without electrical utility service, until such building has been brought into compliance with all applicable codes. (Ord. No. 12-08, § 2(Att.), 10-22-2012) 
Sec. 5-124. - Owner's right of entry.     Every occupant of a building, dwelling or dwelling unit shall give the owner thereof, or the owner's agents or employees, access to any part of such building, dwelling or dwelling unit or its premises, at all reasonable times, for the purpose of maintenance, improving or making such repairs or alterations as are necessary to effect compliance with the provisions of this article or with any lawful rule or regulation adopted pursuant to the provisions of this article. (Ord. No. 12-08, § 2(Att.), 10-22-2012) 
Sec. 5-125. - Inspection warrant for occupied premises. (a)  The city manager, in addition to other procedures provided, may obtain an inspection warrant under the conditions specified in this section in order to inspect occupied buildings and premises. The warrant shall authorize the city manager, building official, codes enforcement officer, or agents thereof to conduct a search or inspection of property, either with or without the consent of the person whose property is to be searched or inspected, under the conditions set out in this section. (b)  Inspection warrants may be issued by the municipal court when the issuing judge is satisfied that all of the following conditions are met: (1)  The person seeking the warrant must establish under oath or affirmation that the property to be inspected is to be inspected as a part of a legally authorized program of inspection which includes that property or there is probable cause for believing there is a condition, object, activity, or circumstance which legally justifies such an inspection of that property. (2)  The issuing judge determines that the issuance of the warrant is authorized by this section. (c)  The inspection warrant shall not be valid unless it meets all of the following requirements: (1)  The warrant is attached to the affidavit required to be made in order to obtain the warrant. (2)  The warrant describes, either directly or by reference to the affidavit, the property upon which the inspection is to occur and is sufficiently accurate that the executor of the warrant and the owner or possessor of the property can reasonably determine from it the property for which the warrant authorizes an inspection. (3)  The warrant indicates the conditions, objects, activities, or circumstances which the inspection is intended to check or reveal. (4)  The warrant refers, in general terms, to the ordinance provisions sought to be enforced. (Ord. No. 12-08, § 2(Att.), 10-22-2012) 
Sec. 5-126. - Weeds, junk, etc., prohibited; notice of violations. (a)  It shall be unlawful for the owner, operator, or occupant of any property within the city to maintain such property with vegetation, dead limbs, branches from trees, underbrush, garbage, trash, stagnant water, or other things accumulated thereon that will constitute an unsightly, unsanitary or dangerous condition, health menace or fire hazard. (b)  It shall be unlawful for the owner, operator or occupant of any property within the city to utilize the premises of such property for the open storage of any abandoned or junked motor vehicle, ice box, refrigerator, stove, other appliance, glass, building material, building rubbish, or similar vehicles, implements, or items that will constitute an unsightly, unsanitary or dangerous condition, health menace or fire hazard. For the purposes of this section, an abandoned or junked motor vehicle is defined as an automobile, truck or other vehicle that is wrecked or in a state of disrepair and incapable of being moved under its own power, or any vehicle that does not bear a current license tag. (c)  Where parking in open areas is used jointly for the benefit of two (2) or more owners or tenants, the responsibility for maintaining these parking areas free of garbage, trash, and other materials prohibited in this section shall be the joint and severable responsibility of the owners and tenants of these premises. (d)  A written warning notice shall be issued to the owner or occupant of any property maintaining such property in violation of the provisions of this section. The warning notice shall state what items constitute the unsightly, unsanitary or dangerous condition, health menace or fire hazard that must be cleared or removed from the premises. If the owner or occupant of any such property shall fail to clean the premises or remove such items within the time specified in the warning notice, such failure on the part of the owner or occupant of the property shall constitute a violation of this section. Warning notices shall be: (1)  Delivered to the owner or occupant personally or to any other person of suitable age and discretion regularly residing within the household of the occupant or owner; or (2)  Sent by regular United States mail, with sufficient postage prepaid to assure delivery, and addressed to the owner or occupant at his last known address. (e)  Any violation as defined in this section shall be punishable as other ordinance violations. A citation may be issued by any city law enforcement officer or other duly authorized and empowered city official, and service of such citation upon an owner or occupant shall be deemed sufficient if it is: (1)  Delivered to the owner or occupant personally or to any other person of suitable age and discretion regularly residing within the household of the occupant or owner; or (2)  Sent by regular and certified United States mail, return receipt requested, with sufficient postage prepaid to assure delivery, and addressed to the owner or occupant at his last known address. A failure or refusal of such addressee to accept delivery shall constitute valid service under this section. (f)  Citations issued pursuant to the provisions of this section may be so written as to reflect separate and additional violations for each and every succeeding day or portion thereof during which the unlawful conditions continue unabated. (g)  In addition to other remedies, the codes enforcement officer may make written report of his findings to the city manager with recommendation that the city have the premises cleaned and have removed therefrom such items as described in this section that constitute an unsightly, unsanitary or dangerous condition, health menace or fire hazard. When such report with recommendation has been filed: (1)  A copy of the written report aforesaid and a written notice of the time and place fixed for hearing the matter shall be served upon the owner or occupant of such property at least ten (10) but no more than thirty (30) days prior to the date fixed for the hearing, such service to be made by the codes enforcement officer or other designated officer of the city in the manner specified in subsection (e) of this section. The hearing may be continued upon request of either party for reasonable cause. (2)  The city manager shall hear the matter, including the response of such owner or occupant and witnesses introduced, and make his finding. (3)  The city manager shall have full power and authority to order that the offending premises be cleaned and to authorize entry upon such premises for such purpose and to have such premises cleaned and to have removed therefrom vegetation, dead limbs and branches from trees, underbrush, garbage, trash, stagnant water, or other things thereon that constitute an unsightly, unsanitary or dangerous condition, health menace or fire hazard, and to assess the property for cost of the cleaning and removal, and the assessment shall constitute a lien on the property until paid. An execution in favor of the city in the amount of such assessment shall be issued by the city clerk and be collected in accordance with the applicable provisions of law. (Ord. No. 12-08, § 2(Att.), 10-22-2012) State Law reference— Repair, closing and demolition of dwellings unfit for human habitation, O.C.G.A. § 36-61-11; nuisance abatement, O.C.G.A. § 41-2-1 et seq. 
Secs. 5-127—5-140. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - BUILDING NUMBERING 
Sec. 5-141. - Designation of street numbers.     Street numbers for dwelling units and places of business on all public streets and street numbers or building numbers for dwelling units and places of business within developments located on private streets shall be assigned by the building official in consultation with the city clerk and the county planning department. 
Sec. 5-142. - Assigning numbers; size; when to be erected.     Street numbers will be assigned for all buildings and structures. Numbers must be erected and displayed in front of the project on a board with permanent numbers not smaller than two (2) inches. Numbers must be in place at the beginning of the job before the footing inspection is made and be continuously displayed thereafter until the job is completed and all final inspections have been made. 
Sec. 5-143. - Posting. (a)  Each one-, two-, and three-family residential unit shall have posted and maintained in a conspicuous place on the property, visible from the street providing general public access, the address of such residential unit in figures at least three (3) inches high on a contrasting background. (b)  All other residential buildings shall have posted and maintained in a conspicuous place on the building, visible from the parking lot or street providing general public access, the address or number of the building in figures at least six (6) inches high on a contrasting background and each individual unit within the building shall be marked on or about its main entrance with the individual unit number and/or address in figures at least three (3) inches high on a contrasting background. In addition to the above, where such residential buildings have more than one (1) exterior entrance, each such entrance shall be marked in figures at least three (3) inches high on contrasting background with the numbers and/or address of each and every individual apartment/unit to which access is provided through that common entrance. (c)  Each place of business shall have posted and maintained in a conspicuous place on the property, visible from the street providing general public access, the address of the place of business in figures at least three (3) inches high on a contrasting background. 
Secs. 5-144—5-160. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - EXISTING BUILDINGS[3] Footnotes: --- (3) --- Cross reference— Fire prevention code; fire safety rules; enforcement, § 10-1. 
Sec. 5-161. - Definitions.     As used in this article, the following terms shall have the respective meanings ascribed to them:     Enforcement authority means the safety fire commissioner, the state fire marshal, the city building official, local fire marshals, or any other state or local official responsible for the implementation, application, or enforcement of any state law or local ordinance relating to building construction, or any state or local rule or regulation relating to building construction, or any building, mechanical, electrical, plumbing, life safety or fire prevention codes, or other construction standards that apply or are intended to apply to existing buildings. The term "enforcement authority" also means any local official designated by the governing authority as the enforcement authority for the purposes of this article.     Existing building or structure means any completed building or structure which has been placed in service for a minimum of five (5) years.     Safety fire commissioner or commissioner means the office created in O.C.G.A. § 25-2-2. (Ord. No. 815, § 2, 6-27-88) Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 5-162. - Authority.     This article is enacted pursuant to the Uniform Act for the Application of Building and Fire Related Codes to Existing Buildings, Ga. Laws 1984, pp. 1160—1169, O.C.G.A. §§ 8-2-200 through 8-2-222, as authorized by O.C.G.A. § 8-2-203. (Ord. No. 815, § 1, 6-27-88) 
Sec. 5-163. - Effect of article on local enforcement authority and appeals boards.     The enforcement authority and all appeals boards of the city shall be apprised of and shall enforce this article so that its intent may be carried into effect. (Ord. No. 815, § 3, 6-27-88) 
Sec. 5-164. - Alteration or repair without total compliance with new construction requirements.     The provisions of this article shall require any state code enforcement authority and shall permit any authorized local code enforcement authority to permit the repair, alteration, addition, or change of use or occupancy of existing buildings without total compliance with any state or local rule, regulation, code, or standard for new construction requirements under the following general conditions: (1)  All noted conditions hazardous to life, based on the provisions of applicable state and local standards or codes for existing buildings, shall be corrected to a reasonable and realistic degree as set forth in this article, with specific attention to sections 5-174 through 5-179; (2)  The existing building becomes the minimum performance standard; and (3)  The degree of compliance of the building after changes shall not be below that existing before the changes. Nothing in this article will require or prohibit compliance with requirements more stringent than those provided in this article. (Ord. No. 815, § 4, 6-27-88) State Law reference— Authority, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-204. 
Sec. 5-165. - Identification and correction of certain conditions or defects.     With reference to existing buildings, authorized enforcement authorities shall give special attention to the conditions or defects described in this section in accordance with the provisions of section 5-164, so as to ensure that any such conditions or defects are identified and corrected as deemed appropriate by the enforcement authority having jurisdiction based on applicable state and local codes and through the utilization of appropriate compliance alternatives: (1)  Structural. Any building or structure or portion thereof which is in imminent danger of collapse because of, but not limited to, the following factors: a.  Dilapidation, deterioration, or decay; b.  Faulty structural design or construction; c.  The removal, movement, or instability of any portion of the ground necessary for the purpose of supporting such building; or d.  The deterioration, decay, or inadequacy of the foundation; (2)  Number of exits. Less than two (2) approved independent, remote, and properly protected exit ways serving every story of a building, except where a single exit way is permitted by the applicable state or local fire or building code or life safety code; (3)  Capacity of exits. Any required door, aisle, passageway, stairway, or other required means of egress which is not of sufficient capacity to provide for the population of the portions of the building served and which is not so arranged as to provide safe and adequate means of egress to a place of safety; and (4)  Mechanical systems. Utilities and mechanical systems not in conformance with the codes in effect at the time of construction of a building which create a serious threat of fire or threaten the safety of the occupants of the building. (Ord. No. 815, § 5, 6-27-88) 
Sec. 5-166. - Consideration of compliance alternatives.     Sections 5-167 through 5-171 contain generally acceptable compliance alternatives illustrating principles which shall be applied to the rehabilitation of existing buildings by state enforcement authorities and which may be applied by authorized local enforcement authorities in the state. It is recognized for purposes of this article that all building systems interact with each other; therefore, any consideration of compliance alternatives shall take into account all existing and proposed conditions to determine their acceptability. The compliance alternatives are not all-inclusive and do not preclude consideration and approval of other alternatives by any enforcement authority. (Ord. No. 815, § 6, 6-27-88) State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-206. 
Sec. 5-167. - Compliance alternatives for inadequate number of exits.     Compliance alternatives for an inadequate number of exits include, but are not limited to, the following: (1)  Provide connecting fire exit balconies acceptable to the enforcement authority between buildings; (2)  Provide alternate exit or egress facilities leading to safety outside the building or to a place of safe refuge in the building or an adjoining building as acceptable to the enforcement authority; (3)  Provide one (1) or more exterior fire escapes as acceptable to the enforcement authority where the providing of enclosed interior or enclosed exterior stairs is not practical; or (4)  Install early fire warning and fire suppression systems. (Ord. No. 815, § 7, 6-27-88) State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-207. 
Sec. 5-168. - Compliance alternatives for excessive travel distances to approved exit.     Compliance alternatives for excessive travel distances to an approved exit include, but are not limited to, the following: (1)  Install an approved smoke detection system throughout the building; (2)  Install an approved complete automatic fire suppression system; (3)  Subdivide the exit travel route with smokestop doors acceptable to the enforcement authority; (4)  Increase the fire resistance rating of corridor walls and doors; or (5)  Provide additional approved means of escape. (Ord. No. 815, § 8, 6-27-88) State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-208. 
Sec. 5-169. - Compliance alternatives for unenclosed or improperly enclosed exit stairways or vertical shafts.     Compliance alternatives for unenclosed or improperly enclosed exit stairways or vertical shafts include, but are not limited to, the following: (1)  Improve enclosure of exit stairway; (2)  Add a partial fire suppression system; (3)  Add a sprinkler draft curtain; or (4)  Add a smoke detection system. (Ord. No. 815, § 9, 6-27-88) State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-209. 
Sec. 5-170. - Compliance alternatives for inadequate fire partitions or walls.     Compliance alternatives for inadequate or a total lack of fire partitions or fire separation walls shall be as set forth in section 5-169. (Ord. No. 815, § 10, 6-27-88) State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-210. 
Sec. 5-171. - Compliance alternatives for lack of required protection of openings in exterior walls.     Compliance alternatives for a lack of required protection of openings in exterior walls where a fire exposure is a risk include, but are not limited to, the following: (1)  Improve fire resistance of existing openings and protect them with fire-rated windows or doors as appropriate; (2)  Seal the openings with fire-rated construction as approved by the enforcement authority; or (3)  Install an approved fire suppression system. (Ord. No. 815, § 11, 6-27-88) State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-211. 
Sec. 5-172. - Filing of approved compliance alternatives.     Whenever action is taken on any existing building to repair, make alterations, or change the use or occupancy of an existing structure and, when such action proposes the use of compliance alternatives, the authorized enforcement authority shall ensure that at least one (1) copy of the accepted compliance alternatives approved, including applicable plans, test data, or other data submitted for evaluation, be maintained on file in the office of the local enforcement authority. If such structure also falls under the jurisdiction of a state level enforcement authority, at least one (1) copy of same material shall be maintained on file with that authority. (Ord. No. 815, § 12, 6-27-88) State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-212. 
Sec. 5-173. - Final review of projects; agreement of local authorities.     Where an existing building or structure falls within the jurisdiction of both state level and local level enforcement authorities, the final review of any part of the project which is under the jurisdiction of both such enforcement authorities shall occur with the state authority; provided, however, the local fire and building authorities must agree in writing with any compliance alternatives before such can be approved by the state authority. It is the intent of this section that the state enforcement authority be very liberal in the consideration and approval of compliance alternatives which have the documented support of local enforcement authorities. (Ord. No. 815, § 13, 6-27-88) State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-213. 
Sec. 5-174. - Additions.     Additions to an existing building shall comply with the applicable requirements of state and local laws, rules, regulations, codes, and standards for new construction. Such additions shall not impose loads either vertical or horizontal which would cause the existing building to be subjected to stresses exceeding those permitted under new construction. If the existing building does not comply with the standards provided in this article and the authorized enforcement authority finds that the addition adversely affects the performance of the total building, the authorized enforcement authority may require: (1)  The new addition to be separated from the existing structure by at least a two-hour firewall with openings therein properly protected; or (2)  The installation of an approved automatic fire suppression system; or (3)  Other remedies which may be deemed appropriate by the enforcement authority. (Ord. No. 815, § 14, 6-27-88) State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-214. 
Sec. 5-175. - Minor alterations or repairs; reduction or removal of features, alteration or repair without further compliance, installation of mechanical systems.     Minor alterations or repairs to an existing building which do not adversely affect the performance or safety of the building may be made with the same or like materials. Existing buildings which, in part or as a whole, exceed the requirements of any applicable construction or fire safety code, may, in the course of compliance with this article, have reduced or removed, in part or total, features not required by such code for new construction, provided, however, that such features were not a condition of prior approval. Existing buildings and structures which, in part or as a whole, do not meet the requirements of the applicable code for new construction may be altered or repaired without further compliance to any such code by utilizing the provisions of this article, provided their present degree of compliance to any applicable construction or fire safety code is not reduced. Any new mechanical systems installed in an existing building shall conform to applicable codes for new construction to the fullest extent practical as approved by the authorized enforcement authorities. (Ord. No. 815, § 15, 6-27-88) State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-215. 
Sec. 5-176. - Continuation of legal use and occupancy.     The legal use and occupancy of any building or structure may be continued without change, except as may be provided otherwise by this article or as may be legally provided for by any applicable state or local law, ordinance, rule, regulation, code, or standard. (Ord. No. 815, § 16, 6-27-88) State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-216. 
Sec. 5-177. - Total change in use or occupancy. (a)  A total change in the use or occupancy of an existing building which would cause a greater hazard to the public shall not be made unless such building is made to comply with the requirements of the applicable state and local rules, regulations, codes, and standards for the new use or occupancy; provided, however, the compliance alternative provisions of this article may be utilized by authorized enforcement authorities where total or strict compliance with applicable state or local rules, regulations, codes, or standards is not practical. (b)  When the proposed use is of equal or lesser hazard as determined by an authorized enforcement authority, further compliance with any code for new construction is not required unless otherwise provided in this article. Alterations or repairs to an existing building or structure which do not adversely affect the performance of the building may be made with like materials. Any proposed change to the existing building or change in type of contents of the existing building shall not increase the fire hazard to adjacent buildings or structures. If the fire hazard to adjacent buildings or structures is increased, then requirements of applicable construction or fire safety codes for exterior walls shall apply. (Ord. No. 815, § 17, 6-27-88) State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-217. 
Sec. 5-178. - Change of portion of building to new use or occupancy. (a)  If a portion of a building is changed to a new use or occupancy and that portion is separated from the remainder of the building with vertical or horizontal fire separations complying with applicable state or local rules, regulations, codes, or standards or with compliance alternatives, then the portion changed shall be made to comply to the applicable requirements for the new use or occupancy to the extent noted in section 5-177 of this article. (b)  If a portion of the building is changed to a new use or occupancy and that portion is not separated from the remainder of the building as noted in subsection (a) of this section, then the provisions of the applicable state and local rules, regulations, codes, and standards applying to each use or occupancy of the building shall apply to the entire building to the extent noted in section 5-177 of this article; provided, however, if there are conflicting provisions in requirements for the various use or occupancies, the authorized enforcement authority shall apply the strictest requirements. (Ord. No. 815, § 18, 6-27-88) State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-218. 
Sec. 5-179. - Changes which increase floor loading.     Any proposed change in the use or occupancy of an existing building or portion thereof which could increase the floor loading shall be investigated by a state registered professional engineer to determine the adequacy of the existing floor system to support the increased loads. If the existing floor system is found to be inadequate, it shall be modified to support the increased loads or the proposed allowable floor loading shall be reduced by and posted by the appropriate enforcement authority. (Ord. No. 815, § 19, 6-27-88) State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-219. 
Sec. 5-180. - Rules and regulations.     The safety fire commissioner shall promulgate reasonable rules and regulations to implement and carry out the requirements of this article. (Ord. No. 815, § 20, 6-27-88) State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-220. 
Sec. 5-181. - Appeals of rulings or decisions.     Should any person be dissatisfied with any ruling or decision of the state fire marshal pursuant to the provisions of this article, the right is granted to appeal within ten (10) days to the commissioner. If the person is dissatisfied with the decision of the commissioner, appeal is authorized to the superior court within thirty (30) days in the manner provided under O.C.G.A. title 50, ch. 13. In the event of such appeal, the person shall give a surety bond which will be conditioned upon compliance with the order and direction of the state fire marshal or the commissioner or both. The amount of bond shall be fixed by the commissioner in such amount as will reasonably cover the order issued by the commissioner or the state fire marshal or both. (Ord. No. 815, § 21, 6-27-88) State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-221. 
Sec. 5-182. - Immunity of state and local entities; liability of proper owner or user.     Nothing in this article shall be construed to constitute a waiver of the sovereign immunity of the state or any officer or employee thereof in carrying out the provisions of this article. Further, no action shall be maintained against the state, any municipality, county, or any duly authorized elected or appointive officer or duly authorized employee thereof, for damages sustained as a result of any fire or hazard covered by this article by reason of inspection or other action taken or not taken pursuant to this article. Nothing in this article shall be construed to relieve any property owner or lessee or person in charge thereof from any legal duty, obligation, or liability incident to the ownership, maintenance, or use of such property. (Ord. No. 815, § 22, 6-27-88) State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-222. 
Secs. 5-183—5-200. - Reserved.

ARTICLE VIII. - HISTORIC PRESERVATION[5] Footnotes: --- (5) --- Cross reference— Zoning, app. A. 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
Sec. 5-231. - Definitions.     As used in this article, the following terms shall have the respective meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:     Certificate of appropriateness means a document evidencing approval by the Avondale Estates Historic Preservation Commission of an application to make a material change in the appearance of a designated historic property or of a building, structure, site, object, or work of art located within a designated historic district.     Designation means a decision by the governing body to designate a property or district as a historic property or as a historic district and thereafter to prohibit all material changes in appearance of such property or within such district prior to the issuance of a certificate of appropriateness by the historic preservation commission.     Exterior architectural features means the architectural style, general design and general arrangement of the exterior of a building or other structure, including, but not limited to, the kind or texture of the building material, the type and style of all windows, doors, signs; and other appurtenant architectural fixtures, features, details or elements relative to the foregoing.     Historic district means a geographically definable area designated by the governing body as a historic district pursuant to the criteria established in section 5-271.     Historic property means an individual building, structure, site, object or work of art, including the adjacent area necessary for the proper application or use thereof, designated as a historic property pursuant to the criteria established in section 5-272.     Material change in appearance means a change that will affect only the exterior architectural features of a historic property or of any building, structure, site, object, or work of art within a historic district, such as: (1)  A reconstruction or alteration of the size, shape or facade of a historic property, including relocation of any doors or windows or removal or alteration of any architectural features, details or elements; (2)  Demolition or relocation of a historic structure; (3)  Commencement of excavation for construction purposes; (4)  A change in the location of advertising visible from the public way on any historic property; or (5)  The erection, alteration, restoration or removal of any building or other structure within a designated historic district, including walls, fences, steps and pavements, or other appurtenant features except exterior paint alterations. (Ord. No. 806, § 2, 7-28-86; Ord. No. 855, § 1(5-70), 9-27-93) Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 5-232. - Purpose.     In support and furtherance of its findings and determination that the historical, cultural and aesthetic heritage of the city is among its most valued and important assets and that the preservation of this heritage is essential to the promotion of the health, prosperity and general welfare of the people; in order to stimulate revitalization of the business districts and the historic residential neighborhood and to protect and enhance local historical and aesthetic attractions to tourists and thereby promote and stimulate business; in order to enhance the opportunities for federal or state tax benefits under relevant provisions of federal and state law; and in order to provide for the designation, protection, preservation and rehabilitation of historic properties and historic districts and to participate in federal and state programs to do the same, the governing body hereby declares it to be the purpose and intent of this article to establish a uniform procedure for use in providing for the protection, enhancement, perpetuation and use of places, districts, sites, buildings, structures, objects and works of art having a special historical, cultural or aesthetic interest or value, in accordance with the provisions of this article. (Ord. No. 806, § 1, 7-28-86; Ord. No. 855, § 1(5-71), 9-27-93) 
Secs. 5-233—5-245. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - HISTORIC PRESERVATION COMMISSION 
Sec. 5-246. - Creation.     There is hereby created a commission the title of which shall be "Avondale Estates Historic Preservation Commission." It is hereinafter referred to as "preservation commission." (Ord. No. 806, § 3(A), 7-28-86; Ord. No. 855, § 1(5-80), 9-27-93) 
Sec. 5-247. - Position within the city.     The preservation commission shall be part of the planning function of the city. (Ord. No. 806, § 3(B), 7-28-86; Ord. No. 855, § 1(5-81), 9-27-93) 
Sec. 5-248. - Members; number, appointment, terms, compensation. (a)  The preservation commission shall consist of five (5) members appointed by the governing body. All members shall be residents of the city. (b)  A majority of the members shall be appointed from among professionals in the disciplines of architecture, history, architectural history, planning, archaeology, or other historic preservation-related disciplines, such as urban planning, American studies, American civilization, cultural geography, cultural anthropology, real estate, law, or landscape architecture, and all shall have demonstrated special interest, competence or knowledge in historic preservation. (c)  Members shall serve three-year terms. In order to achieve staggered terms, initial appointments shall be one (1) member for one (1) year; two (2) members for two (2) years, and two (2) members for three (3) years. (d)  Members shall not receive a salary, although they may be reimbursed for expenses at the discretion of the governing body. (Ord. No. 806, § 3(C), 7-28-86; Ord. No. 834, § 1, 9-27-90; Ord. No. 855, § 1(5-82), 9-27-93) 
Sec. 5-249. - Powers generally.     The preservation commission shall be authorized to: (1)  Prepare an inventory of all property within the city having the potential for designation as historic property; (2)  Recommend to the governing body specific places, districts, sites, buildings, structures or works of art to be designated by ordinance as historic properties or historic districts; (3)  Review applications for certificates of appropriateness, and grant or deny same in accordance with the provisions of this article; (4)  Recommend to the governing body that the designation of any place, district, site, building, structure or work of art as a historic property or as a historic district be revoked or removed; (5)  Restore or preserve any historic properties acquired by the city; (6)  Promote the acquisition by the city of facade easements in accordance with the provisions of the "Georgia Uniform Conservation Act" (O.C.G.A. §§ 44-10-1 through 44-10-8); (7)  Conduct educational programs on historic properties located within the city and on general historic preservation activities; (8)  Make such investigations and studies of matters relating to historic preservation as the governing body or the preservation commission itself may, from time to time, deem necessary or appropriate for the purposes of this article; (9)  Seek out local, state, federal and private funds for historic preservation, and make recommendations to the governing body concerning the most appropriate use of any funds acquired; (10)  Consult with historic preservation experts in the historic preservation section of the state department of natural resources or its successor, the Georgia Trust for Historic Preservation, Inc., and other experts; (11)  Submit to the historic preservation section of the state department of natural resources, or its successor, a list of historic properties or historic districts designated as such pursuant to this article; (12)  Perform historic preservation activities as the official agency of the city's historic preservation program; (13)  Solicit, on behalf of the city, donations, grants, funds or gifts of historic properties. The preservation commission shall not obligate the city without prior written approval and consent of the governing body; (14)  Review and make comments to the historic preservation section of the state department of natural resources concerning the nomination of properties in the city to the national register of historic places; and (15)  Participate in private, state and federal historic preservation programs and, with the consent of the governing body, enter into agreements to do the same. (Ord. No. 806, § 3(D), 7-28-86; Ord. No. 855, § 1(5-83), 9-27-93) 
Sec. 5-250. - Adoption of rules and standards; meetings. (a)  The preservation commission shall adopt rules and standards for the transaction of its business and for consideration of applications for designations and certificates of appropriateness, such as bylaws, removal of membership provisions, and design guidelines and criteria.
