Sec. 12-4.3. - Disturbing the peace; violations and penalties. (a)  The provisions of this section may be enforced by police officers and/or code enforcement officers of the city. (b)  Any person found to be disturbing the peace in violation of this section for the first time within a given calendar year shall be issued a written warning by the police or code enforcement officer rather than a citation. Such warning shall be filed and indexed appropriately by such officer to facilitate the enforcement of this section. (c)  Any person that does anything prohibited or fails to do anything required by this section, whom has already received a written warning for disturbing the peace during the current calendar year, shall be issued a citation by a police officer or a code enforcement officer. (d)  Where a citation is issued for disturbing the peace in violation of this section and the person so cited is convicted in municipal court for violation of this section, the municipal court shall impose the following penalties: (1)  Upon a first conviction for disturbing the peace within a given calendar year, the court shall impose a fine of one hundred dollars ($100.00); (2)  Upon a second conviction for disturbing the peace within a given calendar year, the court shall impose a fine of two hundred and fifty dollars ($250.00); (3)  Upon a third conviction for disturbing the peace within a given calendar year, the court shall impose a fine of five hundred dollars ($500.00); and (4)  Upon a fourth conviction for disturbing the peace within a given calendar year, the court shall impose a fine of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) and may also sentence the offender to up to six (6) months of confinement if the court deems appropriate. (Ord. No. 19-01, § 2(Att.), 1-28-19) 
Sec. 12-5. - Keeping disorderly house, permitting gambling.     It shall be unlawful for any person to keep a disorderly house, or to knowingly permit in any house or tenement in such person's premises any gambling table or gambling device at which any game of chance shall be played for money or property or anything representing same; or for any person to bet, win or lose, or play for money, or property or anything representing same; either in specie or by means of anything representing the same, at any such table or device, or at any game of chance. (Code 1973, § 2-801(3)) State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. §§ 16-11-44, 16-12-20 et seq. 
Sec. 12-5.1. - Operation of game of chance.     It shall be unlawful for any person to operate or permit the operation of any game of chance. Each day of operation, or permission to operate, shall constitute a separate offense. (Code 1973, § 2-801(57)) State Law reference— Gambling, O.C.G.A. § 16-12-20 et seq. 
Sec. 12-6. - Gambling in public.     It shall be unlawful for any person to expose in any street or upon any public ground any table or device of any kind intended for playing a game of hazard or chance, or for any person to play any such game, or any other unlawful game, in any street or upon any public ground in the city. (Code 1973, § 2-801(5)) State Law reference— Gambling, O.C.G.A. § 16-12-20 et seq. 
Sec. 12-7. - Public intoxication; consumption; transporting open containers of alcoholic beverages. (a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to be and appear on the streets and roads of the city or in any public place or place of business patronized by the public in an intoxicated condition. (b)  No person shall consume alcoholic beverages or transport open containers of alcoholic beverages on or upon public areas, except where authorized under the provisions of section 15-4 pertaining to consumption of alcoholic beverages in city parks. State Law reference— Public drunkenness, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-42. 
Sec. 12-8. - Damage, etc., to utility property.     It shall be unlawful for any person to climb upon, displace, break, deface, or in any way impair or damage any poles, wires, lamps, or equipment of any electric, telephone, telegraph or other utility. (Code 1973, § 2-801(23)) State Law reference— For similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 16-7-22 et seq. 
Sec. 12-9. - Damaging street signs, etc.     It shall be unlawful for any person to damage, deface or destroy any street sign, guidepost or lamp or lantern thereon, or any tree, building, fence, post or other thing set, erected or made for the use or ornament of the city, or paint or draw any work or figure upon any curbstone or sidewalk; or deface any sign erected on any building, or written or printed notices or placards. (Code 1973, § 2-801(22)) State Law reference— Damaging property, etc., O.C.G.A. § 16-7-22 et seq. 
Sec. 12-10. - Moving into building without authority.     It shall be unlawful for any person to move into or occupy in any manner any building belonging to any person, society, or religious assembly without leave from the person in charge of such building. (Code 1973, § 2-801(41)) State Law reference— Criminal trespass, O.C.G.A. § 16-7-21 et seq. 
Sec. 12-11. - Discharge of weapons.     It shall be unlawful for any person without legal justification to fire a gun, rifle, pistol, revolver, cannon, air rifle, or firearm of any type or shoot a slingshot or bow and arrow upon any street or highway or within one hundred (100) yards thereof, or in any building or within one hundred (100) yards of any building in the city. (Code 1973, §§ 2-801(26), (56), 2-7171) State Law reference— Discharge of guns, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-103 et seq. 
Sec. 12-12. - Reserved. Editor's note— Ord. No. 13-01, § 1, adopted Feb. 25, 2013, repealed § 12-12, which pertained to regulations prohibiting the possession of knives. 
Sec. 12-13. - Entry on closed streets.     It shall be unlawful for any person, without authority, to enter or remain upon any portion of the public streets which have been enclosed, barricaded or roped off by order of the city manager, director of public works, chief of police, or county fire chief. (Code 1973, § 2-801(29), (48)) 
Sec. 12-14. - Removal of barricades, etc.     It shall be unlawful for any person to remove the ropes or other guards placed across a street of the city while paving, grading or other public improvement or purpose which is in progress. (Code 1973, § 2-801(48)) 
Sec. 12-15. - Assembling or conspiring to commit crime.     It shall be unlawful to assemble with an intent, or being assembled, to mutually agree to do any unlawful act with force or violence against the property of the city, or the person or property of another, or against the peace, or to the terror of others, or to make any movement or operation therefor. (Code 1973, § 2-801(17)) State Law reference— Conspiracy, O.C.G.A. § 16-4-8; unlawful assembly, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-33. 
Sec. 12-16. - Preventing or disrupting lawful meetings, gatherings, or processions; crowding, pushing other persons. (a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to recklessly or knowingly commit any act which may reasonably be expected to prevent or disrupt a lawful meeting, gathering, or procession. (b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to jostle or roughly crowd or push any person in any public place. State Law reference— Disrupting lawful meeting, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-34. 
Sec. 12-17. - Interference with fire plugs.     It shall be unlawful for any person to interfere with any fire plug in any way whatever, except for a member of the fire department in the discharge of official duty or persons authorized to repair such plugs. (Code 1973, § 2-801(30)) Cross reference— Fire protection and prevention, ch. 10. 
Sec. 12-18. - Loitering or prowling—Generally. (a)  A person commits the offense of loitering or prowling when he is in a place at a time or in a manner not usual for law-abiding individuals or on the property of another without permission or legal justification under circumstances that warrant a justifiable and reasonable alarm or immediate concern for the safety of persons or property in the vicinity. (b)  Among the circumstances which may be considered in determining whether alarm is warranted is the fact that the person takes flight upon the appearance of a law enforcement officer, refuses to identify himself, or manifestly endeavors to conceal himself or any object. Unless flight by the person or other circumstances make it impracticable, a law enforcement officer shall, prior to any arrest for an offense under this section, afford the person an opportunity to dispel any alarm or immediate concern which would otherwise be warranted by requesting the person to identify himself and explain his presence and conduct. No person shall be convicted of an offense under this section if the law enforcement officer failed to comply with the foregoing procedure or if it appears at trial that the explanation given by the person was true and would have dispelled the alarm or immediate concern. (Ord. No. 829, § 1, 11-6-89) State Law reference— Loitering or prowling, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-36. 
Sec. 12-19. - Same—Minors.     It shall be unlawful for any parent, guardian, or other person having the custody or control of any minor to permit, allow, or encourage such minor to violate section 12-18. 
Sec. 12-20. - Same—For purpose of procuring others to engage in sexual acts for hire.     It shall be unlawful for any person to loiter in public for the purpose of soliciting or procuring others to engage in any sexual acts for hire. 
Sec. 12-21. - Same—For purpose of engaging in drug-related activity. (a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to loiter in or near any thoroughfare, place open to the public, or near any public or private place in a manner and under circumstances manifesting the purpose to engage in drug-related activity contrary to any of the provisions of O.C.G.A. tit. 16, ch. 13 (O.C.G.A. § 16-13-1 et seq.). (b)  Among the circumstances which may be considered in determining whether such purpose is manifested are: (1)  Such person is a known unlawful drug user, possessor, or seller. For purposes of this chapter, a "known unlawful drug user, possessor, or seller" is a person who has, within the knowledge of the arresting officer, been convicted in any court within this state of any violation involving the use, possession, or sale of any controlled substance as defined in O.C.G.A. tit. 16, ch. 13 (O.C.G.A. § 16-13-1 et seq.) or such person has been convicted of any violation of any of the provisions of such title and chapter of the Official Code of Georgia or substantially similar laws of any political subdivision of this state or of any other state; or a person who displays physical characteristics of drug intoxication or usage, such as needle tracks, burned or callused thumb and index fingers, underweight, nervous and excited behavior. (2)  Such person is currently subject to a court order prohibiting his presence in a high drug activity geographic area. (3)  Such person behaves in such a manner as to raise a reasonable suspicion that he is about to engage in or is then engaged in an unlawful drug-related activity including, by way of example only, such person acting as a lookout or hailing or stopping cars. (4)  Such person is physically identified by the officer as a member of a gang, or association which has as its purpose illegal drug activity. (5)  Such person transfers small objects or packages in a furtive fashion. (6)  Such person takes flight or manifestly endeavors to conceal himself upon the appearance of a police officer. (7)  Such person manifestly endeavors to conceal any object which reasonably could be involved in an unlawful drug-related activity. (8)  Such person possesses any instrument, article, or thing whose customary or primary purpose is for the sale, administration, or use of controlled substances such as, but not limited to, crack pipes, push wires, chore boys, hand scales, hypodermic needles, razor blades, or other cutting tools. (9)  The area involved is by public repute known to be an area of unlawful drug use and trafficking. (10)  Any vehicle involved is registered to a known unlawful drug user, possessor, or seller, or a person for whom there is an outstanding warrant for a crime involving drug-related activity. 
Sec. 12-22. - Selling, soliciting, begging on city property. (a)  Without the express written consent of the city manager, it shall be unlawful for any person to beg, solicit, or sell goods, wares or other objects or services within any building, or on any grounds, sidewalks or other ways owned by or under the control of the city, its agencies, authorities, commissions, boards, bureaus, or other city entities. (b)  It shall be unlawful to sell, offer for sale, or solicit for sale any candy, ice cream, confection or any food or beverage for human consumption from any pushcart, bicycle cart, motorized cart or other type of motor vehicle on the public streets, sidewalks, or in the public rights-of-way of the city. 
Sec. 12-23. - Advertisements—Posting bills on public property; obscene posters. (a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to post any advertising matter upon the streets or other public places of the city; nor shall any poster or placard be posted, publicly displayed or exhibited which is lewd, indecent or vulgar, or which pictorially represents the commission of or attempt to commit any crime. (b)  Each day or part of a day that any such poster or placard remains so displayed or exhibited shall be deemed a separate offense. (c)  Nothing herein shall be construed to prevent anyone from displaying legitimate advertising of such person's own business in or upon such person's own premises if in conformance with the city's sign ordinance contained in chapter 5. (Code 1973, § 2-801(24)) Signs and advertising structures, § 5-361 et seq.; littering with handbills, § 11-32 et seq. 
Sec. 12-24. - Same—Posting bills on poles, etc.     It shall be unlawful for any person to post upon any building, fence, tree, telegraph, telephone, or other public service pole any sign, advertisement, picture, or notice of any kind. It shall be unlawful for any person to post upon any building or other structure in the city any sign, advertisement, or notice of any kind without first having obtained permission to do so from the owner or occupant of such building or other structure, as well as from the city clerk. (Code 1973, § 2-801(43)) Cross reference— Littering with handbills, § 11-32; signs and advertising structures, § 5-361 et seq. 
Sec. 12-25. - Same—Displaying illegal matter.     It shall be unlawful for any person to display or allow to be displayed upon such person's premises or for any person to display in any public place any advertisement of any business, performance or attraction prohibited by any law or any city ordinances, or for any publication or advertising medium to be sold or distributed within the city which contains an advertisement of any business or performance forbidden by law or ordinance. (Code 1973, § 2-801(25)) 
Sec. 12-26. - Reckless operation of motor vehicle upon parking facility or walkway.     No person shall operate a motor vehicle upon any parking facility, public or private, vehicle-access, or pedestrian walkway of any parking facility by sudden starting, stopping or turning so as to endanger the person or property of another. 
Sec. 12-27. - Operation of motorized vehicles on school property.     The operation of motorized vehicles of any nature in or on any yard, campus, playing field or open area of any public school, college or institution in the city, except on those areas designated by school authorities for use of motorized vehicles, is prohibited. 
Sec. 12-28. - Fortunetelling.     It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in or participate in the practice of fortunetelling, phrenology, clairvoyance, palmistry, or other kindred practices, businesses, or professions where a charge is made or a donation accepted for such services. This section does not apply to astrology. State Law reference— Authority to prohibit fortunetelling, O.C.G.A. § 36-1-15. 
Sec. 12-29. - Residential picketing prohibited. (a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in picketing upon, before, or about the private residence or home of any individual. (b)  Picketing shall include, but not be limited to, the following types of activities: (1)  Staging a passage to or from a residence; (2)  Promoting a strike or a boycott at a residence; (3)  Intimidating or otherwise harassing a resident. (c)  It is the purpose of this section to protect and preserve the home, inasmuch as the public health and welfare and the good order of the city require that citizens of the city enjoy a feeling of peace, well-being, and privacy in their homes at all times. 
Sec. 12-30. - Throwing objects.     No person shall recklessly or knowingly throw or propel any stone, brick, piece of wood or other object at any person, vehicle, house, building or other structure or object, or across or upon any private or public property. 
Sec. 12-31. - Defecating or urinating on public property or in certain areas.     It shall be unlawful for any person to defecate or urinate on or adjacent to any street or sidewalk, or in the halls, elevators, stairways, or any other area designated for public passage within any public or commercial buildings, or on any property open to public view. 
Secs. 12-32, 12-33. - Reserved. Editor's note— Ord. No. 9907, § 2, adopted 11-22-99. repealed §§ 12-32, 12-33 in their entirety. Formerly, § 12-32 pertained to giving false name, address, or date of birth to a police officer and § 12-33 pertained to criminal impersonation. See the Code Comparative Table. 
Sec. 12-34. - False police alarms.     No person shall knowingly and willfully harass or attempt to harass or mislead any police officer by false alarms or unauthorized use of any device of whatever nature to summon police aid without reasonable cause. 
Sec. 12-35. - Alarm systems. (a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:     Alarm system means an assembly of equipment and devices designated and arranged to detect a fire or signal an unauthorized intrusion into premises or to signal an attempted robbery at protected premises, and, with respect to such signal, public safety officers are expected to respond.     False alarm means the activation of a fire, burglary and/or robbery alarm by other than a fire, forced entry or attempted forced entry to the premises and at a time when no fire, burglary or robbery is being committed or attempted on the premises.     Response means the dispatch of a public safety officer to the premises where an alarm system has been activated indicating a fire, burglary and/or robbery is presently in progress on those premises. (b)  Penalty for violation of or noncompliance with section. Any person or business violating or failing to comply with any of the provisions of this section shall be summoned to the municipal court for each violation and noncompliance and upon conviction shall be punished as provided by law. (c)  Unlawful activation; failure to notify police department of malfunction or repair work. It is unlawful for anyone to activate any fire, robbery or burglar alarm for the purpose of summoning public safety officers except in the event of an actual fire, attempted burglary or robbery, or for anyone notifying public safety of an activated alarm and having knowledge that such activation was apparently caused by an electrical or other malfunction of the alarm system, or was apparently caused by maintenance or service to the alarm system, to fail at the same time to notify public safety of such apparent malfunction or repair. (d)  Response to false alarm; fees; corrective action. For a public safety response to any false alarm, the city manager shall charge and collect fees from the person or business having or maintaining such fire, burglary and/or robbery alarm system on the premises owned or occupied by him as follows: (1)  For a first false alarm response to premises at which no other false alarm has occurred within a calendar year period, no fee shall be charged, but the person having or maintaining such fire, burglary and/or robbery alarm shall, within seven (7) working days after notice to do so, make a written report to the city manager on forms prescribed by him setting forth the cause of such false alarm, the corrective action taken, whether such alarm has been inspected by an authorized serviceman, and such other information as the city manager may require to determine the cause of such false alarm and corrective action necessary. (2)  For the second false alarm response to premises after a first false alarm response within a calendar year period, no fee shall be charged, but a written report shall be required as for a first false alarm response and the city manager shall be authorized to inspect or cause to be inspected the alarm system at such premises and to prescribe necessary corrective action. (3)  For a third and a fourth false alarm response to premises after a second false alarm response within a calendar year, no fee shall be charged, but a written report shall be required as for a first false alarm response and the city manager shall be authorized to inspect or cause to be inspected the alarm system at such premises, prescribe necessary corrective action, and shall give notice to the person or business having or maintaining such alarm system of the conditions and requirements of this chapter, including the fee requirements for five (5) or more false alarm responses by the police within each calendar year. (4)  After a fourth false alarm response to premises within a calendar year, and for all succeeding false alarm responses within that calendar year, a fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) shall be charged and, if such false alarms are as a result of failure to take necessary corrective action prescribed by the city manager, the city manager may order the disconnection of such alarm system until such corrective action is taken; provided no disconnection shall be ordered as to any premises required by law to have an alarm system in operation. (Ord. No. 840, § 1(19-1)—(19-4), 9-23-91) 
Sec. 12-36. - False information to police officer prohibited.     It shall be unlawful for any person to fail to give full, complete, and accurate information as to his or her own name, social security number, address, date of birth, or driver's license to a city police officer in the lawful discharge of his or her duties who is attempting to ascertain such person's true identity. (Ord. No. 99-07, § 1, 11-22-99) 
Sec. 12-37. - Possession of marijuana prohibited.     It shall be unlawful for any person to possess one (1) ounce or less or marijuana within the corporate limits of the city. (Ord. No. 9909, § 1, 11-22-99) 
Sec. 12-38. - Motion picture, television and photographic production ordinance. (a)  Permit required. (1)  No person shall use any public or private property, building, facility or residence of producing, taking or making any motion picture, television production or photographic production without first applying for and receiving a city filming permit issued pursuant to the provisions of this chapter. (b)  Exceptions. (1)  Regulation by this chapter shall not apply to: a.  Amateur photographers. b.  Reporters or cameramen in the employ of a newspaper, news service, radio or television broadcasting station engaged in on the spot broadcasting, reporting or photographing of news of general public interest. This exception is not to include magazine or documentary programs. c.  Productions which are conducted by the city or any city board or commission. (c)  Permit administrator. (1)  The city manager is hereby appointed as the permit administrator and shall issue permits as provided for in this chapter. (d)  Application for permit. (1)  Any person desiring a permit under the provisions of this chapter shall make application on the approved form provided by the city. The form must be signed and accompanied by all required fees, deposits, hold harmless agreement and insurance certificates required by this chapter before any permit will be considered for approval. (2)  Filming permit applications shall be submitted at least five (5) working days prior to the date on which such person desires to conduct an activity for which a permit is required. (e)  Issuance of permit; conditions; appeals. (1)  The city manager shall issue a permit as provided for in this chapter, when, from a consideration of the application and from such other information as may be otherwise obtained, he/she finds that: a.  The conduct of such activity will not unduly interfere with traffic or pedestrian movement or endanger public safety and that no streets will be completely closed to traffic for an unreasonable period of time. Seventy-two (72) hours advance notice of any street closure request shall be provided. b.  The conduct of such activity will not unduly interfere with normal governmental or city operations, threaten to result in damage or detriment to public property, or result in damage or detriment to public property, or result in the city incurring costs or expenditures in either money or personnel not reimbursed in advance by the applicant. c.  At the determination of the city manager that such activity will not constitute a fire hazard or any other type of hazard and all safety precautions will be taken as determined necessary by the city manager. (2)  The decision of the city manager to issue, conditionally issue, or deny a permit shall be final unless appealed in writing within five (5) working days of the decision to the board of mayor and commissioners. (3)  The board of mayor and commissioners shall render a decision to issue, conditionally issue or uphold the denial of a permit at the next regularly scheduled meeting of the board of mayor and commissioners. The decision of the board of mayor and commissioners will be final. (f)  Bond, insurance, hold harmless and indemnification. (1)  As a condition of issuing such a permit, the applicant shall furnish a bond, insurance or both in the amount to be determined by the city manager, but in no event, an amount less than five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00), to protect the city against claims of third persons for personal injury, wrongful death and property damage and to indemnify the city for damage to city property arising out of the permittee's activities. (2)  A minimum of five million dollars ($5,000,000.00) of such bond, general liability insurance coverage or both shall be required in the event aircraft, helicopters, pyrotechnics or automobile chase scenes are used in the activity. Such insurance shall be evidenced by the standard general liability special endorsement form mandated by this chapter. City shall be listed as additional insured and applicant shall have primary coverage. (3)  The applicant shall execute an indemnity and hold harmless agreement as provided by the city prior to the issuance of any permit that shall hold the city harmless against any claims, liability or judgments arising out of the permittee's activities. (g)  Suspension or revocation of permit. (1)  The city manager shall have the authority, after notice and an opportunity for a hearing, to suspend or revoke any permit issued hereunder where the terms and conditions of said permit have been violated or ignored, including the timely payment of all required fees and deposits, or suspend or revoke any permit where the public safety or welfare is endangered by the permitted activity. Provided however, that whenever there is an imminent danger to the public health, safety or welfare from activities conducted by the permittee to the extent that immediate action is necessary to protect the public, the city manager shall have the authority to suspend a permit pending a hearing. (h)  Fees and costs of additional services. (1)  Each application shall be accompanied by the following non-refundable fees: a.  A processing fee in the amount of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) will be submitted to the city at the time of application. b.  Upon approval of an application for a city filming permit, the city manager shall provide the applicant with a statement of the estimated cost of providing police, public works and other city employees and services for public safety for the production. The cost of such services shall be borne by the applicant and shall be paid to the city prior to the conducting of a production. The amount of such fees shall be based on the city's actual cost of providing the required number of police and other city employees and services necessary to ensure the safety of both the participants of the production and the community. c.  If the actual cost of public services for the production is less than the estimated cost pursuant to subsection (h)(1)b. of this section, the permittee shall promptly be refunded the difference by the city. If the actual cost for public services is more than the estimated cost pursuant to subsection (h)(1)b. of this section, the difference shall become due and payable to the city immediately upon the permittee's receipt of a statement of actual costs by the city. d.  All fees may be waived for wholly charitable or educational purposes and from which no profit is derived, either directly or indirectly. Tax exempt and nonprofit organizations must qualify under Section 501(c)(3) of the United States Internal Revenue Code and proof of such status must be provided to the city in order for said fees to be waived by the city. (i)  Regulations and conditions. (1)  The applicant shall: a.  Maintain a copy of the production permit on-site at all times. b.  Comply with any and all conditions or restrictions the city may impose as a condition to issuing a permit. No changes to the conditions or restrictions shall be made without the written approval of the city manager. c.  Have nonexclusive use of facilities and public right-of-way unless otherwise granted in writing. d.  Provide advanced notification of forty-eight (48) hours in a form approved by the city manager to adjacent properties for any production. e.  Comply with the City of Avondale Estates Noise Ordinance. (2)  The city manager may promulgate and enforce additional regulations as necessary and appropriate in the implementation and enforcement of this chapter. (j)  Filming on private property. (1)  An applicant is required to obtain the property owner's permission, consent, and/or lease for use of property not owned or controlled by the city. Written permission of the property owner must be presented at time of permit application. (2)  An applicant is required to minimize interference with the normal activities of a neighborhood or commercial area, including access to private or public property. (k)  Filming at city facilities or on the public right-of-way.     In the event that the applicant desires to locate their production event at a facility owned or managed by the city, or on the public right-of-way, the city shall charge a daily fee in an amount determined by the city manager not to exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per day. If an existing facility charge has been established by the city at a facility owned or managed by the city, that fee will be charged to the applicant. (l)  Traffic control.     The city retains the right and the authority to regulate traffic and require vehicles to be moved or towed (at the owner's expense) to protect the health, safety and welfare of the community. (m)  Faithful performance bond; clean up and restoration.     To ensure clean-up and restoration of any site on public property or public right-of-way used by permittee within the city limits, said permittee may be required to post a refundable faithful performance bond (amount to be determined by the city manager) at the time the application is submitted. Upon completion of the production and upon the finding by the city that the site has been satisfactorily cleaned up and restored, the bond may be returned to the permittee. (Ord. No. 0602, § 1, 6-26-06) 
Chapter 13 - MUNICIPAL UTILITIES AND SERVICES[1] Footnotes: --- (1) --- Charter reference— Authority to own, etc., § 1-102(11). 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
Sec. 13-1. - Unauthorized sewer connections.     It shall be unlawful for any person to enter or attempt to enter or connect or attempt to connect a private drain or sewer or a building or plumbing fixture into or to any portion of the public sewer system or of any of the mains of such system unless such person is authorized to do so in the manner prescribed by law. (Code 1973, § 2-7138) 
Secs. 13-2—13-19. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - WASTE MANAGEMENT[2] Footnotes: --- (2) --- Charter reference— Authority, § 1-102(19). Cross reference— Litter, § 11-20 et seq. State Law reference— Solid Waste Management Act, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-20 et seq. 
Sec. 13-20. - Applicability.     This article applies to the preparation and storage, collection, transportation and disposal of all refuse in the area under jurisdiction of the city as presently or hereafter established. It prescribes rules and regulations therefor, regulates the private collection of garbage and refuse, provides for the licensing and regulation of private garbage and refuse collection, prescribes rules and regulations for hauling garbage, refuse and other waste material within or through the city, and prohibits the deposit of litter within the city. (Ord. No. 844, § 1(12-20), 11-25-91) 
Sec. 13-21. - Definitions.     The following words, terms and phrases when used in this article shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:     Administrative officer means the city manager or the person authorized by the city manager, to enforce the provisions of this article.     Ashes means waste products from coal, wood and other fuels used for cooking and heating from private residences.     Building refuse means waste material resulting from construction, remodeling, repairs and demolition operations on houses, buildings and other structures, including driveways and walks and comprising waste and rejected matter such as excavated earth, stones, bricks, plaster, wallpaper, sheetrock and lathes, lumber, shingles, tile, concrete and waste parts occasioned by the installation or replacement of plumbing, heating systems, electrical work and roofing.     Commercial/industrial establishment means any hotel, motel, industrial, public or semipublic establishment of any nature or kind whatsoever other than residential dwelling units.     Disposal area means a site, location, tract of land, or facility, used or intended to be used for the final disposal of solid waste, garbage, putrescible waste, hazardous waste, or other waste, except that the term shall not include the land or facility used for the disposal of solid waste or other waste from a single-family dwelling on which the owner, occupant or lessee of such land or facility resides.     Garbage means food waste, including waste accumulation of animal or vegetable matter used for or intended for use as food or that attends the preparation, use, cooking, dealing in or storing of meat, fish, fowl, fruit or vegetables.     Hazardous waste means solid or liquid waste material resulting from the manufacture or use of pesticides and drugs (other than normal household use); pathological wastes; highly flammable or explosive wastes; toxic wastes; sewage sludges; and other waste material that the director determines to be a likely hazard to the public health, safety or environment, except radioactive waste materials as provided in rules of the Georgia Department of Human Resources, chapter 270-5-20, entitled "Radioactive Materials."     Industrial refuse means waste materials from factories, processing plants, wholesale establishments, assembling plants, food processing wastes, cinders and ashes, lumber scraps, excelsior, shavings, floor sweepings, metal scrap and shavings, and any other waste products from industrial and manufacturing processes.     Owner means any person, firm or corporation owning, leasing, renting or occupying any premises within the jurisdiction of the city.     Recyclable waste means all aluminum cans, newspaper print, all unbroken glass bottles, jars and containers, and all plastic bottles and containers. Recyclable waste shall also include any other items that may hereafter be designated as recyclable pursuant to the rules and regulations promulgated by the governing authority.     Rubbish means nonrecyclable, household waste derived from places of residence and includes paper, rags, plastics, cartons, boxes, tin and other metal cans, broken glass bottles and jars, crockery, excelsior, rubber, discarded clothing and similar materials.     Scavenge means uncontrolled picking from discarded solid waste materials.     Solid waste means mineral matter, metal and wooden furniture, appliances, large metal scraps and wires, automobile or other vehicle bodies, tires or parts, wooden crates, boxes or pallets, dead animals, and any other wastes in a solid or semisolid state (excluding human body excrement), not otherwise defined in this section.     Waste means any unwanted or discarded material including, but not limited to, ashes, building refuse, garbage, hazardous waste, industrial refuse, recyclable waste, rubbish, solid waste, and yard debris.     Waste management collector means any person authorized by the city to collect, recycle, and dispose of waste acceptable for collection.     Yard debris means tree limbs, branches, stumps and logs, twigs, grass and shrub trimmings and clippings, bushes, weeds, leaves and general yard and garden waste materials, excluding stone and dirt rakings and similar waste materials resulting from routine landscaping activities. (Ord. No. 765, § 1(1), 2-28-77; Ord. No. 844, § 1(12-21), 11-25-91) Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 13-22. - Administration and enforcement of article. (a)  Responsibility for administration. In order to protect the health and safety of the people in the city, the administrative officer shall implement and enforce the provisions of this article to control the storage, collection, and disposal of solid waste in the city. Such officer shall plan, organize, procure equipment and personnel, and manage a collection and disposal service and/or establish criteria for evaluation of private collection and disposal services, make recommendations to the governing body regarding contracts for waste collection and/or disposal between it and private collectors and/or disposal site owners and/or operators, and shall regulate the establishment, maintenance and operation of public or private waste collection and/or disposal systems, methods and sites. (b)  Functions of administrative officer. Collection, transportation and disposal of waste shall be under the supervision and control of the administrative officer. Such officer shall have the authority to establish routes and days of collection, types and locations of waste containers, and such other matters pertaining to collection, transportation and disposal of waste as such officer may find necessary and to change and modify the same after notice as required by law, provided such measures are not contrary to the provisions of this article. (Ord. No. 765, § 1(2)(a), (b), 2-28-77; Ord. No. 844, § 1(12-22), 11-25-91) 
Sec. 13-23. - Violations; penalties. (a)  Upon determining that a violation of this article exists, the administrative officer shall cause a written notice of violation to be issued to the subject owner setting forth the condition existing and a reasonable time within which for the owner to correct the condition. (b)  Upon determining that the owner has failed to correct the subject condition within the time limit prescribed in the notice, the administrative officer shall cause a summons to be issued directing the owner to appear in the municipal court to answer the charge of violation of the appropriate section of this article. (c)  Any person violating or failing to comply with any of the provisions of this article shall be summoned to the municipal court for each violation and upon conviction shall be punished by a fine not exceeding one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), or by imprisonment for a period not to exceed six (6) months, either or both of such fines and imprisonment, or work on the streets, parks and/or public works, in the discretion of the municipal judge. Each day a violation of any provision of this article continues shall constitute a separate offense. (Ord. No. 844, § 1(12-23), 11-25-91) 
Sec. 13-24. - Transportation of refuse; licensing of commercial sanitation firms. (a)  It shall be unlawful for any person including city refuse collectors and other waste management collectors to haul, convey or cause to be conveyed any refuse, including discarded building material or discarded furniture, upon or along the public streets and roadways except when the material transported is adequately secured in such a manner as to prevent it from falling, leaking or being blown from transporting vehicles. The operator or owner of the offending vehicle shall be personally responsible for any violation of this section. (b)  It shall be unlawful for any person not approved by the city to collect and haul any refuse other than that arising from such person's own accumulation within any areas of the city in which refuse collection service is maintained by the city. An application in compliance with this section shall be submitted to the administrative officer for approval or other disposition. (1)  Each application shall have attached a list showing the type, size and location of stationary compactors, stationary compactor containers and/or industrial waste materials to be serviced by the applicant. A commercial sanitation firm applying for approval to operate stationary compactors, stationary compactor containers or industrial waste containers shall certify at the time of application that the applicant or any corporate officer of the firm is not engaged in any illegal servicing of any commercial containers or refuse collection of any type in the city. (2)  Each authorized commercial sanitation firm shall pay a monthly charge based on the size of the stationary compactor container or industrial waste container in use on the last day of each month in the amount of one dollar ($1.00) per cubic yard. This fee shall be paid on or before the fifteenth day of each succeeding month for which the service was rendered. A schedule of the location of each stationary compactor shall accompany the payment of the fees. (3)  Each stationary compactor, stationary compactor container or industrial waste container shall carry in a conspicuous location the name, telephone number and address of the firm permitted to service the stationary compactor, stationary compactor container or industrial waste container. (4)  Plans and specifications for installing a stationary compactor unit shall be approved by the city codes enforcement officer prior to the installation. All stationary compactor containers shall be installed on class A, three thousand (3,000) psi concrete pads of not less than six-inch thickness. All installations shall comply with the requirements of the city and county mechanical codes, fire code and health regulations. (5)  All stationary compactor containers shall be in good condition and repair and shall be washed and treated with appropriate chemicals as necessary to prevent nuisances. (Ord. No. 765, § 4, 2-28-77; Ord. No. 844, § 1(12-24), 11-25-91) 
Sec. 13-25. - Pickup routes and districts established; collection days. (a)  The administrative officer shall divide the city into pickup routes and shall prepare a list of the names of all the streets, roads, alleys, drives, highways and other public thoroughfares within each route. (b)  In residential areas not more than four (4) days, nor less than two (2) days, shall elapse between one collection and the next, and routes of collection shall be arranged so that collections shall be made on the same days of each succeeding week. From commercial areas and institutions, collections shall be made daily except Saturday, Sunday and holidays. Collections shall not be made on the following holidays unless otherwise specified by the administrative officer: New Year's Day, Observance of Martin Luther King, Jr.'s birthday, Memorial Day, Independence Day, Labor Day, Thanksgiving Day and the day after, and Observance of Christmas (two (2) days). (c)  It shall be the duty of the occupant of any residential or commercial/industrial unit to place refuse for collection by the city at the proper collection site prior to 7:45 a.m. or prior to the arrival of the sanitation truck. (d)  Any containers placed at curbside by the owner or occupant for collection shall be removed by the owner/occupant to a storage location located on the residential premises the day the contents are emptied and collected. (Ord. No. 765, § 4, 2-28-77; Ord. No. 844, § 1(12-25), 11-25-91) 
Sec. 13-26. - Collection by city; disposal of unacceptable or commercial/industrial waste.     All refuse generated or accumulated in the city shall be collected, transported and disposed of by the city through its designated agents, employees, or contract representatives. No other person shall collect, transport or dispose of any refuse generated or accumulated in the city, except that these rules and regulations shall not prohibit the producers of waste unacceptable for routine collection, producers of commercial/industrial waste or the owner of premises upon which commercial/industrial waste has accumulated from collecting, transporting and disposing of such refuse, subject to laws and regulations pertinent thereto, if such service is not provided by the city and if any such private contractor has been approved by the city to conduct such business within the city. (Ord. No. 765, § 1(2)(c), (d), 2-28-77; Ord. No. 844, § 1(12-26), 11-25-91) 
Sec. 13-27. - Waste acceptable for routine collection by the city. (a)  Subject to the conditions and requirements set forth in this article, garbage, recyclable waste, household rubbish and yard debris constitute waste acceptable for collection by the city's waste management collector. (b)  Small dead animals, not over thirty (30) pounds in weight, if kept separate from garbage and rubbish, will be collected without charge upon notice to the administrative officer, provided that a charge will be made for all such animals collected from animal hospitals, kennels, pet shops and the like. Owners of large dead animals shall be responsible for their removal and disposal. (Ord. No. 765, § 3, 2-28-77; Ord. No. 844, § 1(12-27), 11-25-91) 
Sec. 13-28. - Waste unacceptable for routine collection by the city. (a)  Except as provided in this article, it shall be a violation of this article to place or cause to be placed in any container or at curbside for routine collection any of the following: (1)  Building refuse; (2)  Hazardous waste; (3)  Industrial refuse; (4)  Solid waste; (5)  Yard debris, except as provided in section 12-31; (6)  Trees, bushes or other vegetation from commercial tree trimmers, landscapers or building contractors; and (7)  Waste of any type from vacant lots unless payment of sanitation or lot upkeep tax for the current year has been made. (b)  Waste not acceptable for routine collection shall be the responsibility of the owner. It shall be the duty of each owner to make arrangements as may be necessary with the city and/or the city's waste management collector for the collection and disposal of such waste on a special fee, on-call basis. (Ord. No. 844, § 1(12-28), 11-25-91) 
Sec. 13-29. - Containers—Generally. (a)  Refuse containers adequate to hold the refuse normally accumulating between scheduled removals shall be provided on each premises by the owner or occupant of each residence, industry, place of business or congregation and shall be maintained in good condition. Each container shall be waterproof, galvanized metal or durable plastic of a capacity of not more than thirty-two (32) gallons, having two (2) handles on the side thereof or a bail by which it may be lifted, with a tightfitting metal or plastic top with a handle and so constructed as to permit the free discharge of its contents. Oil or grease drums, paint cans and similar salvaged containers shall not be acceptable. (b)  Refuse containers shall be kept clean and free of accumulated waste and shall be treated with appropriate chemicals as necessary to prevent nuisance. Containers failing to comply with these provisions or with sharp or jagged edges or with defects liable to hamper or injure the person collecting the contents thereof shall be promptly replaced by the owner or occupant. (Ord. No. 765, § 3, 2-28-77; Ord. No. 844, § 1(12-29), 11-25-91) 
Sec. 13-30. - Same—Preparation and storage for commercial/industrial waste. (a)  Hazardous or noxious wastes shall be contained in a safe and sanitary manner. (b)  Containers shall be consolidated to minimize the number of collection sites and located so as to reasonably equalize the distance from the building spaces they serve. (c)  Containers and enclosures shall be located so as to allow ease of access for collection trucks and direct access to drive areas. Straight-in or circular drives are encouraged to reduce truck maneuvering problems. No parking or other obstructions shall be permitted in the access area for enclosures. (d)  Containers and enclosures shall be placed away from public view insofar as is practical. (e)  Containers and enclosures shall be situated so that they do not cause excessive nuisance or offense to occupants of nearby buildings. (f)  All refuse containers shall be screened with a six-foot high (minimum) fence or wall which conceals containers from all sides. (g)  Concrete pads of appropriate size and construction shall be provided for containers or groups of containers having a capacity of six (6) thirty-two-gallon cans or more. Adequate drainage shall be provided in and around the pad area. (h)  Newspapers, aluminum cans, and all other recyclable waste should be separated from waste acceptable for routine collection. For storage of these and other recyclable materials, the enclosure area and pad size shall be increased to amply accommodate the extra materials and their containers. (i)  The tops of trash enclosures which are directly visible from the second floor of any off-site building shall be screened with a roof or overhead trellis. (j)  Screening and gates shall be of a durable construction; fences, walls, footings, slabs and curbs shall meet all applicable ordinances. Gates shall be constructed of heavy-gauge metal or of a heavy-gauge metal frame with a covering of wood or other suitable material. Gates shall be secured with sturdy hinges or sliders and latches. For enclosures of six (6) cans or more and for bins, the screening shall be protected at its base by curbs. If screening is to be situated directly adjacent to parking spaces or drives, it shall be protected by a concrete-curbed buffer strip (minimum three (3) feet wide) of landscaping or pavement. (k)  The design of the screening shall be compatible with the architectural design of on-site buildings and shall be approved by the city's codes enforcement officer. Screening shall be constructed of concrete tilt-up or masonry materials or the primary material used on the on-site building walls. (l)  Before a building permit shall be issued for construction of a commercial or industrial establishment, arrangements for the storage of refuse and location of containers must be approved by the city's codes enforcement officer. (m)  All garbage and rubbish shall be free of liquid and placed in watertight paper or plastic bags. The bags shall be unbroken and securely sealed and placed in the container in a manner so that normal handling will not cause the bag to open. (n)  The occupants, of commercial establishments shall be responsible for maintaining the area surrounding refuse containers clean and free of accumulations of refuse. (Ord. No. 844, § 1(12-30), 11-25-91) 
Sec. 13-31. - Same—Preparation and storage of residential waste. (a)  It shall be the duty of the occupant or owner of any premises to keep all refuse pending collection and disposal as follows: (1)  All waste shall be free from liquid and placed in watertight paper or plastic bags of a type, size and material designed for waste storage and disposal. The bags shall be unbroken and securely sealed and placed in the container in a manner so that normal handling will not cause the bag to open. (2)  All containers shall be stored at the side or rear of the residence for collection. (3)  Tree limbs, branches, heavy brush and other similar types of yard debris shall be cut into lengths not exceeding six (6) feet and four (4) inches in diameter, and placed in containers not over fifty (50) pounds gross weight or tied into bundles not exceeding fifty (50) pounds each for curbside pickup. (4)  Bundles or bags of yard debris shall be placed at curbside for collection and shall at no time extend into the streets, gutters, drains, walkways, alleys, rights-of-way, or other property of the city. (5)  Leaves shall be separated from other yard debris for curbside collection. (6)  Newspapers, aluminum cans, and all other recyclable waste shall be separated from other waste acceptable for routine collection for recycling collection. a.  The interior of all aluminum cans, plastic, and glass bottles shall be rinsed and drained. All lids, tops, and caps shall be removed and properly disposed of as rubbish. b.  All newspapers shall be tied or bagged for recycling collection and shall be maintained in a dry condition. (b)  Residential refuse will not be collected by the city if such refuse is contained in a locked area or where dogs are loose. (c)  Waste generated from the conduct of business or commercial enterprise carried on from residential units will not be collected by the city except on a special fee basis. (d)  Trees, bushes or other vegetation from commercial tree trimmers, landscapers or building contractors will not be collected by the city except on a special fee basis. (e)  Waste of any type from vacant lots will not be collected unless payment of the sanitation or lot upkeep tax for the current year has been made. (Ord. No. 765, § 3, 2-28-77; Ord. No. 844, § 1(12-31), 11-25-91) 
Sec. 13-32. - Scavenging prohibited.     It shall be deemed a violation of this article for any person, other than the owner, the city or the city's waste management collector to remove, collect, salvage or otherwise interfere with any containerized waste pending collection. (Ord. No. 765, § 3, 2-28-77; Ord. No. 844, § 1(12-32), 11-25-91) 
Sec. 13-33. - Littering; accumulation prohibited. (a)  No person shall throw, discharge, discard or otherwise cause to be deposited waste of any character into the streets, gutters, drains, walkways, alleys, rights-of-way, streams, lakes or impoundment, or other property of the city. (b)  Except as otherwise set forth in this article, any accumulation of waste on any property within the city is hereby declared to be a nuisance and is prohibited. (c)  The provisions of subsection (b) of this section do not apply to the dumping on private property with the owner's permission of sand, dirt, broken dirt, blocks, broken pavement or other suitable material for use as fill to raise the elevation of the land, provided it is not maintained in an unsightly condition and provided the owners of the property on which such material is dumped level such dumped material with appropriate grading equipment. (Ord. No. 765, § 3, 2-28-77; Ord. No. 844, § 1(12-33), 11-25-91) 
Sec. 13-34. - Air pollution controls; burning of combustible materials.     No person shall set fire to or burn any papers or other combustible materials in any container or on the grounds thereof except as may be permitted by county regulations at the county incinerator or at state-approved sanitary landfills. (Ord. No. 765, § 5, 2-28-77; Ord. No. 844, § 1(12-34), 11-25-91) 
Sec. 13-35. - Sanitation tax; payment thereof. (a)  The sanitation tax for the collection and disposal of waste by the city shall be as established in the city's tax ordinance, a copy of which is on file in the office of the city clerk. (b)  It shall be the duty of the city clerk to prepare and mail to each property owner a tax bill showing the amount of sanitation tax due for the calendar year. In accordance with the city's tax ordinance, a late payment penalty and an assessment of interest shall be imposed upon each account for which payment is not made within the time limits prescribed in the tax ordinance. (c)  It shall be the duty of the city clerk to prepare and maintain a complete record of the name of each owner, the address, tax map reference number, the amount due for the calendar year, and an entry showing when payment was made. This docket shall be called the sanitation tax docket. (d)  It shall be the duty of the city clerk to make an annual audit of the sanitary docket not later than December 1 of each year, and issue a fi. fa. or execution against the property served, which fi. fa. or execution shall have the same lien dignity and priority as fi. fa.'s or executions issued for city real estate taxes. (e)  On premises being assessed a sanitation tax, after the property owner has been notified that the sanitation tax is delinquent and the property owner refuses to promptly pay it, the city may refuse collection at those premises. (Ord. No. 844, § 1(12-35), 11-25-91) 
Chapter 14 - OCCUPATION AND BUSINESS TAXES, LICENSES, AND REGULATIONS[1] Footnotes: --- (1) --- Charter reference— Authority, § 1-102(20). 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
Sec. 14-1. - Display of merchandise outside of building; prohibited. (a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to display merchandise for sale, lease or rental on the exterior of any building. (b)  No city license or permit shall be issued to any person who intends to display merchandise for sale, lease or rental on the exterior of any building in violation of this section. (Code 1973, § 2-7190; Ord. No. 780, § 2, 4-26-82) 
Sec. 14-2. - Weights and measures—Selling by false representation.     Any person who, personally or by servant or agent, shall sell, offer or expose for sale any quantity of any commodity which by weight, measure or numerical count is less than the quantity which such person represents same to be shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. (Code 1973, § 2-7112) 
Sec. 14-3. - Same—Possession or sale of false instruments.     Any person who, personally or by servant or agent, or as the servant or agent of another, shall offer or expose for sale, sell or retain in such person's possession a false weight or measure, or weighing or measuring device, which has not been sealed by a state, county or city sealer of weights and measures within one (1) year, or use same in buying or selling of any commodity or thing or for hire or reward, or shall dispose of any condemned weight, measure, weighing device or measuring device contrary to law, or remove any tag placed thereon by any sealer of weights and measures, or shall, personally or by servant or agent, or as the servant or agent of another, offer or expose for sale, or have in such person's possession for the purpose of selling, any device or instrument to be used to or calculated to falsify weight or measure shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. (Code 1973, § 2-7113) 
Sec. 14-4. - Same—Standard thereof.     The standard of weights and measures as provided in O.C.G.A. § 10-2-1 et seq. shall be the standard of weights and measures for the city. (Code 1973, § 2-7114) 
Sec. 14-5. - Street vending prohibited.     No person shall place or keep any table, stall, booth or other device, implement or structure on any street or sidewalk in the city for the sale of fruit or other thing. (Code 1973, § 2-7177) 
Secs. 14-6—14-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - OCCUPATION REGISTRATION AND TAXES[2] Footnotes: --- (2) --- Editor's note— Section 1 of Ord. No. 876, adopted December 17, 1996, replaced former art. II of ch. 14 in its entirety, and enacted a new art. II to read as herein set out. Former art. II pertained to similar subject matter. For a detailed history of the provisions of former art. VII, see the Code Comparative Table. 
Sec. 14-31. - Occupation tax required; occupation tax required for business dealings in the city.     For the year 1995 and succeeding years thereafter, each person engaged in any business, trade, profession, or occupation in the city with (1) a location in the city, or (2) in the case of an out-of-state business with no location in the state but exerting substantial efforts within the city pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-13-7, or (3) in the case of real estate brokers with no location in the city but transacting business within the city shall pay an occupation tax for said business, trade, profession, or occupation; which tax and any applicable registration shall be displayed in a conspicuous place in the place of business if the taxpayer has a permanent business location in the city. If the taxpayer has no permanent business location in the city, such business tax registration shall be shown to the city treasurer or this officer's deputies or to any police officer of the city upon request. (Ord. No. 876, § 1, 12-16-96) State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. §§ 48-13-6, 48-13-7, 48-13-17. 
Sec. 14-32. - Construction of terms; definitions. (a)  Wherever the term "city" is used herein, such term shall be construed to mean the City of Avondale Estates, Georgia. Wherever the term "state" is used herein, such term shall be construed to mean the State of Georgia. (b)  As used in this article, the following terms shall have the respective meanings ascribed to them:     Administrative fee means a component of an occupation tax which approximates the reasonable cost of handling and processing the occupation tax.     Business means any person, sole proprietor, partnership, corporation, trade, profession, occupation, or other entity and the efforts or activities associated thereby for the purposes of raising revenue.     Gross receipts means the total revenue of the business or practitioner for the period, including without limitation the following: (1)  Total income without deduction for the cost of goods or expenses incurred; (2)  Gain from trading in stocks, bonds, capital assets, or instruments of indebtedness; (3)  Proceeds from commissions on the sale of property, goods, or services; (4)  Proceeds from fees for services rendered; and (5)  Proceeds from rent, interest, royalty, or dividend income.     Gross receipts shall not include the following: (1)  Sales, use, or excise tax; (2)  Sales returns, allowances, and discounts; (3)  Inter-organizational sales or transfers between or among the units of a parent-subsidiary controlled group of corporations as defined by 26 U.S.C. § 1563(a)(1), or between or among the units of a brother-sister controlled group of corporations as defined by 26 U.S.C. § 1563(a)(2); (4)  Payments made to a subcontractor or an independent agent; and (5)  Governmental and foundation grants, charitable contributions, or the interest income derived from such funds received by a nonprofit organization which employs salaried practitioners otherwise covered by this article, if such funds constitute eighty (80) percent or more of the organization's receipts.     Location of office shall not include a temporary work site which serves a single customer or project.     Occupation tax means a tax levied on persons, partnerships, corporations, or other entities for engaging in an occupation, profession, or business for revenue-raising purposes.     Regulatory fees means payments, whether designated as license fees, permit fees, or by another name, which are required by the city as an exercise of its police power and as a part of or an aid to regulation of an occupation, profession or business. The amount of a regulatory fee shall approximate the reasonable cost of actual regulatory activity performed by the city. A regulatory fee may not include an administrative fee. Development impact fees as defined by O.C.G.A. § 36-71-2(8) or other costs or conditions of zoning or land development are not regulatory fees.     Dominant line means the type of business, within a multiple-line business, that the greatest amount of income is derived from.     Person includes sole proprietors, corporations, partnerships, nonprofits, or any other form of business organization but specifically excludes charitable nonprofit organizations which utilize fifty (50) percent of their proceeds for charitable purposes.     Practitioner of profession or occupation means one who by state law requires state licensure regulating such profession or occupation. Practitioners of professions and occupations shall not include a practitioner who is an employee of a business if the business pays an occupation tax. (Ord. No. 876, § 1, 12-16-96) State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-5. 
Sec. 14-33. - Administrative and regulatory fee structure. (a)  A nonprorated, nonrefundable administrative fee of sixty dollars ($60.00) shall be required on all business and occupation tax accounts for the initial start-up, renewal, or reopening of those accounts. (b)  A regulatory fee will be imposed on those businesses listed under O.C.G.A. § 48-13-9(b). (Ord. No. 876, § 1, 12-16-96) State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. §§ 48-13-8(b), 48-13-9, 48-13-10(d). 
Sec. 14-34. - Occupation tax levied; restrictions. (a)  An occupation tax shall be levied upon those businesses and practitioners of professions and occupations with one (1) or more locations or offices in the city, and upon applicable out-of-state businesses with no location or office in the state pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-13-7, and upon real estate brokers with no location or office in the city pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-13-17, based upon the following criteria:     Gross receipts of the business or practitioner in combination with the profitability ratio for the type of business, profession, or occupation as measured by nationwide averages derived from statistics, classifications, or other information published by the U.S. Office of Management and Budget, the U.S. Internal Revenue Service, or successor agencies of the United States. (b)  Occupation tax schedule. The tax rate determined by profitability ratios in combination with gross receipts for each business, trade, profession, or occupation shall be as follows and will be developed and updated from time to time by the city. Tax Class Profit Range Tax Rate Percent 1 00.00—00.49 0.03 2 00.50—00.99 0.04 3 01.00—01.49 0.05 4 01.50—01.99 0.06 5 02.00—02.49 0.07 6 02.50—02.99 0.08 7 03.00—03.49 0.09 8 03.50—03.99 0.10 9 04.00—04.49 0.11 10 04.50—04.99 0.12 11 05.00—05.49 0.13 12 05.50—05.99 0.14 13 06.00—06.49 0.15 14 06.50—06.99 0.16 15 07.00—07.49 0.17 16 07.50—07.99 0.18 17 08.00—08.49 0.19 18 08.50—08.99 0.20 19 09.00—09.49 0.21 20 09.50—09.99 0.22 21 10.00—10.49 0.23 22 10.50—10.99 0.24 23 11.00 and up 0.25  (c)  The city shall not require the payment of more than one (1) occupational tax for each location that a business or practitioner shall have nor shall the city require a business to pay an occupational tax for more than one hundred (100) percent of the gross receipts. (d)  The city shall not require an occupation tax on those receipts that were taxed by occupation tax in other localities or states. (e)  Real estate brokers, agents, or companies whose principal and branch offices are located outside the city shall pay an occupation tax to the city based upon gross receipts derived from real estate transactions with respect to property located in the city pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-13-17. (f)  Out-of-state businesses with no location in Georgia shall be assessed occupation taxes based on the gross receipts of the business as defined in O.C.G.A. § 14-13-7 (see section 13-5 of this article) which are reasonably attributed to sales or services in the state of Georgia. (g)  For purposes of this section, prima facie evidence of gross receipts generated during any period shall be a copy of the business' federal income tax return or an affidavit of the business' accounting firm. (Ord. No. 876, § 1, 12-16-96) State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. §§ 48-13-7, 48-13-10, 48-13-13, 48-13-14, 48-13-17. 
Sec. 14-35. - Paying occupation tax of business with no location in the state.     Registration and assessment of an occupation tax is hereby imposed on those businesses and practitioners of professions with no location or office in the state of Georgia if the business' largest dollar volume of business in Georgia is in the City of Avondale Estates and the business or practitioner: (1)  Has one (1) or more employees or agents who exert substantial efforts within the city for the purpose of soliciting business or serving customers or clients; or (2)  Owns personal or real property which generates income and which is located within the city. (Ord. No. 876, § 1, 12-16-96) State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-7. 
Sec. 14-36. - Registration of name of business; more than one line of business; payment of taxes required. (a)  No person shall be engaged in, pursue, or carry on any business within the city in any manner without having registered the name of the business with the city treasurer and either paid the taxes as provided by this article or produced evidence of occupational tax payment to another jurisdiction. (b)  At the time of business registration, such person shall also identify to the city treasurer the line or lines of business that the business conducts. Classification of businesses for occupation tax purposes shall be based on the dominant line of business conducted. (c)  Each separate business trade name shall be subject to the provisions of this article and shall fully comply with all city code requirements before engaging in, pursuing, or carrying on any business within the city. (Ord. No. 876, § 1, 12-16-96) State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-12. 
Sec. 14-37. - Number of businesses considered to be operating in the city.     Where a person conducts business at more than one (1) fixed location or has multiple business trade names, each location or place and each trade name shall be considered to be separate for the purpose of occupation tax and the gross receipts of each will be returned on a form furnished by the city in accordance with the provisions of this article. (Ord. No. 876, § 1, 12-16-96) 
Sec. 14-38. - Professionals. (a)  Practitioners of professions as described in O.C.G.A. § 48-13-9(c)(1) through (18) shall elect as their entire occupation tax one (1) of the following: (1)  The occupation tax based on gross receipts combined with profitability ratios as set forth in this article. (2)  A fee of four hundred dollars ($400.00). Such fee is per practitioner and applies to each person in the business who qualifies as a practitioner under the state's regulatory guidelines and framework who is licensed by the state to provide the service, such tax to be paid at the practitioner's office or location. Practitioners paying according to this paragraph shall pay the administrative fee and the fee per practitioner and shall not be required to provide information relating to gross receipts of the business or practitioner. (b)  This election is to be made on an annual basis and must be done by February 1 of each year. (c)  Any practitioner whose office is maintained by and who is employed in practice exclusively by the United States, the state, a municipality or county of the state, or instrumentalities of the United States, the state, or a municipality or county of the state shall not be required to obtain a license or pay an occupation tax for that practice. (Ord. No. 876, § 1, 12-16-96) State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. §§ 48-13-10(f), 48-13-13(3). 
Sec. 14-39. - Business classifications for determining tax levy. (a)  For the purpose of this article, every person engaged in business requiring the payment of occupational taxes shall be classified in accordance to the major line of business as defined in the Standard Industrial Classification (SIC) Manual, Office of Management and Budget; and profitability classes shall be assigned in accordance with Statistics of Income, Business Income Tax Returns, United States Treasury Department, Internal Revenue Service. The city treasurer shall review assignment of businesses to profitability classes on a biennial basis and shall administratively reassign businesses as necessary to the then most accurate profitability class. (b)  Classifications by business profitability are incorporated herein by reference and adopted for use in the application of this article. All separate businesses engaged in more than one (1) business activity shall be classified on the basis of their dominant business activity at each location where business is done; except, that a person whose dominant business activity is legally exempt as defined by this article shall be classified according to such person's principal subsidiary business, if any, which is subject to the levy and assessment of occupation taxes. (c)  The occupation tax shall be determined by applying the business' gross receipts returned to the city to the business' profitability classification established for each business type. (d)  A copy of the business classifications shall be maintained in the office of the city clerk and shall be available for inspection by all interested persons. (Ord. No. 876, § 1, 12-16-96) State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-10. 
Sec. 14-40. - Purpose and scope of tax.     The occupation tax levied herein is for revenue purposes only and is not for regulatory purposes, nor is the payment of the tax made a condition precedent to the practice of any such profession, trade, or calling. The occupation tax only applies to those businesses and occupations which are covered by the provisions of O.C.G.A. §§ 48-13-5 to 48-13-26. All other applicable businesses and occupations are taxed by the local government pursuant to the pertinent general and/or local law and ordinance. (Ord. No. 876, § 1, 12-16-96) 
Sec. 14-41. - When tax due and payable; effect of transacting business when tax delinquent. (a)  Each such occupation tax shall be for the calendar year 1995 and succeeding calendar years thereafter unless otherwise specifically provided. Said registration and occupation tax for businesses continuing from the preceding year shall be due and payable January 1 of each year and shall be considered delinquent if not paid by March 15 of each year. The failure to pay the occupational taxes and administrative fees within ninety (90) days after January 1 shall subject such delinquent business to a ten (10) percent penalty of the amount of tax/or fee due. Such penalty shall be assessed in full on April 1 of the tax year. (b)  In the event that any person commences business on any date after January 1 in any year, the registration and occupational tax shall be due and payable on the date of the commencement of the business. A ten (10) percent penalty shall be imposed for failure to pay the registration and tax when due. (c)  The tax registration herein provided for shall be issued by the city treasurer and if any person, firm, or corporation whose duty it is to obtain a registration shall, after said registration or occupation tax becomes delinquent, transact or offer to transact in the city any of the kind of profession, trade, or calling subject to this article without having first obtained said registration, such offender shall be guilty of a violation of the City Code and, upon conviction thereof, shall be subject to the penalties as provided in the City Code. (d)  In addition to the above remedies, the city treasurer may proceed to collect in the same manner as provided by law for tax executions. (Ord. No. 876, § 1, 12-16-96) Editor's note— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. §§ 48-13-20, 48-13-21, 48-13-26. 
Sec. 14-42. - Allocation of gross receipts of business with multiple intra- or interstate locations. (a)  For those businesses that have multiple locations inside and outside of the city where the gross receipts can be allocated to each location, the gross receipts used to determine the occupation tax assessed will be those gross receipts attributed to each city location. Where the dollar amount of gross receipts attributed locally cannot be determined in those businesses with multiple locations, the total gross receipts will be divided by the total number of locations in the city and elsewhere and allocated to those locations. Upon request, the business or practitioner with a location or office situated in more than one (1) jurisdiction shall provide to the city the following: (1)  Financial information necessary to allocate the gross receipts of the business or practitioner; and (2)  Information relating to the allocation of the business' or practitioner's gross receipts by other local governments. (b)  Where the business has locations outside of the city and taxation is levied for a criteria other than gross receipts in the other local governments, the city shall not assess more than the allotted share of gross receipts for the local operation. (Ord. No. 876, § 1, 12-16-96) State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-14. 
Sec. 14-43. - Casual and isolated transactions. (a)  Nothing in this article shall be interpreted to require any person who may engage in casual or isolated commercial transactions, where they involve only personal assets and are not the principal occupation of the individual, to pay occupational tax therefor. (b)  Street vendor, transient vendor, or flea market vendor activities shall not be considered to be casual and isolated business transactions and shall be required to comply with the provisions of this article. (Ord. No. 876, § 1, 12-16-96) 
Sec. 14-44. - Exemption on grounds that business is operated for charitable purpose. (a)  No business on which a business registration or occupation tax is levied by this article shall be exempt from said registration or tax on the ground that such business is operated for a charitable purpose, unless fifty (50) percent or more of the entire proceeds from said business are devoted to such purpose. (b)  Notwithstanding any exemption from payment of city occupation taxes, an exempt person or business shall comply with the same laws and regulations as are required of other registered businesses. (Ord. No. 876, § 1, 12-16-96)
