and (17)  Such other provisions as the city reasonably determines are necessary or appropriate to permit the city to manage its streets or ensure compliance with the franchise or revocable license, to the extent not prohibited by law. (b)  The city manager shall make available to any applicant a model franchise or revocable license, as applicable, containing the terms and conditions the city seeks to impose pursuant to this article. The city manager shall have the right to modify from time to time such model franchise or revocable license, so long as such modifications are consistent with this ordinance and applicable law. (Ord. No. 0110, § 1, 12-10-01) 
Sec. 14-429. - Revocation of revocable license.     The revocable license shall be revocable at any time by the city for cause, or if the revocable license is for the provision of private telecommunications services or facility services, for the city's convenience. The revocable license, together with all revocable licenses granted to the applicant or affiliated persons, shall not authorize the occupation and use of more than five hundred (500) linear feet of specifically identified streets, unless the use or occupation of the streets does not involve the offering or provision of telecommunications services by the grantee, any affiliated persons or any other persons to or from any person or location in the city, or unless the use or occupation of the street is for the provision of facility services. (Ord. No. 0110, § 1, 12-10-01) 
Secs. 14-430—14-450. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 
Sec. 14-451. - Severability.     If any section, subsection, sentence, clause, phrase, or other portion of this ordinance is, for any reason, declared invalid, in whole or in part, by any court, agency, commission, legislative body or other authority of competent jurisdiction, such portion shall be deemed a separate, distinct and independent portion. Such declaration shall not affect the validity of the remaining portions hereof, which other portions shall continue in full force and effect. (Ord. No. 0110, § 1, 12-10-01) 
Sec. 14-452. - Delegation.     Consistent with applicable law, the board of mayor and commissioners shall have the right to delegate and redelegate, and to revoke any such delegation or redelegation, from time to time, any of its rights or obligations under this ordinance to any body, organization or official. Any such delegation, redelegation or revocation, no matter how often made, shall not be deemed an amendment to this ordinance or to require the consent of any applicant for a franchise or revocable license or grantee. The board may also establish and appoint one (1) or more advisory boards, with such duration and such number of members as the board shall determine, to advise it on such matters which are the subject of this ordinance. (Ord. No. 0110, § 1, 12-10-01) 
Sec. 14-453. - Application to existing telecommunications systems and providers of telecommunications services and private telecommunications services.     This ordinance shall not be retroactively applied to franchises for the operation of telecommunications systems used to provide telecommunications services existing on the effective date of the ordinance, but shall apply to any renewal or extension of such franchises. (Ord. No. 0110, § 1, 12-10-01) 
Sec. 14-454. - Applicability of other ordinances.     All ordinances or parts of ordinances in conflict with this ordinance are hereby repealed. (Ord. No. 0110, § 1, 12-10-01) 
Sec. 14-455. - Effective date.     This ordinance shall become effective 10 December 2001 immediately upon approval by the Board of Mayor and Commissioners of the City of Avondale Estates. (Ord. No. 0110, § 1, 12-10-01) 
Chapter 15 - PARKS AND RECREATION 
Sec. 15-1. - Lake Avondale—Use restricted. (a)  All dogs present at Lake Avondale must display a current license and be restrained on a leash held by a person competent to maintain control. (b)  It shall be unlawful for any person or dog to swim in Lake Avondale. (c)  No watercraft shall be allowed in Lake Avondale without the express permission of the city manager. (Ord. No. 16-08, § 1, 12-12-16) 
Sec. 15-2. - Reserved. Editor's note— Ord. No. 17-01, § adopted April 24, 2017, repealed § 15-2, which pertained to Lake Avondale permit required; regulations and derived from Code 1973, §§ 2-759, 2-760; and Ord. No. 759, § 1, adopted October 28, 1974. 
Sec. 15-3. - Willis park and playground. (a)  Park hours are from 7:00 a.m. until sundown. It shall be unlawful to be present in Willis park outside of such hours. (b)  All dogs in Willis park must display a current license and be restrained on a leash held by a person competent to maintain control. (Ord. No. 16-08, § 2, 12-12-16) 
Sec. 15-4. - Alcoholic beverages.     No person shall serve, consume, or transport in open containers any alcoholic beverage within a city park or recreation facility, except during city-sponsored concerts and dances held in a city park or recreation facility. 
Sec. 15-5. - Motor vehicles in parks.     No person shall operate a motorized vehicle of any kind or nature in or on any park or other area owned or operated by the city for recreation purposes; provided, however, that this section shall not apply to vehicles used for maintenance purposes by the city. 
Sec. 15-6. - Gazebo at Lake Avondale; pavilion at Dartmouth Avenue Park; reservations; fees. (a)  The city may reserve for a reasonable period of time the gazebo located at Lake Avondale and the picnic pavilion at the park and playground located on Dartmouth Avenue for purposes of group activities of city residents, their children, and guests upon submittal of an application and approval by the city manager or his designee. Use of these areas shall be free to residents and members of their immediate families; nonresidents may only rent the gazebo or pavilion as guests of a resident who shall sign the application as the sponsor. A deposit, in addition to any fee, shall be required for residents and sponsored nonresident guests. Following the group activity, the city manager or his designee shall inspect the location and, provided there is no damage and clean-up of the facilities is satisfactory, the deposit shall be returned. If damage exceeds the deposit, the resident signing the application shall pay for any excess damages upon notice from the city. In the event of a cancellation, refunds for the rental fee, less a processing fee, shall be issued after written notification of the cancellation is received by the city. (b)  The rental fee for sponsored nonresident guests, amount of deposit for residents and sponsored nonresident guests, and the cancellation processing fee shall be as specified on the application form. (c)  Rules and regulations pertaining to the use of the gazebo and the pavilion shall be specified on the application form. 
Chapter 16 - PERSONNEL[1] Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Police department, § 2-60 et seq. 
Sec. 16-1. - Personnel management system.     The city personnel management system document is on file in the office of the city clerk. 
Sec. 16-2. - Retirement plan. (a)  The document entitled "A Retirement Plan for the Employees of the City of Avondale Estates, Georgia," and any amendments thereto attached to the ordinance from which this section is derived as exhibit A and comprising 62 pages, is hereby adopted as the retirement plan of the city. (b)  The document attached to the ordinance from which this section is derived as Appendix A to the retirement plan of the city and consisting of pages A-1 through A-16, is hereby adopted as the joint trust agreement for the administration of such plan by the city and the state municipal employees' benefit system. (c)  The documents referred to in subsections (a) and (b) are hereby made public records and shall be maintained by the city clerk as such and be accessible to the members of the general public at city hall during all normal business hours. (d)  The effective date of this section was fifteen (15) days after final passage in accordance with section 1-401 of the city Charter, or not earlier than January 1, 1989, whichever was later, and the effective dates of the attachments hereto shall so correspond. (Ord. No. 817, §§ 1—4, 12-15-88; Ord. No. 833, § 1, 5-29-90; Ord. No. 838, § 1, 8-26-91; Ord. No. 845, § 1, 11-25-91; Ord. No. 0305, § 1, 8-25-03) Cross reference— Social security, § 2-9 et seq. 
Sec. 16-3. - Personnel board established; term; procedures; duties. (a)  There is hereby established the personnel board of the city to consist of five (5) residents who hold no other office with and shall remain residents of the city during the term for which appointed to the personnel board. (b)  Members of the personnel board shall be appointed by resolution, with terms to be four (4) years except for the first personnel board appointed, two (2) members of which shall be appointed for one-year terms, one (1) member for a two-year term, one (1) member for a three-year term and one (1) member for a four-year term. Thereafter, all terms shall be four (4) years. (c)  The operating procedures of the personnel board shall be those set out in the personnel management system manual as the same now exists or is hereinafter amended, it being the intent hereof that the personnel board shall perform all functions previously assigned to the board of mayor and commissioners in the said personnel management system manual. (Ord. No. 9903, §§ 1—3, 5-24-99) 
Chapter 17 - STREETS AND SIDEWALKS[1] Footnotes: --- (1) --- Charter reference— Authority, § 1-102(15), (16). Cross reference— Littering public places, § 11-22 et seq. 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
Sec. 17-1. - Reference point elevations.     The base or datum plane to which all levels taken by the city shall be referred shall be that plane at or near sea level from which the following local bench marks have elevations as follows: Elevation 1,074.95 feet at east end of car stop at starting point of Clarendon Avenue rail driven between car tracks. Elevation 1,088.33 feet nail in oak tree 50 feet east of Dudley Street (now Windsor Terrace) south corner of Covington Road. Elevation 1,011.00 feet pine tree south side of bathing pool. Elevation 1,099.49 feet first floor level of Avondale Grammar School. Elevation 1,002.95 feet nail in pine tree southeast of dam. (Code 1973, § 2-7144) Editor's note— This section is included because of its historic interest. 
Sec. 17-2. - Street grades.     The word "grade" as applied to any street shall mean the elevation above sea level, as indicated, above the sidewalk, at the building line or curb line as indicated, and grades shall be fixed by resolution of the governing body on presentation of a profile which shall be known as the official profile. Official profiles shall bear endorsements of the mayor and city clerk showing the facts and dates of their approval by the governing body. No grade once established shall be changed except upon resolution by the governing body. (Code 1973, § 2-7145) 
Sec. 17-3. - Curb grades.     On streets or along hillsides where it is necessary for drainage economy to have the curb grades higher or lower than the center line of the street, the same shall be shown on the profile and the curb grade as well as the street grade shall be established. (Code 1973, § 2-7146) 
Sec. 17-4. - Street numbers.     No person shall apply a street number to or maintain on such premises without ascertaining the correct number from the city clerk and using the number so designated. (Code 1973, § 2-7199) 
Sec. 17-5. - Construction and repair of sidewalks, curbs, gutters and streets—Sidewalk construction on petition of property owner. (a)  All applications for sidewalks shall be made by petition to the governing body, signed by the property owners abutting, and the contractor shall agree therein to lay such sidewalks in accordance with the specifications prescribed by the governing body. (b)  On the granting of the petition, or on the passage of any resolution for the construction of any sidewalk, curb or gutter, the city clerk shall notify the city manager in writing, and the city manager shall have the necessary grading done as soon as possible thereafter, provided there is available cash on hand in the street fund to pay for the same. When the cash is not on hand, the governing body may require the property owners to pay for the cost of grading of such sidewalks. (c)  A permit shall then be issued in writing by the city manager, on a form provided therefor, and on which shall be printed the specifications prescribed by the governing body. No permits shall be issued to any contractor who has not previously given bond to the city in the amount required by the governing body, conditioned to indemnify the city against loss or damage, for injury to person or damage to property due to the execution of the work, and to bind said contractor to comply with the terms of this chapter. Nothing in this section shall be construed to limit the right of the city to require property owners to put down sidewalks, where in the opinion of the governing body, the public welfare requires it, but in all such cases the contractor shall be required to obtain a permit from the city manager before beginning work. (Code 1973, § 2-7153) 
Sec. 17-6. - Reserved. 
Sec. 17-7. - Construction and repair of sidewalks, curbs, gutters and streets—Apportionment of costs.     The governing body may require that the entire cost of the construction of sidewalks and curbs and three-fourths of the entire cost of gutters, when the construction of gutters is ordered by the governing body, be borne by the abutting property owners, except the alley crossings and quadrants at intersections. (Code 1973, § 2-7154) 
Sec. 17-8. - Same—Recovery of costs.     If any of the owners of the lots or properties shall refuse to build or repair such sidewalks within the time required by the notice, and agreeable thereto, the governing body, through the city manager, may contract for the construction or repair of same, and shall pay the cost thereof out of the general fund, and amounts so paid shall be a lien upon such lots or property and may be enforced by attachments at law or in equity or in the manner provided in the Charter; or the amount may be recovered against the owners by suit before any court of competent jurisdiction; and the city attorney is authorized to proceed to enforce the lien declared and fixed by the Charter and this section. (Code 1973, §§ 2-7150, 2-7155) 
Sec. 17-9. - Same—On initiative of governing body. (a)  For the purpose of securing good and substantial sidewalks in the city and securing uniformity in the construction thereof, the governing body, wherever it is deemed necessary by it for the public welfare, may require the owner of any lot or part of a lot in the city fronting upon any public street to construct and keep in repair a good and substantial sidewalk of foot pavement along the whole street frontage of such person's lots or property, and of width and material prescribed by resolution of the governing body. (b)  When so instructed by resolution by the governing body, the city clerk shall give the owners of lots written notice stating the action of the governing body, and specifically setting forth work to be done and the length of time within which the same must be done, provided that the time fixed shall not be less than twenty (20) days. (Code 1973, §§ 2-7148—2-7150, 2-7155) 
Sec. 17-10. - Paving on railroad right-of-way.     When any street occupied by the track of a railroad is about to be paved or otherwise improved, it shall be the duty of the railroad company to pave at its own expense that portion of such street lying within its right-of-way, using such materials and construction methods as shall be approved by the city manager. (Code 1973, § 2-790) 
Sec. 17-11. - Excavations; obstructions—Permit; restoration of surface. (a)  No person, except in or as incident to the exercise of rights given by franchise, shall break or dig up the grounds in any public street, way or public place or lands of the city, or erect or place thereon any staging, or place or deposit thereon any brick, stone, timber or other building material without first having obtained a permit from the city manager in writing. In all cases in which a permit may be given for excavating in or obstructing any street, the city manager shall impose such restrictions and limitations as the city manager shall see fit to make the street safe and convenient for public travel by the erection of barriers, the maintaining of lights, the removal of rubbish or otherwise. It shall also be a condition of the permit that the person so excavating any street shall cause same to be refilled and tamped, and put in as good condition as it was before being opened. In case of a permit applicable to a paved street, the earth so excavated shall be hauled away and the excavation refilled with slag or sand well tamped on which the paving shall be laid as it was before, all done to the satisfaction of the city manager. (b)  Any person making an excavation shall meet the requirements as set forth in the federal occupational safety and health regulations for construction, as adopted April 17, 1971, and each amendment thereafter, with the following exceptions: (1)  Excavations involved in the construction of a basement or foundation for a single-family residential structure are exempt from all of these requirements, with the exception that any excavation or foundation grading on which construction does not proceed within thirty (30) days shall be fenced, so as to prevent general public entrance to the building site, or filled in. However, an extension may be allowed if justified and if approved by application to the city manager. (2)  Table P-2, the line reading "ten (10) to fifteen (15) feet, likely to crack" and the column "Maximum Spacing, Vertical Feet," shall contain the number "4." (Code 1973, § 2-7142) Cross reference— Traffic and vehicles, ch. 18. 
Sec. 17-12. - Same—Bond; cash deposit.     No person shall be given a permit to excavate a street without first having executed a good and sufficient bond to the city in such amount as required by the governing body, conditioned to save the city harmless on account of any loss or damages resulting from excavations, and without having first deposited a sufficient amount of cash with the city treasurer as will, in the opinion of the city manager, cover the cost of restoring the street or way to its condition prior to the excavating. (Code 1973, § 2-7143) 
Sec. 17-13. - Same—Repairs.     If any street in the portion which has been so opened or dug up shall require repairing or resurfacing within a period of six (6) months after it has been so disturbed, the city manager shall give notice in writing to the person who had or was given the right to make the excavation to make such repairs therein as are necessary. If such repairs are not made within seven (7) days from the day of notification, the city manager shall proceed at once to have such repairs made and the expense of the same shall be paid by the party making the excavations. (Code 1973, § 2-7143) 
Sec. 17-14. - Reserved. 
Sec. 17-15. - Dangerous areas adjacent to streets.     All dangerous places upon private lots which are below the grade of the adjoining street shall be properly enclosed with fences or walls, and should the owner fail to so fence or wall upon being notified by the city manager, such person shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. (Code 1973, § 2-7186) 
Sec. 17-16. - Cutting curbs and gutters; driveway construction; crossing gutter, etc.; permit to cut. (a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to cut a curb or gutter or to damage any sidewalk, in constructing a sidewalk or for any other purpose, without making petition to and obtaining from the city manager a permit to do so. If a permit is granted therefor, the party securing such permit shall perform such work at such person's own expense and as specified by the city manager. (b)  No person shall be allowed to place a bridge, or other obstruction in or over any paved gutter; provided, however, that the city manager may grant a permit to any person to put in a temporary crossing over a sidewalk for the purpose of excavating on or filling in private premises or hauling in building materials upon such conditions as may be necessary to protect such sidewalk from damage while such work is going on, to be constructed and maintained at the expense of the person to whom such permit is granted. (Code 1973, § 2-7182) 
Sec. 17-17. - Roof gutters.     All structures that are built so as to project over the sidewalk shall be so provided with gutters that there shall be no drip upon the sidewalk. (Code 1973, § 2-7183) 
Sec. 17-18. - Drainage—Discharge of water.     No water shall be discharged from the roof of any building so as to flow across any sidewalk upon any street in which curbs or gutters or a public drain have been laid; and the conductor for such water shall be made by the owner of such building to connect with such drain, under the direction of the city manager. (Code 1973, § 2-7176) 
Sec. 17-19. - Same—Obstruction of flow of water.     No person occupying the streets or alleys of the city with such person's work or any appurtenances shall obstruct or impede the flow of water in any street, gutter, alley or drain; and when sand, mortar or other like building material shall be deposited on the streets to be used for building purposes, the contractor or builder shall provide suitable boxes or other receptacles for the same, or otherwise keep the gutter open. (Code 1973, § 2-7181) Cross reference— Buildings; construction, maintenance, and related activities, ch. 5. 
Sec. 17-20. - New streets—Privately installed.     If any person shall lay out a new addition to the city or a new street, the same shall be surveyed and opened in such manner as to conform to the streets of the city already opened and accepted, and no new streets surveyed and opened by a private person shall be considered as streets of the city, or be taken charge of by the governing body unless a plat of same with all dimensions clearly marked thereon in figures is adopted by governing body, upon the recommendation of the city manager and filed with the city manager. (Code 1973, § 2-7156) Cross reference— Subdivisions, app. B. 
Sec. 17-21. - Same—Opening by city; altering streets. (a)  Whenever the governing body shall by resolution determine that the public interest demands that any new street shall be opened within the corporate limits, or any old street should be extended, widened or straightened, and the owners of the land through which same shall pass require damages, the governing body shall, by resolution, proceed to condemn land for the same and provide damages therefor in the manner set forth in the charter and in O.C.G.A. § 22-1-6 et seq. The notices required by law shall be served by any police officer of the city, and such publications and other notices shall be made by the city clerk. The names of any number of nonresident owners may be inserted in one advertisement. (b)  Whenever the funds to settle the damages assessed as provided by law shall be in the hands of the treasurer for the benefit of the owner of the land, the governing body may condemn the land, by ordinance, and after allowing the property owners five (5) days' time in which to open such street, may order such street to be opened, and the same shall be and become a public thoroughfare. Any person failing or refusing to open such street shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-8 for each such day of such failure or refusal. (Code 1973, §§ 2-7157, 2-7158) 
Sec. 17-22. - Utility apparatus—Permit to install. (a)  No person opening a public utility or furnishing public service shall locate any pole, wire, conduit, pipe or other apparatus without first having obtained a permit from the city manager in writing; one (1) copy shall be filed with the city clerk. The permit and installation shall be subject to the publication "Utility Accommodation and Standards," 1988, and each amendment thereafter, on file in the city clerk's office. (b)  Any permit granted hereunder shall be subject to the right of the city, free of charge, to place its fire alarm, telegraph or other electric lines upon the poles or through the conduits so permitted to be maintained; and to the right of the city to license the location of wires or lines by any other person upon such poles or through such conduits upon the payment or tender to the owner thereof a reasonable compensation to be determined by the parties. (c)  The city manager shall not grant permits for more than one (1) line of poles on any street, unless it is impossible to use two (2) or more lines of wires on the same pole, and shall use every endeavor to locate poles where they will be least objectionable. (d)  The number of poles permitted in each block shall be determined by the city manager. (e)  All utility wiring involving new construction shall be located underground. (Code 1973, §§ 2-7151, 2-7159, 2-7161) 
Sec. 17-23. - Same—Removal.     Any such person, at such person's own expense, shall remove such person's poles or conduits to other suitable locations whenever ordered to do so by the governing body. (Code 1973, § 2-7160) 
Sec. 17-24. - Placement of sharp objects.     No person shall throw, scatter, drop or place or cause or procure to be thrown, scattered, dropped or placed within the city any glass, tacks, nails, pieces of metal or any other substance likely to damage tires on any vehicle. (Code 1973, § 2-7175) Cross reference— Traffic and vehicles, ch. 18; vehicles damaging streets, § 18-8. 
Sec. 17-25. - Removal of city property.     No person shall remove or carry away any city property in any of the public streets or other public places of the city except as authorized by the city. (Code 1973, § 2-7170) 
Sec. 17-26. - Fires in streets.     No person shall make any fire in any street for any purpose. (Code 1973, § 2-7166) 
Sec. 17-27. - Apertures in streets or sidewalks—Permit to make.     No person shall make or cause to be made any aperture in or under any street or sidewalk for any purpose without first having obtained a permit from the city manager; and no person shall leave any aperture opened or unfastened except while actually in use with workers present. (Code 1973, § 2-7178) 
Sec. 17-28. - Same—Cellar doors.     Every cellar door opening upon the pavement shall be of iron grating, and so constructed that when shut it shall be on a level with the pavement and have its gratings running at right angles to the line of the street. No cellar door shall be permitted to extend more than five (5) feet from the wall, nor be so constructed as to open downward. (Code 1973, § 2-7179) 
Sec. 17-29. - Same—Security and repair.     Whenever the owner or occupant of any premises upon which there is a cellar, hole, area, or vault opening on the street is notified by the city that the covering of the same is insecure and dangerous, it shall be such person's duty to repair the same at once. If such person fails to do so after five (5) days' notice, it shall be the duty of the city manager to have the same repaired or placed in safe condition and collect the cost thereof from the owner or occupant. No cellarway or other hole of like nature opening in or upon the public streets or sidewalks shall be allowed to be open when not in use. All such means of access to buildings shall be provided with a substantial lock. (Code 1973, § 2-7185) 
Sec. 17-30. - Projections upon sidewalk—Bay windows; steps.     No person shall build or erect any bay window or steps to project upon any sidewalk from the first story of any building. (Code 1973, § 2-7189) 
Sec. 17-31. - Same—Awnings.     No awning frames shall have supports placed on sidewalks or in parkways, but swinging awnings may be constructed and securely attached to the buildings extending not beyond the curbline, the rods of which shall be at least seven and one-half (7½) feet above the sidewalk, and the flaps and aprons of such awnings shall clear the sidewalk at least seven (7) feet. (Code 1973, § 2-7188) 
Sec. 17-32. - Mailboxes.     It shall be unlawful for any person to move a mailbox currently attached to any building to any street. (Code 1973, § 2-7196) 
Sec. 17-33. - Protection of sidewalk, curb and gutter.     No substance of a greater weight than four hundred (400) pounds shall be handled upon the sidewalk, curbing or guttering of the city, unless such sidewalk, curbing or guttering be sufficiently covered with wood so as to protect it from damage. (Code 1973, § 2-7192) Cross reference— Traffic and vehicles, ch. 18. 
Sec. 17-34. - Use of the public right-of-way.     It shall be unlawful for any person to place or maintain a dumpster, pod-type storage container, construction materials and equipment, landscape materials and equipment, or portable toilet on the public streets, sidewalks or other public right-of-way within the city limits, unless the city manager or his designee makes a finding that the placement of any of the items set forth in this section on private property would be impractical due to the topography or other physical condition of the land and to set conditions as to the use and placement of such items on public streets, sidewalks or other rights-of-way, in which case any such item may be located on the public street, sidewalk or other public right-of-way with the city limits, as designated in such finding; provided, however, in the event of such finding by the city manager of his designee, no such item set forth in this section, with the exception of portable toilets, shall remain on the public street, sidewalk or other public right-of-way for more than three (3) days in any continuous thirty (30) day period. (Ord. No. 0505, § 1, 7-25-05) 
Sec. 17-35. - Maintenance of refuse receptacles, pod type storage containers and portable toilets.     Any person using or in possession of a refuse receptacle (garbage can or dumpster), pod-type storage container or portable toilet shall maintain such refuse receptacle, pod-type storage container or portable toilet free of graffiti. (Ord. No. 0505, § 1, 7-25-05) 
Sec. 17-36. - Requirement to have portable toilets. (a)  Any person issued a building permit* in the city limits of Avondale Estates for construction or renovation of property, where said construction or renovation is valued at a cost estimate exceeding ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00), is required to have a portable toilet to serve their property from the date the construction or renovation begins until the work being performed receives final approval by the issuing authority, unless such person shall sign a statement that all persons performing work pursuant to said permit shall be allowed to use a toilet located on the property. (b)  Portable toilets must have a working key or combination locking mechanism and shall be locked when not in use. (Ord. No. 0505, § 1, 7-25-05) *Note— Section 4 of Ord. No. 0505 states that this ordinance shall apply to all permits issued after July 25, 2005. For permits issued prior to July 25, 2005, the effective date shall be Oct. 1, 2005. 
Secs. 17-37—17-39. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - TREE BOARD; TREES[2] Footnotes: --- (2) --- Editor's note— Ord. No. 08-05, §§ 1, 2, adopted Oct. 27, 2009, repealed the former Art. II, §§ 17-40—17-51, and enacted a new Art. II as set out herein. The former Art. II pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 798, 11-26-84; Ord. No. 857, 9-27-93. See also the Code Comparative Table. 
Sec. 17-40. - Definitions.     The following words, terms and phrases when used in this article shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:     Park trees means trees, shrubs, bushes and other woody vegetation in public parks having individual names, and all areas owned by the city, or to which the public has free access as a park.     Street trees means trees, shrubs, bushes, and all other woody vegetation on land lying between property lines on both sides of all streets and other public ways within the city. (Ord. No. 08-05, § 2, 10-27-08) Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 17-41. - Tree board—Created and established; membership. (a)  Created and established. There is hereby created and established a city tree board. (b)  Appointment of members. The members of the board shall be appointed by the mayor. (c)  Term of office. The terms of the members of the city tree board shall be two (2) years. (d)  Compensation. Members of the city tree board shall serve without compensation. (Ord. No. 08-05, § 2, 10-27-08) 
Sec. 17-42. - Same—Duties and responsibilities.     It shall be the responsibility of the city tree board to study, investigate, counsel and advise the city manager who will administer a written plan for the care, preservation, pruning, planting, replanting, removal or disposition of trees and shrubs in parks, along streets and in other public areas. Such plan will be presented annually to the governing body and upon its acceptance and approval shall constitute the official comprehensive city tree plan. The city tree board, when requested by the governing body shall consider, investigate, make findings, report and recommend upon any special matter or question coming within the scope of its work. (Ord. No. 08-05, § 2, 10-27-08) 
Sec. 17-43. - Same—Organization.     The city tree board shall choose its own officers and make its own rules and regulations. A majority of the members shall be a quorum for the transaction of business. (Ord. No. 08-05, § 2, 10-27-08) 
Sec. 17-44. - Review of city manager's acts.     The governing body shall have the right to review the conduct, acts and decisions of the city manager relative to his/her actions that relate to this article. (Ord. No. 08-05, § 2, 10-27-08) 
Sec. 17-45. - City manager—Interference therewith.     It shall be unlawful for any person to prevent or interfere with the city manager or his designee(s), while engaging in the planting, cultivating, mulching, pruning, spraying or removing of any street tree, park tree, or tree on private grounds, as authorized in this article. Any person(s) found to be in violation of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. (Ord. No. 08-05, § 2, 10-27-08) 
Sec. 17-46. - Official tree species list.     No tree may be planted on city property without prior written permission from the city manager. Sec. 17-47. - Planting, maintaining, removing trees, plants.     The city shall have the right to plant, prune, maintain and remove trees, plants and shrubs within the lines of all streets, alleys, avenues, lanes, squares and public grounds, as may be necessary to ensure public safety or to preserve or enhance the symmetry and beauty of such public grounds. The city tree board may recommend the removal of any tree or part thereof which is in an unsafe condition or which by reason of its nature is injurious to sewers, electric power lines, water lines, or other public improvements, or is affected with any injurious fungus, insect or other pest. (Ord. No. 08-05, § 2, 10-27-08) 
Sec. 17-48. - Tree topping.     It shall be unlawful for any person or city department to top any street tree, park tree, or other tree on public property except as expressly permitted by this section. Topping is defined as the severe cutting back of limbs to stubs larger than three (3) inches in diameter within the tree's crown to such a degree as to remove the normal canopy and disfigure the tree. Trees severely damaged by storms or other causes, or certain trees under utility wires or other obstruction, where other pruning practices are impractical, may be excepted from this section at the determination of the city manager. Any person(s) found to be in violation of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. (Ord. No. 08-05, § 2, 10-27-08) 
Sec. 17-49. - Pruning and removal of vegetation. (a)  Every owner of any tree overhanging any street or right-of-way within the city shall prune the branches so that such branches shall not obstruct the light from any street lamp or interfere with visibility of any traffic control device or sign, or obstruct the view of any street intersection. (b)  There shall be a clear space of eight (8) feet above the surface of the street or sidewalk. (c)  Such owners shall remove all dead, diseased or dangerous trees, or broken or decayed limbs which constitute a hazard to the safety of the public or harbor insects or diseases which constitute a potential threat to other trees within the city. (Ord. No. 08-05, § 2, 10-27-08) 
Sec. 17-50. - Removal on private property. (a)  The city shall have the right to cause the removal or pruning of trees, limbs or shrubs as necessary as indicated is section 17-49. (b)  The city manager or his designee shall notify, in writing, the owners of such trees. (c)  Removal shall be done by such owners at their own expense within ten (10) days of written notification. (d)  In the event of failure of owners to comply with such provisions, the city shall have the authority to remove or prune such trees and shrubs and add the cost of removal to the property tax of the owner. (Ord. No. 08-05, § 2, 10-27-08) 
Sec. 17-51. - Removal of stumps.     All stumps of street and park trees shall be removed below the surface of the ground so that the top of the stump shall not project above the surface of the ground. (Ord. No. 08-05, § 2, 10-27-08) 
Secs. 17-52—17-59. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - LAKE AVONDALE ADVISORY BOARD 
Sec. 17-60. - Definitions.     The following words, terms and phrases when used in this article shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning.     Lake area shall mean all public land lying between the easterly curb line of Berkeley Road, the northerly curb line of Wiltshire Drive, the westerly curb line of Lakeshore Drive and the southerly curb line of Lakeview Place, plus the area commonly known as the "bird sanctuary" south of Wiltshire Drive as it parallels the dam of Lake Avondale.     Trees means trees, shrubs, bushes, and all other woody vegetation within the lake area. (Ord. No. 10-14, § 1, 8-23-04) 
Sec. 17-61. - Lake Avondale Advisory Board—Created and established; membership. (a)  Created and established. There is hereby created and established a Lake Avondale Advisory Board. (b)  Appointment of members. The five (5) members of the board shall be appointed by the board of mayor and commissioners. All members shall be citizens of the City of Avondale Estates. (c)  Qualification of members. At least two of the members of Lake Avondale Advisory Board shall have either education and/or experience in watershed/lake management, natural resource management, environmental management, environmental engineering or a related field as determined by the governing body. (d)  Restricted members. No more than two (2) of the members of Lake Avondale Advisory Board may reside within view of Lake Avondale. (e)  Term of office. The terms of the members of Lake Avondale Advisory Board shall be two (2) years and shall be appointed in staggered terms so that not more than two (2) members of Lake Avondale Advisory Board shall have their initial terms expire simultaneously. (f)  Compensation. Members of the Lake Avondale Advisory Board shall serve without compensation. (Ord. No. 10-14, § 1, 8-23-04) 
Sec. 17-62. - Same—Duties and responsibilities.     It shall be the duty and responsibility of the Lake Avondale Advisory Board to: (a)  Study, investigate, counsel and advise the city manager in writing on any matter which affects the aesthetics, visibility or user friendliness of the lake area, it being understood Lake Avondale is a primary recreational resource of the city. (b)  Exercise the sole authority to recommend preservation, pruning, planting, replanting, removal or disposition of trees in the lake area, including memorial plantings. (c)  In conformity with section 17-49, ensure an eight (8) feet clear space be maintained between the ground and any tree limb in the lake area, where practicable, and eliminate any tree which unduly restricts fishing access or visibility so that the full vista of Lake Avondale may be enjoyed by residents. (d)  Investigate, make findings, report and recommend regarding any special matter or question coming within the scope of its work when requested by the governing body. (e)  Advise the city manager regarding any matter which either affects water quality or the fish or waterfowl populations of Lake Avondale. (Ord. No. 10-14, § 1, 8-23-04) 
Sec. 17-63. - Duty of city manager to comply; exceptions.     The city manager shall comply with any written recommendation of the Lake Avondale Advisory Board within the scope of its work unless within ten (10) days of its receipt the city manager notifies the Lake Avondale Advisory Board in writing giving reasons why its recommendation cannot be implemented. Should lack of funding be a reason for any such denial, the city manager shall either request a supplemental budget appropriation or include a sufficient funding request in the next annual budget submitted to the board of mayor and commissioners to cover such recommendations. Absent written notification as set out above, the city manager shall comply with all written recommendations of the Lake Avondale Advisory Board in accordance with their terms within sixty (60) days where practicable. (Ord. No. 10-14, § 1, 8-23-04) 
Sec. 17-64. - Organization.     The Lake Avondale Advisory Board shall choose its own officers and make its own rules and regulations. A majority of the members shall be a quorum for the transaction of business. (Ord. No. 10-14, § 1, 8-23-04) 
Sec. 17-65. - Planting in lake area prohibited without written permission.     No tree, including memorial plantings, shall be planted in the lake area without the written permission of the Lake Avondale Advisory Board. (Ord. No. 10-14, § 1, 8-23-04) 
Chapter 18 - TRAFFIC AND VEHICLES[1] Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Scattering of articles on streets from vehicles, § 11-30; barricades, § 17-11; placement of sharp objects on streets, § 17-24; placing heavy objects on sidewalks, § 17-33. 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
Sec. 18-1. - Uniform Rules of the Road and definitions; adopted by reference, penalty for violation. (a)  Pursuant to O.C.G.A. §§ 40-6-372—40-6-376, all provisions of O.C.G.A. tit. 40, ch. 6 (O.C.G.A. § 40-6-1 et seq.), known as the Uniform Rules of the Road, and the definitions contained in O.C.G.A. § 40-1-1 are hereby adopted as and for the traffic regulations of the city with like effect as if recited in this chapter. (b)  Any future amendments or repeal of a provision of the chapter of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated containing the Uniform Rules of the Road or the definitions referenced in this chapter shall so amend or repeal the pertinent provisions of this chapter without any action by the governing body of the city being required. (c)  Unless another penalty is expressly provided by law, every person convicted of a violation of any provision of this chapter shall be punished as provided in section 1-8. (Ord. No. 758, § 2, 10-28-74) State Law reference— Adoption of rules of the road by reference, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-372 et seq. 
Sec. 18-2. - Chapter does not affect property rights.     Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to prevent the owner of real property used by the public for purposes of vehicular travel by permission of the owner, and not as a matter of right, from prohibiting such use, or from requiring other or different or additional conditions than those specified herein, or otherwise regulating such use as may seem best to such owner. State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-8. 
Sec. 18-3. - Applicability to public officers and employees.     The provisions of this chapter applicable to the drivers of vehicles upon the streets and highways shall apply to the drivers of all vehicles owned or operated by the United States, any state or any county, city, town, district, or any other political subdivision of the state, except as otherwise provided. 
Sec. 18-4. - Owners or persons directing drivers of vehicles not to permit violation.     It is unlawful for the owner or any other person employing or otherwise directing the driver of any vehicle to require or knowingly permit the operation of that vehicle upon a street or highway in any manner contrary to this chapter. 
Sec. 18-5. - Use of vehicle without consent of the owner.     It shall be unlawful for any person to take, use, or operate any motor vehicle or motorcycle upon the public streets and highways of the city without the permission of the owner thereof. 
Sec. 18-6. - Obstructions to right-of-way. (a)  Prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to obstruct the right-of-way of any public road, street, or other easement in the city by placing or maintaining thereon any obstruction, whether it is in the nature of shrubbery, signs, fences or whatever, which interferes with the clear view of motorists or the free passage of pedestrians thereon. (b)  Notice to remove. Wherever any obstruction prohibited by subsection (a) of this section has been placed and is being maintained, the city manager or his designee shall notify in writing the owner of the obstruction and the owner of the land abutting the right-of-way where the obstruction is found and also the person in possession of the property. Such notice shall state the nature of the obstruction and the fact that the obstruction is an interference with the clear view of motorists or the free passage of pedestrians and that it shall be removed with ten (10) days from the date of the notice. (c)  Issuance of summons upon failure to remove. Whenever the person so notified as provided by subsection (b) of this section fails or refuses to remove the obstruction within the time allowed in the written notice, the city manager or his designee shall issue a citation to this person to appear in municipal court on a day certain to stand trial for the violation. (d)  Continued violations; issuance of summons without notice. If upon conviction for the first offense, the person continues to refuse to remove the obstruction, each day that it remains intact shall constitute a new violation of subsection (a) of this section for which the city manager or his designee shall issue a citation without the necessity of issuing additional written notice. 
Sec. 18-7. - Abatement of unsafe vehicles as nuisances.     The use of any vehicle on the streets is a nuisance where by reason of a defect in such vehicle the driving thereof on the streets constitutes a menace or a hazard to the life, safety or property of others. The members of the police department are charged with the duty of enforcing this section. Where it is shown that any vehicle on the street is dangerous or likely to cause injury to person or damage to property, the police shall have authority to order the driver or owner thereof to immediately remove such vehicle from the streets or, if the vehicle can be made safe by repair, to repair it. Failure to remove the vehicle from the streets immediately, or to continue to drive the vehicle on the streets shall be an offense. If on the hearing of such failure to remove the vehicle from the streets as ordered by the police or to continue to drive such vehicle on the streets, the municipal judge sees from the evidence that such vehicle is a nuisance, within the meaning of this section, such judge shall enter an order so declaring and stating the terms of the abatement and the conditions under which such vehicle may be driven on the streets. (Code 1973, App. II, § 2) State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 40-8-7; nuisances, O.C.G.A. § 41-1-1 et seq. 
Sec. 18-8. - Vehicle damaging streets.     No vehicle shall be operated on the streets with cleated wheels, or so constructed in other ways as to damage the street. (Code 1973, App. II, § 3) Cross reference— Placing sharp objects on street, § 17-24. 
Sec. 18-9. - Use of coasters, roller skates and similar devices restricted. (a)  No person upon roller skates, or riding in or by means of any coaster, toy vehicle, or similar device, shall go upon any roadway except while crossing a street on a crosswalk and when so crossing such person shall be granted all of the rights and shall be subject to all of the duties applicable to pedestrians. This section shall not apply upon any street while set aside as a play street as authorized by ordinance of this city. (b)  It shall be unlawful for persons so skating or riding to gather in crowds, or to create noise or be guilty of any disorderly conduct, or to take hold of or hang on to any automobile or other vehicle, or in any way to interfere with the natural progress of vehicles along and in the streets of the city, or for two (2) or more persons to join hands while skating on the sidewalks. Any persons so skating or riding shall give right-of-way to, and in no way interfere with, persons walking on the sidewalks. (c)  Any persons violating any provisions of this section shall be subject to the penalties provided in section 1-8; provided, however, that any such offender under the age of seventeen (17) years shall be dealt with as provided by the law creating juvenile courts. The parent of any child and the guardian of the person of any ward shall not authorize or knowingly permit any such child or ward to violate any of the provisions of this section. (Code 1973, App. II, § 5) 
Sec. 18-10. - Unlawful riding.     No person shall ride on any vehicle upon any portion thereof not designed or intended for the use of passengers. This provision shall not apply to an employee engaged in the necessary discharge of a duty, or to persons riding within truck bodies in space intended for merchandise. (Code 1973, App. II, § 8) State Law reference— Obstructing driver's view, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-242. 
Sec. 18-11. - Persons entering or leaving moving vehicle.     No person shall board or alight from any vehicle while such vehicle is in motion. (Code 1973, App. II, § 11) 
Sec. 18-12. - Parades and marches. (a)  Definition. The word "parade" or "march" means an assemblage of persons, groups of persons, vehicles, bands, floats, or devices gathered together in public with some circumstance of show. It shall not include a funeral procession or an assemblage of public officials gathered for any purpose in the public interest. (b)  Prohibited without permit. It shall be unlawful for any person or group of persons to hold or participate in a parade in the city without first securing a parade permit from the city. (c)  Application for permit. To obtain a parade permit, the person or group of persons desiring to hold a parade shall file an application with the city manager at least five (5) days before the date of the scheduled parade. The application shall contain the following information: (1)  The name, address, and telephone number, both business and residential, of the applicant. (2)  The date and hours when the parade is to be held. (3)  The location and time of the point of assembly. (4)  The parade route. (5)  The anticipated number of marching persons. (6)  The anticipated number and types of motorized and other vehicles and devices. (7)  The number of bands and floats in the parade. (8)  A statement by the applicant agreeing to assume all responsibility for the mechanical condition of each vehicle in the parade and all damages caused by mechanical failure of any vehicle, float, or other device in the parade. (d)  Issuance of permit; conditions. The issuance of the permit by the city manager shall give full consideration to the condition and width of the streets or sidewalks along the proposed route; the nature of traffic conditions as related to the number of participants and the number and type of vehicles to participate in the parade or march as shown on the application for such permit; the number of police personnel available to direct traffic, properly manage such parade or march, and provide police protection to participants and the general public; and whether the city, county, state, or a public utility company has scheduled improvements along the parade route during the time of the parade which cannot be interrupted. The city manager may require the applicant for a parade permit to furnish to the city a bond in an amount not to exceed two hundred fifty thousand dollars ($250,000.00) secured by a surety company licensed to do business in the state, payable to the city or to any person in the city who may suffer any injury or damage from any vehicle, float, device or person participating in the parade or march. (e)  Police vehicle to precede parades and marches. All parades and marches through the streets of the city shall be preceded by a police vehicle and conducted in such manner as to impede and interfere with the flow of traffic to the least possible extent. (f)  Hours restricted. No parade permit shall be issued for any parade to be held between 9:00 p.m. and 9:00 a.m. (g)  Appeals from denial of parade permit. An applicant who has been denied a parade permit by the city manager has the right to file an appeal to the governing body with the city clerk within five (5) days from the date the application is denied. The governing body shall hear the appeal at any regular or special meeting of the board to be held at any time not less than fifteen (15) nor more than sixty (60) days from the date the appeal is received by the city clerk. (Code 1973, § 2-801(52), App. II, § 12) Cross reference— Miscellaneous provisions and offenses, ch. 12. State Law reference— Authority to regulate or prohibit parades, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-371(a); operation of motor vehicles in parades, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-7. 
Sec. 18-13. - Funeral processions. (a)  Vehicles of a funeral procession shall have the right-of-way over all vehicles, except authorized emergency vehicles, provided each shall identify itself by burning regular headlights, shall keep in close formation, and shall display a device with the word "funeral," in such size and form as to identify the procession as a funeral. (b)  Each driver in a funeral procession shall drive as near to the right-hand edge of the street or roadway as practicable and shall follow the vehicle ahead as close as is practicable and safe. (c)  When the lead vehicle in a funeral procession has entered an intersection on a green light, all other cars in the procession may proceed through the intersection even though such signal may change to red. (d)  No driver of a vehicle shall drive between the vehicles comprising a funeral procession while they are in motion and when these vehicles are conspicuously designated as required in this section. (Code 1973, App. II, § 36) State Law reference— Authority to regulate processions on highways, § 40-6-371(a)(3). 
Sec. 18-14. - Sanitation vehicles.     All employees and vehicles of the city when engaged or used in performance of collection of solid waste or recovered materials shall have the right-of-way in the use of the streets within the city and may stop or stand on the road, street, or highway for the sole purpose of collecting such waste or materials; provided, however, that such vehicle shall maintain flashing hazard lights at all times that it is engaged in stopping or standing for the purpose of waste or materials collection. State Law reference— Special privileges of municipal solid waste or recovered materials vehicles, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-203. 
Sec. 18-15. - Open alcohol container in motor vehicles prohibited. (a)  As used in this Code section "open container" means any container which is immediately capable of being consumed from or which the seal has been broken. (b)  No person shall possess an open container of any alcoholic beverage while operating a motor vehicle or while a passenger in a motor vehicle in operation within the city. For purposes of this code section, an open container shall be considered in the possession of the operator of the motor vehicle if the container is not in possession of a passenger, and is not located in a locked glove compartment, locked trunk, or other locked non-passenger area of the motor vehicle. (c)  Any person who violates this Code section is subject to a fine not to exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). (Ord. No. 9908, § 1, 11-22-99) 
Secs. 18-16—18-19. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - TRAFFIC ADMINISTRATION; ENFORCEMENT 
Sec. 18-20. - Authority to install traffic-control devices.     The city manager shall cause to be placed and maintained traffic-control signs and devices when and as required under this chapter and other traffic ordinances of this city to make effective the provisions of this chapter and such ordinances. The city manager may cause to be placed and maintained such additional traffic-control devices as deemed necessary to regulate traffic under this chapter and other traffic ordinances of this city or under state law, or to guide or warn traffic. (Code 1973, App. II, § 56) 
Sec. 18-21. - Duty and authority of police officers. (a)  It shall be the duty of officers of the police department to enforce this chapter and all other traffic laws of the city and all of the state vehicle laws applicable to street traffic in the city. (b)  Officers of the police department, or such officers as are assigned by the chief of police, are hereby authorized to direct all traffic by voice, hand, or signal in conformity with traffic laws; provided that, in the event of a fire or other emergency or to expedite traffic or to safeguard pedestrians, officers of the police department may direct traffic as conditions may require notwithstanding the provisions of the traffic laws. (c)  County fire officers when at the scene of a fire, may direct or assist the police in directing traffic thereat or in the immediate vicinity. (Code 1973, App. II, § 18) State Law reference— Authority to regulate traffic by means of police officers, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-371(a)(2). 
Sec. 18-22. - Delegation of powers and duties.     The city manager may delegate to any officer in the police department the duties and responsibilities conveyed to him by this chapter. (Code 1973, App. II, § 19) 
Sec. 18-23. - Traffic violations bureau—Created; administration; accepting fines. (a)  A traffic violations office to assist the court with the clerical work of traffic cases shall be established. The office shall be in charge of such persons and shall be open at such hours as the governing body may designate. (b)  The municipal judge who hears traffic cases shall designate the specified offense under this chapter or other traffic ordinances of this city and applicable state traffic laws in respect to which payment of fines may be accepted by the traffic violations office in satisfaction thereof, and shall specify by suitable schedules the amount of such fines, provided such fines are within the limits declared by law or ordinance, and shall further specify what offenses shall require appearance before the municipal judge. (Code 1973, App. II, § 114) State Law reference— Traffic violations bureau, O.C.G.A. § 40-13-50 et seq. 
Sec. 18-24. - Same—When person charged may elect to appear thereat. (a)  Any person charged with an offense for which payment of a fine may be made to the traffic violations office shall have the option of paying such fine within the time specified in the notice of arrest at the traffic violations office upon entering a plea of guilty and upon waiving appearance in court; or may have the option of depositing required lawful bail and upon a plea of not guilty shall be entitled to a trial as authorized by law. (b)  The payment of a fine to the office shall be deemed an acknowledgment of conviction of the alleged offense, and the office upon accepting the prescribed fine shall issue a receipt to the violator acknowledging the payment thereof. (Code 1973, App. II, § 115) 
Sec. 18-25. - Same—Duties.     The following duties are hereby imposed upon the traffic violations office in reference to traffic offenses: (1)  Accept designated fines and issue receipts to such violators as are permitted and desire to plead guilty and waive court appearance. (2)  Receive and issue receipts for cash bail from the persons who must or wish to be heard in court, enter the time of their appearance on the court docket, and notify the arresting officer and witnesses, if any, to be present. (3)  Keep an easily accessible record of all violations of which each person has been guilty during the preceding five (5) years, whether such guilt was established in court or in the traffic violations office. (Code 1973, App. II, § 116) 
Sec. 18-26. - Same—Following procedure.     The traffic violations office shall follow such procedure as may be prescribed by this chapter or other traffic ordinances of this city or as may be required by any laws of this state. (Code 1973, App. II, § 117) 
Sec. 18-27. - Records of traffic violations.     The traffic violations office shall keep a record of all violations of this chapter and other traffic ordinances of this city or the state vehicle laws of which any person has been charged, in the municipal court, together with a record of the final disposition of all such alleged offenses. Such record shall be so maintained as to show all types of violations and the total of each. Such record shall accumulate during at least a five-year period and from that time on the record shall be maintained complete for at least the most recent five-year period. Such matters shall be filed alphabetically under the names of the persons so arrested or convicted.     All such records shall be public records. (Code 1973, App. II, §§ 14, 17) State Law reference— Records to be kept, O.C.G.A. § 40-13-27. 
Sec. 18-28. - Licenses and reports of conviction to state department of public safety. (a)  Whenever any person is convicted of any offense for which state law mandates the suspension of the license of such person by the state department of public safety, the municipal court shall require the surrender to it of any driver's license then held by the person so convicted and the license and citation shall be forwarded to the state department of public safety within the time frame prescribed in O.C.G.A. § 40-5-53(a). (b)  Citations for other convictions of offenses pertaining to the operation of motor vehicles shall be forwarded to the state department of public safety in the manner and within the time frame prescribed in O.C.G.A. § 40-5-53(b). (c)  Any payments to the municipal court or municipal court clerk from the state department of public safety for the submission of uniform citations shall be paid into the city treasury. 
Sec. 18-29. - Accidents—Immediate notice.     The driver of a vehicle involved in an accident resulting in injury to or death of any person or property damage to an apparent extent of that amount prescribed in O.C.G.A. § 40-6-273 or more shall immediately, by the quickest means of communication, give notice of such accident to the police department if such accident occurs within this city. (Code 1973, App. II, § 24) 
Sec. 18-30. - Same—Police department to investigate; etc.     It shall be the duty of the police department to investigate traffic accidents and to arrest and assist in the prosecution of those persons charged with violations of law causing or contributing to such accidents. (Code 1973, App. II, § 15) 
Sec. 18-31. - Same—Reports by police. (a)  It shall be the duty of every member of the police department investigating a traffic accident to make a written report of such officer's findings as soon as practicable after completing the investigation. (b)  The police department shall maintain a suitable system of filing traffic accident reports required by this section. (c)  A copy of all accident reports shall be submitted to the department of public safety in the manner and within the time frame as prescribed in O.C.G.A. § 40-9-31. (Code 1973, App. II, § 16) 
Sec. 18-32. - Vehicle inspection.     It shall be an offense against the city for any person to drive or operate on any of the streets of the city any motor vehicle required to be inspected by state law which has not been so inspected. (Code 1973, App. II, § 130) State Law reference— Inspection authorized, O.C.G.A. § 40-8-200; display of valid emission inspection sticker, O.C.G.A. § 12-9-55. 
Sec. 18-33. - Driver's license. (a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a motor vehicle upon the streets of the city without having a valid driver's license in such person's immediate possession at the time. (b)  Refusal to display a valid driver's license upon the demand of a law enforcement officer shall constitute a violation of this section. (c)  A person convicted of a violation of subsection (b) of this section shall be fined in an amount not to exceed that amount prescribed in O.C.G.A. § 40-5-29(c). (Code 1973, App. II, § 131) State Law reference— Driver's license, O.C.G.A. § 40-5-29. 
Sec. 18-34. - Procedure upon arrest.     Except when authorized or directed under state law immediately to take a person arrested for a violation of any of the traffic laws before the municipal judge, any police officer, upon making an arrest for violation of this chapter or other traffic ordinance of the city or laws of the state, shall take the name, address, and operator's license number of the alleged violator and the license tag number of the motor vehicle involved and shall issue to such person on a form provided, a notice to answer to the charge against such person at a place and time to be specified in the notice. (Code 1973, App. II, § 119) State Law reference— Form of citation, O.C.G.A. § 40-13-1. 
Sec. 18-35. - When summons for arrest to be issued.     In the event any person fails to comply with a notice given to such person or attached to a vehicle or fails to make appearance pursuant to a summons directing an appearance in the traffic violations office, or if any person fails or refuses to deposit bail as required and within the time permitted by ordinance, the traffic violations office may forthwith secure and issue a summons for such person's arrest. (Code 1973, App. II, § 124) 
Sec. 18-36. - Penalty for failure to appear when served with copy of charges.     Any person who has been lawfully served with a copy of charges to appear in the municipal court and shall fail to appear at the time and place indicated in such copy of charges shall be guilty of an offense and upon conviction in the municipal court shall be punished as provided in this Code. (Code 1973, App. II, § 125) 
Sec. 18-37. - Disposition of traffic fines and forfeitures.     All fines and forfeitures collected upon conviction or upon the forfeiture of bail for any person charged with a violation of any of the provisions of this chapter or other ordinance of the city shall be paid into the city treasury. (Code 1973, App. II, § 126) 
Secs. 18-38—18-49. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - OPERATIONS OF VEHICLES GENERALLY 
Sec. 18-50. - Speed limits—Generally.     Unless otherwise specifically provided by ordinance, it shall be unlawful for any person to drive a motor vehicle in excess of twenty-five (25) miles per hour on any street with the exception of those streets listed in section 18-51. (Code 1973, App. II, § 47A; Ord. No. 775, § 1, 4-28-80) Cross reference— Speed of bicycles, § 18-153. State Law reference— Authority to decrease speed limit, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-183. 
Sec. 18-51. - Same—On streets where speed detection devices employed. (a)  On-system streets. For on-system streets see the latest speed zone order for the county as effected and issued by the state department of transportation and the state department of public safety. The state speed zone order is hereby adopted by reference thereto for those sections of state routes within the city. Signs are to be erected by the state department of transportation. _____(b)  Off-system street. The following are off-system streets, signs for which are to be erected by the city: Street     From     To Length (miles) Speed Limit (m.p.h.) Berkeley Road South Avondale Plaza Lakeview Place .40 25 Berkeley Road Lakeview Place Wiltshire Drive .30 25 Clarendon Ave. North Avondale Road Columbia Drive 1.50 30 Kensington Road Covington Highway South Avondale Plaza .80 30 North Clarendon Ave. Old Rockbridge Road North Avondale Road .30 30 South Avondale Road Fairfield Drive Clarendon Avenue .30 30  (Ord. No. 848, §§ 1, 2, 2-24-92; Ord. No. 0301, § 1, 2-24-03; Ord. No. 0308, § 1, 12-15-03; Ord. No. 0413, § 1, 12-21-04) 
Sec. 18-52. - Same—Slowly moving vehicles generally.     Slowly moving or heavily laden vehicles shall not be driven upon the streets abreast, but one must follow behind the other and keep as near the right-hand curb as possible. (Code 1973, App. II, § 50) 
Sec. 18-53. - Limitations on backing.     The driver of a vehicle shall not back the same unless such movement can be made in safety. Such backing shall be done at a speed not to exceed five (5) miles per hour, nor for a greater distance than sixty (60) feet, and never into an intersection. (Code 1973, App. II, § 43) 
Sec. 18-54. - Towing.     No vehicle shall tow more than one (1) other vehicle, nor shall the connection between vehicles exceed sixteen (16) feet in length. (Code 1973, App. II, § 46) 
Sec. 18-55. - Pass-through traffic prohibited at certain times. (a)  Between the hours of 7:00 a.m. to 9:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m. to 6:00 p.m., it shall be unlawful for pass-through traffic to enter the city at the following locations: (1)  South Avondale Road or Clarendon Avenue at either's intersection with East College Avenue/North Avondale Road and to exit at Kensington Road at its intersection with Stratford Road or at its intersection with Wynn Drive or at its intersection with Covington Highway; or (2)  Kensington Road at its intersection with Covington Highway or at its intersection with Wynn Drive or at its intersection with Stratford Road and to exit at South Avondale Plaza or to exit at Clarendon Avenue or to exit at South Avondale Road/North Avondale Road/East College Avenue. (b)  An operator of a motor vehicle shall be deemed to engage in pass-through traffic when such driver enters and exits streets in the city as above-stated without making a bona fide stop at the elementary school on Lakeshore Drive at Covington Road or within the residential district of the city, except as directed by traffic control devices. 
Sec. 18-56. - Pass through truck traffic prohibited.     It shall be unlawful for trucks to use the residential streets of the city except to make a bona fide delivery on a residential street within the city. Any person driving or in charge or control of a truck shall be prepared to present for inspection by a police officer a log book, weight slip, delivery slip or other written evidence of such person's destination in the residential district of the city and point of origin to justify the presence of the restricted vehicle on the residential street. 
Sec. 18-57. - Securing loads.     No person shall operate any vehicle with a load on the public streets and roads of the city unless the load on or in such vehicle is adequately secured so as to prevent any of its load from dropping, escaping, or shifting in such a manner as to create a safety hazard or in such a manner so as to litter the streets and roads of the city. 
Sec. 18-58. - Play streets. (a)  Authority to establish; signing. The city may declare any street or part thereof a play street and place appropriate signs or devices in the roadway indicating and helping to protect it. (b)  Driving on; speed limit. Whenever authorized signs are erected indicating any street or part thereof as a play street, no person shall drive a vehicle upon such street or portion thereof except drivers of vehicles having business or whose residences are within such closed area, and then the driver shall exercise the highest degree of care in driving upon such street or portion thereof, and at no time shall the driver's speed exceed ten (10) miles per hour. 
Sec. 18-59. - One-way streets and rotary traffic islands. (a)  Whenever this chapter or any ordinance of the city designates any one-way street or alley, signs shall be placed giving notice thereof, and no regulation shall be effective unless these signs are in place. Signs indicating the direction of lawful traffic movement shall be placed at every intersection where movement of traffic in the opposite direction is prohibited. The following are one-way streets in the direction indicated: (1)  Lakeshore Drive, northbound, from Kensington Road to Covington Road. (2)  Dartmouth Avenue, northbound, from Clarendon Place to Kingstone Road/Fairfield Plaza, from Memorial Day through Labor Day. (b)  A vehicle passing around a rotary traffic island shall be driven only to the right of such island. State Law reference— Authority to designate one-way streets, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-371(a)(4); one-way streets generally, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-47. 
Sec. 18-60. - All-way stop signs.     Whenever this chapter or any ordinance of the city designates all-way stops at intersecting streets, signs shall be placed giving notice thereof, and no regulation shall be effective unless these signs are in place. The following are designated as intersections at which traffic shall be required to stop in all directions: (1)  Berkeley Road and Kingstone Road; (2)  Dartmouth Avenue and Clarendon Place; (3)  Dartmouth Avenue and Kingstone Road and Fairfield Plaza; (4)  Exeter Road and Fairfield Plaza and Fairfield Drive; (5)  Hess Drive and Lakeshore Drive; (6)  Kensington Road and Berkeley Road and South Avondale Plaza; (7)  Kensington Road and Lakeshore Drive; (8)  Kensington Road and Stratford Road; (9)  Kensington Road and Wynn Drive; (10)  Majestic Circle and Wynn Drive; (11)  Nottingham Drive and Majestic Circle; (12)  Nottingham Drive and Wynn Drive; (13)  Nottingham Drive and Wiltshire Drive; (14)  Wiltshire Drive and Hess Drive; (15)  Wiltshire Drive and Majestic Circle; (16)  Wiltshire Drive and Stratford Road; (17)  Wiltshire Drive and Lakeshore Drive and Lakeshore Plaza; (18)  Wiltshire Drive and Berkeley Road; (19)  Windsor Terrace and Melford Place. 
Secs. 18-61—18-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - PARKING, STOPPING AND STANDING 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
Sec. 18-81. - Parking for certain purposes.     No person shall park a vehicle upon any roadway for: (1)  Displaying such vehicle for sale. (2)  Washing, greasing or repairing such vehicle except repairs necessitated by sudden emergency; in such emergency, such vehicle shall be moved or towed away with all due haste. (3)  For displaying advertising. (Code 1973, App. II, § 68) 
Sec. 18-82. - Illegal parking—Presumption.     In any prosecution charging a violation of any law or regulation governing the standing or parking of a vehicle, proof that the particular vehicle described in the complaint was parked in violation of any such law or regulation, together with proof that the defendant named in the complaint was at the time of such parking the registered owner of such vehicle, shall constitute in evidence a prima facie presumption that the registered owner of such vehicle was the person who parked or placed such vehicle at the point where, and for the time during which, such violation occurred. (Code 1973, App. II, § 120) 
Sec. 18-83. - Same—Owner liable; vehicle subject to impoundment.     It shall be unlawful for any person to allow, permit or suffer any vehicle registered in such person's name to stand or park in any street in violation of this chapter or any other ordinance of the city regulating the parking of vehicles. Such person shall be equally liable with the operator for such violation and, in addition thereto, the vehicle may be removed and conveyed by the police department. (Code 1973, App. II, § 127) 
Sec. 18-84. - Manner of parking. (a)  No person shall stand or park a vehicle in a roadway other than parallel with the edge of the roadway headed in the direction of lawful traffic movement and with the right-hand wheels of the vehicle within six (6) inches of the curb or edge of the roadway, except as otherwise provided in this article. (b)  Vehicles may be parked at an angle at such places as may be provided by property owners adjacent to the street where the indentations provided by such property owners extend a sufficient distance from the original curbline to allow vehicles parked at an angle in such places to project into such street beyond such curbline a distance no greater than the width of such vehicles, the amount of space occupied in such street thereby being no greater than in cases of parallel parking, or at such places where the roadway is of sufficient width as determined by the city manager and chief of police to allow for such angle parking. (c)  No person shall park at an angle any vehicle twenty-four (24) feet or more in length on any street or roadway in the city. 
Sec. 18-85. - Vehicles to be parked within marked spaces.     Whenever a space is marked off on any highway or street for the parking of a vehicle, the vehicle there parked shall be parked within the lines bounding that space. 
Sec. 18-86. - Emergency parking restrictions.     When not inconsistent with this chapter or any other ordinance, the city manager and chief of police have authority in an emergency to prohibit the parking or stopping of vehicles on any street or portion of a street or to close a street to traffic. All these orders shall be temporary only. 
Sec. 18-87. - Authority to prohibit parking in certain streets.     When not inconsistent with this chapter or any other ordinance, the city manager and chief of police may prohibit parking or stopping of vehicles on any street or portion of a street when traffic and engineering surveys indicate that stopping or parking may impede the free flow of traffic on the street. 
Sec. 18-88. - Parking prohibited in specified places. (a)  No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with law or the direction of a police officer or traffic control device in any of the following places: (1)  Between the front building restriction line and the front street line except on a bona fide paved driveway leading to a garage, carport, or other paved parking place; (2)  On a sidewalk or on the verge between the sidewalk and roadway; (3)  On the roadway side of any vehicle stopped or parked at the edge of a curb of a street; (4)  Within an intersection; (5)  On a crosswalk; (6)  Between a safety zone and the adjacent curb or within thirty (30) feet of points on the curb immediately opposite the ends of a safety zone, unless a different length is indicated by signs or markings;
